I disagree with the standards is happening here, I am not convinced. In some cases there are good reviews, in other see that there are some 'too many prejudices against certain films!

title: Non-stop homage to the classics
review: The kind of film I normally avoid. Being a connoisseur of the old Universal films of the 30s and early 40s, I refused to watch it out of loyalty for the franchise that Lugosi and Karloff and Chaney created. Then I happened to watch the opening scene. This movie has no plot that could engage anyone with half a brain, mixes up lore and myth (when I go to the cathedral of Notre Dame in Paris I expect to see Quasimodo, not Mr.Hyde of Edinburgh, especially as the former is at least Universal property), smothers everything in cgi, throws in one lame plot device after another to extricate itself from the holes it digs for itself etc etc etc. and yet... for someone 13 and under it is the kind of movie to be seen over and over again. Kind o like the originals (it's hard to defend the integrity of films such as Frankenstein Meets the Wolfman after all). Not one dull moment, some wonderful characterisations of old classics (I particularly enjoyed that of Dracula), a great soundtrack and some loving attentions of detail that stand out amidst the sloppy and lazy areas such as when a piece of paper obtained centuries earlier still has the exact same shape and hue as the outlying wall from which it was removed). The atmosphere too evokes something out of Karl Freund. www.lairdkeir.spaces.live.com

title: Save your money and rent later...
review:
I was very disappointed with this flick. Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale, both of whom are capable of riveting performances, were flat and uninteresting. They let the clothes, accents, and weapons do the acting for them. Richard Roxburgh, as Dracula, could be menacing and seductive in quiet moments, but all too easily his performance turns over-the-top. Dracula's brides are shrill and much too annoying to be scary. Igor seems to have inherited the lines of Mr. Freeze from the fourth "Batman" movie.

However, there are reasons that makes this movie a rentable rather than a film to ignore. (1) The flatness of the story and performances of the above-mentioned should diminish a bit on the smaller screen. (2) David Wenham, as Van Helsing's jittery but spunky sidekick Carl, puts more personality into one line than most of the others can put into an entire performance. He's the everyman and the story's humor. (3) Shuler Hensley brings in the heart and soul of the flick as Frankenstein's Monster. He, more than anyone else, captures the humanity of a character. All in all, this is a flick to rent when you don't want to think too hard, not something you shell out movie-ticket money on.

title: Waste of money
review: This movie has exactly two good thingies in it: the talent of Hugh Jackman and the nice looks of Kate Beckinsale. The rest - well, no story, awful effects...I should have spended the money elsewhere. For a movie that was that expensive it looks like a B-Movie. It also feels like one. It was a great idea somehow. To bring all the old monsters together, against a newish Van Helsing. Besides him, a beautiful lady with a real task. But the director wasn't able to do anything good with the script which as well was full of holes. If there just were good special effects, then i would have said, great action movie. But even this failed. The guys of ILM didn't have their best day at all.

title: 86 proof Hesling
review: I thought it'd be kinda fun to write a review while I was totally blotto. Is that the right word? Like, drunk. Because writing a review sober got really dull. So, now I have a beautiful perspective on this Van Hesling mess. And it was a fine mess I got myself into! Like Laural and Hardy, get it! HA! Don't you hate exclamation marks?! They are so presumptuous! And you know what?! This was a really fun movie. It was just like being on a thrill ride that goes up and down and back and forth and round and round...oh boy, I feel like I'm gonna puke. Fortunately I wasn't drunk when I was sitting in my theater seat, which was so much like a thrill ride. BANK TO THE RIGHT! NOW TO THE LEFT! It was just like that. So, if you want a thrill ride, go to Disneyland, or this movie. Or, maybe you like 6 Flags. I like Disneyland's Space Mountain, but it's been closed forever while they are making it into a new ride. It's taking them 3 years to change the best ride at Disneyland. Why don't they just leave it alone and take 3 years to make a different ride? I'll tell you why, because they put all the new rides over in California Adventure! Is that a rook or what?! But fortunately they put all the goodies into just one ride here, called Van Hesling! Like, flying bat women! They are the coolest thing from any movie ever made. And it's a really long movie, so you get your moneys worth even if you buy some bon bons. I've never bought bon bons, but I sure would like to someday. But until then, I give this movie a nine out of ten. Don't you hate it when somebody says they really like a movie but they won't commit to give it a full ten out of ten. Like, "I'm too cool to give any movie but Citizen Kane ten out of ten because I don't want to lose the respect of all my fans who are just waiting until I write my next review so they'll be able to go to a movie again." Yeah, so there you go.

title: I liked it, but it could have been much better.
review:
Picture James Bond in the 1800's and instead of fighting criminals he is fighting monsters and you will have a pretty good idea of what this version of the movie is like. They even go so far as including a Bond Babe (Kate Beckinsale) and Q the Gadget Guy (David Wenham). Most of the creature effects were obviously left 'outrageous' to fit with the 'Monster Movie' theme and I feel that the movie could have been a lot better had they done it 'more realistic'. It could have also been a very good horror movie as well as a very good action movie instead of just a decent action movie with monsters had they focused more on the story and less on the effects. Dracula's effects were very cool until the end when they became more like the other 'cartoonish' effects. Although the elements of Dracula's plot were cool, I feel the delivery of it was too corny and cheap and thus took away from the story. I knew that I wasn't going to like the creature affects from the trailers but I had hoped that the story would make up for it, unfortunately, it did not.

I am sure there will be sequels a plenty for this one, especially if it continues to make the money it did in the first weekend. I will probably go see those sequels as well as watch the TV Series, but since the base on which they are built didn't meet my expectations, I can't see myself enjoying them as much as I could have had the original movie been up to par.

Even so, I give this one a 'it in a good theatre and rent/buy it when it comes out on DVD' rating.

title: Not bad at all
review:
Well, I've read some of the comments on this one, but I guess I like this kind of movies too much to think it's a bad one. It's actually one of the best in this genre I've seen so far (in the last 5 years or so), I'd like to see it again sometime soon.

Sure it lacks the well-liked ironic twist of movies like The Mummy 1&2 and League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, but that's because it's somewhere between those and a movie like Ghost Ship (bit more serious).

Also the story would've been more appealing if it wasn't so questionable to whether any part of the movie was actually shot in Transsylvania.

And yes, it would've been a better movie if the characters were a little less shallow, if there was a deeper plot and if some humour and possibly some more 'romantic' scenes were thrown in.

I know I would've liked the movie even more with all of that in, but then it would've become a 3-hour movie, because it would be a crying shame to leave out or shorten some of the action scenes.

The attention to detail in general and in the action scenes in particular is great, but it's just one of those movies where the special effects are most impressive when seen in a movie theatre.

There's little time to enjoy all of it though, because the story goes on and on at a whalloping speed. I wouldn't have mind sitting out the above mentioned longer/better version, but in reality the current two hours plus is already more than enough for most people I think.

Having said this all, it's not a movie everyone will like, but definitely one worth seeing.

title: A CGI fest
review:
The story itself is OK but is comparable to "The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen" - many plots of many authors of the 18th century are mixed together.

Unfortunately "van Helsing" uses an overdose of computer generated effects to create bridges from one scene to another.

Worth to see (for the effects and smooth incoperation of the real live scenes) but not worth to remember.

At least for me as an European, where the stories about Frankensteins Monster, Dracula and other stories mentioned in this film are well known.

title: Steve makes the movies for ME!
review:
I'm 43 and my nine year old son and I just saw Van Helsing. This is what movie making should be, two hours of being blown away! If you liked the Mummy, this is that movie times Ten. Every critic that says there are plot hole?, That's what the sequel is for. This movie kicks major butt, and I hope S Summers has more in him. title: Good action....But the story is weak at best
review:
The Story is weak, predictable. The Action and SFX were good, but thats all this movie had going for it. There were corny scenes like every ten minutes. Richard Roxburgh was a horrible Dracula, Kate Beckinsale did not give a good performance. Hugh Jackman was okay. If you are looking for a good vampire movie with action, blade and blade II are good. Angel the TV series is good. Interview with a Vampire is excellent.

If you wanna see this movie for its action, see it, but don't count on the story. If you want a movie with story, check out man on fire, an excellent movie.

title: Continuing to make these movies, even in 2004.
review: Why do they even bother? Or more precisely, why does Stephen Sommers even bother? Because when you've got money and 'clout', you can release anything and get away with it. This film was an absolute waste of time and money. Over-the-top special effects and ridiculously far-fetched action sequences made for a punishing two-hour experience. There was no style or originality to any of the action, and computer-generated images took the place of human performances. With regards to the performances, they were as wooden as the stakes repeatedly used and referred to throughout this film, not helped at all by the awfully clichÃ©d script that somehow made its way to the final draft. Then again, the writer, director and producer are the same person, so there's the answer. This isn't even a self-indulgent movie on Sommers' part. It hasn't got enough depth for it to be. Then again, perhaps that says all we need to know about Sommers, and both a person and a filmmaker? Van Helsing feels like it belongs in the 90's, as an experiment in different ways to use special effects. The only difference is that it's 2004, and we've seen it all before. Not only that, but we've seen the special effects used better and action sequences choreographed a lot classier. This is the type of film that is so bad it doesn't even deserve a review, but the people need one so that they know not to see it!

title: Classic horror fiction as pop art
review: Let's start with the good. Kate Beckinsale looks and sounds great. OK the accent is pretty corny, but we are in Universal horror territory here. The Dracula Brides are also beautiful and well used, but then it would be difficult to screw up these characters. Shame Josie Maran has less screen time than her counterparts, but she makes the most of her appearances. There is a nice return to traditional werewolf folklore in the transformation sequences, not quite "Company of Wolves" but you get the idea. Similarly, the Frankenstein's Monster is well portrayed, harking back to his literary character. The film's period detail and costumes are well thought out. But there were few things which annoyed me a little. Stephen Sommers does love his CGI. We're not quite into "The Mummy Returns" migraine inducing levels, but certainly getting there. Wolfmen just don't look great as cartoons. I also appreciate that it must be difficult to think up an original concept for Dracula, and Richard Roxburgh's gypsy king is brave stab at this, but sadly it just doesn't work. He just looks wrong. Hugh Jackman's Gabriel Van Helsing is an interesting character, but it would have been nice to hear more of his backstory (perhaps a mention of Abraham?). Having Jackman play another character suffering from historical amnesia is just lazy. But the story moves along at a brisk pace and is very atmospheric. If you loved Sommers' Mummy movies, I'm sure you'll enjoy this, but I think vampire purists should perhaps stay away. You'll only get upset! Don't take it too seriously and you'll have a fun, if unsubstantial, ride.

title: I vant my monaay back!!!!
review: What a sorry stinker created by such a talented writer/director. To say that this movie would be worth seeing for 13 year olds, would be an insult to the entire "tween" generation. While boasting a talented & capable array of actors this movie disabled them with an onslaught of CGI special effects. At one point I thought why do they need actors here anyway, why not CGI the entire thing? The whole budget could have been reduced by half if they slashed the special effects segments and just let the actors do their jobs. Providing of course the was a better plot, script and dialogue! It was painful sitting through the movie and watching it's eventual decent into the "death spiral", only to go up in smoke in the end. The ending was the "final stake thru the heart"! Didn't anyone tell the truth in the screening room? Apparently not! No amount of video games, action figures and fast food tie-ins can redeem the money lost in this production. I can only imagine that the initial script had an ending in the making. Because any actor who read this script and gave it the green light should have his head examined or get a better agent to make his decisions. What kind of signing bonus could they have possibly given? Even taken in the action/adventure/horror genre this movie was a so over the top it went back to lacking. If you're going to beat a dead horse, then you need to beat it very well. It need the right balance between tongue in cheek and drama. He had found it in the Mummy but couldn't seem to nail it here. It goes without saying that an audience can be very forgiving within this genre. So how could this have been such a spectacular disappointment? Needless to say I left the theater thinking "I vant my monaay back"!!!

title: You know, from the point of view of 2003, 2004 looked like a historical year didn't it?
review:
I mean we had Brad Pitt in the Trojan War, we had the Mummy Man pitching the genius concept of a Hammer "Versus" revival, we had Ridley Scott going all epic on us again(!!!), and this is of course excepting the showstopper and king, Spider-man making a victory lap. Well Troy I can tell you is great but Van Helsing sucks. How will Scott do?

Tell me honestly that you weren't drooling when he pitched the idea? Come on, Dracula, Frankenstein and Wolf Man versus a gizmo-ed cross-wielding revision of the first (and coolest sounding) Vampire Hunter? And writer-director Sommers sounded like the man for the job didn't he? In our post-Mummy glow we assumed he knew what to do with it. Alas however it's an affront to logic but Sommers took exactly the same approach with Van Helsing as he did with Mummy 2. But Mummy 2 was pretty good wasn't it, so whats wrong this time? Dear me, where to start?

Firstly, check the cast list Sommers, Brendan Fraser isn't in this one. Without his irresistible goofy wit the one-liners are going to flatten right out. Without his reliable gung-ho approach to everything complimenting that wit, love for the hero is also sliced in half. Without Oded Fehr to back him up there's no co-adventurer we'll swear allegiance to. Without the adorable and hot-as-hell Rachel Wiesz there's no heroin we feel aloud to love from afar. And we can't forget Johnathan and Beni, without them what do we have to chuckle at? What did Van Helsing need?

Well the second I saw that early concept art of Dracula, Frankenstein and Wolf Man I thought Sommers DID know what to do. He was goth-ing it up, I was prepared to sacrifice the humour because I knew it just couldn't sit. I thought Van Helsing would be a convergence of Myths(capital 'M' intended). You can't Nintendo it all up and make these beasties as commonplace as vermin. They should have delved into the Myst-rigue inherent and used the sheer value of these legendary characters to come up with a story that we wanted to watch. They could have chopped that $180mil in half, and put a few hundred grand into a power play that actually interested us on a cerebral level. So lastly, what does the movie have?

I cant believe he actually dared to use the same junk that not only every other adventure movie used but that his own leading man lived off. Come on, forgotten pasts, dark secrets, soulful quests thats not only Wolverine its the Mummy movies and its wanderer mentality which comes into nearly everything. We've had way too much of that already, he should have given it a miss. Sexy as Beckinsale is she cant be both the quest and the love interest and fellow-adventurer and the victim etc, thats just absurdly uninteresting. And Dracula, oh boy. As big a fan as I am of Ozzie actors penetrating Hollywood I'm afraid my countryman was miscast. Dracula HAS to be very tall and very menacing. We should feel as we did in 1898 when John Harker first encoundered this forgotten King who transcended centuries and fought historical battles (Vlad the Impaler). We should feel like a child that needs permission to leave their bedroom before him. Oldman was a stupid choice in 1990 for the "faithful" adaptation and so was Roxburgh. Short of suggesting who he should have cast I'll leave it at that.

And he cribbed from Godzilla!! I mean for goodness sake, there are some movies that should be completely off-limits for theft, out of pure common decency and what of all the $180mil flops of last 10 decades would top the list? Sommers tried to elevate the events of the movie to transcend Transylvania. He should have instead dwelled on the character that the entire "franchise" depended on.

Listen this could go on for pages but it doesn't need to. Here's hoping that the movie makes enough to warrant a sequel in which they might (but likely cant) improve things. Otherwise, and likely, Jackman is still looking for that much touted Indiana Jones to succeed his Han Solo (Wolverine), but my greatest fear is that this will be the finishing attempt at resurrecting the Vampire King. Please, please no.

title: Very entertaining take on the whole thing...
review:
I had never really followed the van helsing character but I liked this movie...

Regardless of what some people say.. I'm going to post my opinion... it WAS entertaining.. in fact I want to own it on DVD.. was it the most brilliant ever? No... and acting... it was decent.. but I really didn't pay attention to it... I was actually pretty engrossed in the movie... For those that are willing to suspend disbelief it can really draw you in..

Over all... it was an action film.. I liked the new take on Dracula's character though, and I think the cgi was blended nicely with the transformations in battle... All in all a good film... just MY opinion..

title: A truly fantastic film that feeds your lust for action
review:
Having just seen it tonight when this review was originally being wrote, I couldn't help but be inspired by the dynamic and professional CGI used in this film, not to mention keeping the originality of the story the same as the myth/legend which makes the film 'inform' you about the history of Transylvania and the origins of Van Helsing and the Vampires.

As said by the user proceeding this review, it starts out as Frankenstein; originally played by Boris Karloff in the older films being created by a mad scientist under the counts employ. The Frankenstein is the key for the Count's children to have eternal life only all doesn't go to plan.

He is hunted down by villagers who resent and despise evil and the undead so therefore the Frankenstein is inevitably pursued by these and the ending for him in the beginning is not nice.

Anyhow, a year later, a certain Van Helsing; know for being a murderer and wanted is of Holy origin whom has had his memory washed away for reasons and has been training by monks, friars and any followers of the Vatican.

Then he is assigned to help the family who have been fighting Dracula for more than 400 years, the last descendant of this holy family is Anna; strong willed women to carry out her laid out duties. Soon, they find out a secret the count has that links Van Helsing and Anna together... you can find that out watching the movie. All in all you will not be disappointed by the action, dramatical depth to the storyline, the CGI effects, scenes that will make you jump like me, the comedy has reference to "A La James Bond Style", especially with the Igor who quaintly played Benny in "The Mummy" which if you loved then this film is the one for you.

title: just when did Stephen Sommers get a lobotomy...?
review:
Watching The Mummy again after sitting through Van Helsing really makes you wonder exactly what Stephen Sommers is thinking these days... How on earth could someone responsible for an imaginative, witty script and sympathetic characters 5 years ago have descended to the level of Van Helsing today?

The answer, I'd imagine, is that he's had obscene amounts of money thrown at him to make Van Helsing, so the dire end result shouldn't really be surprising. What is surprising is that the huge budget couldn't stretch to making the CGI even as good as the 1999 original... that's worrying, more than anything, considering that most of the film is computer generated.

What we're left with is Hugh Jackman suffering a sudden charisma bypass (didn't see that one coming!) the moment he got those stupid hair extensions. Kate Beckinsdale, meanwhile, had a chance to prove that Underworld was no one-off - she has now lost any acting ability she once had, and I spent most of the film wondering how she could breathe in that ridiculous corset. Does she even read the scripts herself these days? Amazing how a cursed Rumanian gypsy princess manages to be a less exciting character than Rachel Weisz's daffy librarian, but the difference is that Evie had brains and a cute grudge against the Benbridge Scholars. Anna has a creaky 'concept', an extremely dodgy accent, a rather unconvincing way with a sword and by all rights should get killed off within 5 minutes of her character being introduced. Shame.

The script is banal at best - David Wenham's lapsed friar, Carl, gets all the best lines, and very slim pickings they are. The days of Sommer's wisecracking hero seem awfully long ago, as Jackman just sleepwalks his way through the unfunny moments he does have. Added to the zero chemistry between him and Kate Beckinsdale and I was wanting to either fall asleep or walk out (it was a late showing!) every time either of them was onscreen. That would be nearly every scene, then...

The plot doesn't even bear thinking about - it certainly owed nothing to logic, reason or good storytelling. Aside from the camp black and white prologue - which raises a faint smile - and a sumptuously produced ballroom scene (choreographed a la Cirque du Soleil), there a no 'wow' moments. Not at all. The film has been CGI'd to death at heart - which was sadly the way The Mummy Returns was headed, but at least that inherited decent characters to buoy it up.

It's hard to convey exactly how mind-numbingly awful Van Helsing is. Unfunny, tedious and essentially heartless, not even the added pathos of Frankenstein's monster can redeem it. It would seem Sommers has followed the Wachowskis and George Lucas down the road of forgetting how to write, direct or cast convincingly the moment they hit the big time.

title: Loads of Action and The plots actually Good to
review:
I saw a preview of this last week and i've got to say it's a cool film

a lot of action and story and great visual effects some dodgy Accents but Kate Beckinsale shines as Anna she has to brake a curse that has killed most of her family line the curse is Dracula and to try and save her brother whos been bitten by the wolfman and Hugh Jackman is great as Van Helsing the man sent to kill Count Draco and his Brides and to protect Anna and the fact that he can't remember anything about his past but Dracula know exactly who Van helsing is a story that has a tragic end and gave me a few frights in the cinema. some of Stephen Sommers great work since The Mummy and its sequal

title: Represents everything that is wrong with Hollywood
review:
"So you're the great Van Helsing..." "And you're a deranged pyschopath killer."

As soon as that crafty dialogue hit my ears, I knew I was in for a long ride. What followed was one of the most uninspiring and unoriginal movies I've ever seen.

Van Helsing is the story about a guy who everyone supposedly hates but who everyone needs -- to fight the monsters that haunt citizens. You'll see all your favorites here, folks. There's the Wolfman and Frankenstein and Dracula.

The screenwriter had arguably the easiest job in the entire world -- make a story that combines these creatures and make it jumpy and include the funny little follower and the hot chick and the tough guy. And the screenwriter did just that - produce a script that would pass off as typical Hollywood crap so we can cash our million dollar checks.

What a horrible movie. I honestly felt cheated after having seen it.

(Note: There is a flash of brilliance in this movie, if you can believe it. Kudos to the director and the production designer for the ballroom scene. Very odd and creepy. Only bright spot in what could possibly be the worst movie I've ever seen.)

title: Fun action, but lacking in any true sense of horror
review:
Pop culture likes to emphasize that `this is not your father's (insert radio/TV/personal pastime here).' Well, such is the case with Van Helsing, the new horror/action thriller, starring Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale. Based on the character who so valiantly fights Count Dracula in Bram Stoker's original novel, and who has been reincarnated on the screen by everyone from Edward Van Sloan (1931) to Peter Cushing (1958) to Sir Laurence Olivier (1979) to Sir Anthony Hopkins (1992), Jackman is hardly the Victorian Era drawing room intellectual who battles evil using crosses, wooden stakes and cloves of garlic so frequently resurrected for the screen. And that is to both the film's good and detriment. Jackman's Van Helsing, a black leather-clad, fedora-sporting adventurer, is employed by the Vatican to battle the world's monsters and evils. Like some 19th century James Bond, he carries an arsenal of advanced weaponry (i.e., a crossbow that shoots a rapid-fire succession of arrows), all devised by his own `Q', a bookish friar named Carl who also serves as his sidekick. When first we meet Van Helsing, he is confronting the belligerent and murderous Mr. Edward Hyde, a bellicose, cigar-smoking giant, who has completely taken over the body of the kindly Dr. Henry Jekyll. The two battle inside a French cathedral (it's not clear if it is Notre Dame), with the end result being Hyde/Jekyll killed, and a centuries old stained glass window shattered. Such results are typical of this Van Helsing's battles, which has him in disfavor with his superiors in Vatican City, despite his success at curbing the world's monster population. Following his exploits in Paris, Van Helsing is sent to Transylvania, where it is learned Count Dracula is close to exterminating the Valeriouses, a wealthy family with close ties to the Vatican. There, Van Helsing uncovers a plot by the Count and his fiendish brides to unleash thousands of vampires upon the world, brought to life through the electrical charge Dr. Frankenstein found in lightning and used to create his monster (the Count, in fact, needs the Monster to carry out his plan). Standing in the Count's way, alongside Van Helsing, is the beautiful and resourceful Anna Valerious (Beckinsale) and her brother Velkan, who has been cursed as a werewolf. You see, in the story as devised by writer-director Stephen Sommers, a werewolf can kill a vampire, although they typically don't because they are usually under the vampire's power. This is the first time that Van Helsing, a character privy until now only

to Dracula, has become involved with the big three, Dracula, Frankenstein's monster and the Wolfman. He has a new first name; Gabriel, not Abraham. And, as personified by Jackman, he is far sexier than Van Sloan's myopic crusader, or Olivier's Dutch accent challenged vampire slayer. Truth be told, Jackman's Van Helsing is far more warrior than professor, acrobatically waging war against the Count and his minions, while leaving to others the deciphering of any riddles connected to Dracula's scheme. This Van Helsing is a man of action, not the mind, a major departure from the character as envisioned by Stoker. To give him a new look and history seems so apropos in this day and age of `extreme makeover', but, so much is accomplished through f/x and CG, there is a human element that is lost. Sommers makes a vain attempt to humanize Van Helsing with a back story that makes his mission to destroy Dracula a personal one, but mostly, in Sommers vision, Van Helsing loses his connection to the audience, and instead becomes just another super-hero swallowed up by stunts. Van Helsing is a fun thrill ride that carries a touch of nostalgia (specifically, a superb black and white salute to the Universal horror film of the 1930s), but which never reaches in to illuminate the soul of the character or cast a true shadow of horror on the audience.

title: Van Schmelshing (Spoliers ahead)
review:
Oh my god - where do I begin pulling this turkey to pieces?

Ok, let's start by mourning the loss of Hugh Jackman's %100 record for making good films. Although his acting is of its usual high standard in this 3-legged donkey of a movie, the script was appaling and I'm still trying to work out what accent he was going for. However, I won't start attacking accents just yet... I'm saving that for Kate Beckinsale's Transylvannian, Irish, Christopher Lambert, Twin Peaks attempt that was about as convincing as England's entry in last year's Eurovision Song Contest (don't worry Americans - you're not missing out on anything, trust me). Kate - Nil point (say this with a French accent)!

Before seeing this film I had been praying and praying that Hugh Jackman would be cast as Superman in the upcoming remake that is, might, could, perhaps, was, will be, being made. However, I think that after being subjected to Van Schmelsching ruining what would otherwise have been a fine bucket of sweet popcorn, Danny DeVito would make a more convincing Super Kent.

In short - the script is utterly terrible (Kate Beckinsale - "nothing is faster than Transylvannian horses"... except for the Wolfman, Dracula and all 3 of his brides), The plot is lacking in consistency at best (Why are Dracula's offspring laid as dinosaur eggs..? Why was Frankenstein encased in a block of ice..?) and the CGI was completely pants (no specific examples are necessary).

Another problem that Hollywood seems to have with films set in "Ye Olden Times" is the pathetic ways they manage to get explosions into films that could only ever fit into Independence Day, ie The Wolfman jumps on top of a horse drawn carriage and the roof cathes fire which moments later leads to an explosion that could only have been caused by the computer-detenated C4 lift-shaft scene in Die Hard. Now, I may not be Steven Hawking but I'm pretty sure there's no scientific explanation for that.

The films only saving grace is Kate Beckinsale's scantily clad frame but this is constantly ignored when she speaks in her native Transylvannian, Irish, Christopher Lambert, Twin Peaks tongue.

Give this one a miss folks!

title: Could be, but it isn't...
review: SPOILERS..I watched this movie expecting to see something like Mummy or, at least, like The Mummy Returns. I was not expecting too much. Having thrown in one movie Dracula, Frankenstein's monster and the Wolfman means that it can't be a serious horror movie. Or can it be?? Perhaps in this question Mr Sommers gave the answer "yes" or, even worse, "maybe". And what's the result?? In one word CATASTROPHE!!! SPOILERS: We have Van Helsing. "Gabriel" Van Helsing.The "left hand of God"!!!Does this ring a bell??It does for me.You want help?? Well, obviously somebody thought it would be clever and deep and intriguing to create a connection between the monster hunter and an Archangel!!Yes, AN ARCHANGEL!!And the excuse is that Mr Sommers did not like the name "Abraham"!Pretty convincing, right?? We leave that aside and we move on:We have Dracula.And the brides. And they want to have kids (about a million of them!!) and thus destroy the world. And, in order to bring their - obviously dead, since their parents are dead - kids to life, they need Frankenstein's monster.And this monster is hiding in the basement.And it definitely likes Jonh's "Apocalypse" as well, since it screams in an advanced shakespearean way "As I walk in the valley of the shadow and death...".And we have the good girl's brother who becomes a wolfman and wants to kill the girl.And, of course, we have the beautiful heroine and the sexy hero...And, naturally, when we have all these together, we can have anything but a serious movie.But some people did not seem to realize that. So, we have a script suitable for a good parody, a nice comic relief guy(Wenham) and an excellent portrait of a self-sarcastic Dracula by -clever- Roxburgh. The rest of the cast/crew/film, though, seems to fail to understand how and what. So, they act seriously while dealing with extremely hilarious facts and situations and they end up looking stupid and ridiculous. Obviously Mr Sommers spent large amounts of money on visual fx and other technical things.Perhaps he should spend a little more time in guiding his cast, leading them through the same way into a "pure-blood" movie. A movie that knows what it is and does not hover between the super-light and the super-grand.3/10 for decent performances.

title: C'mon critics It wasn't that bad. Warning! One small Spoiler
review: Warning small spoiler! I have seen a lot of bad movies in my time. This doesn't deserve the five it's getting. Who expected this to be another Frankenstein or Dracula? NOBODY! Did anyone here see the other Stephen Sommers movie "The Mummy"? Fun, campy, silly stuff. That's what I expected and thats what I got. Compared with most uninteresting trash thats out there now at least this entertained me. Don't compare this to the original Frankenstein thats a whole other class of film. AND I found it an interesting twist to make the character Van Helsing (Spoiler here)Gabriel, the archangel who has no memory. AND it made my laugh more than once. AND of course it was ridicules. That's it.

title: could have been a great movie
review:
After reading some comments, I didn't expect much from this movie. Still, I'm disappointed. For an action one, it was simply boring, I couldn't blame all those folks in the cinema who talked practically non-stop or laughed at wrong moments.

The biggest fault was destroying Dracula, and the character was destroyed from the beginning. What induced Sommers to force Roxburgh to play the Count in such a theatrical manner? It did remember me of Return of the King, when Jackson also slaughtered Denethor by poor script and poor staging and left Noble to pick up the debris. Sure, both Noble and Roxburgh managed their way, but it's a pity they were put on the losing position from the start. This could have been the best Dracula ever. I'd love to see Roxburgh play Vetinari (the Patrician of Ankh-Morpork from Discworld series), but only under a better director.

It would also pay to choose better actresses for the brides. The rest of cast were good, but the "Transilvanian" accents made ME cringe, and I'm not even a native speaker.

The stereotyping was awful, I'm damn happy I'm not a Romanian, I'd either laugh all the way through gritted teeth or fly from the theatre screaming.

Anyway, the music was good, the landscapes fantastic and the sets and camera work did manage to create some atmosphere.

I'm not sorry I saw this film, but I wish I had left ALL my braincells at home.

One thing helped me to go through this movie pretty painlessly, even through those moments when Dracula was not on screen - there was always something nice to look at: the leading male characters were handsome guys, the women at least had interesting clothes, the mountains were beautiful etc.

title: Worth the time
review: If you're looking for a good way to spend 2 hours, go see this movie. Sure, Frankenstein isn't how you remember him from other movies, but he is how he's supposed to be in the book, more or less.  Hollywood has done a lot of damage to the Monster, and now it's time for a more accurate portrayal of Mary Shelley's creation. Hugh Jackman does a good job NOT playing Wolverine, and Kate Beckinsale does Romanian with the best of them.  This is from the guy who brought us "The Mummy" so expect some camp along with your action/adventure.  As someone who has read both "Dracula" and "Frankenstein," I was not disappointed by the way the movie turned out.

title: A truly terrible film..
review:
I want my money back!

This movie was below feeble. From the opening scene, where the lead villain was introduced, I was disappointed. Had this movie been a documentary of the life and times of Liberace, then the casting would have been inspired. Who was this man and why was he pretending to be a badass vampire? This is, quite simply, the WORST piece of casting I had ever seen. We can forgive the fact that Hugh 'Wolverine' Jackman was present - this was a Hollywood farce, after all, but I was totally unmoved by the limp presence and performance of this actor. And don't get me started on the plot and plot devices. This movie actively 'ripped off' other, superior, movies. There is the whole James Bond, Q, scene. There is the Lord of The Rings, bridge scene. The Matrix is touched on. Unbelievably, The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen is robbed of its Mr Hyde. And, believe it or not, there are ACTUALLY Umpa Loompas in this film! The plot is so bad that it is predictable from the first 5 minutes! Admittedly, there were some good action scenes in this movie but I was distracted from enjoying them from laughing at the rest of the awfulness. Do not waste your money. Oh, and by the way, Kate Beckinsale does, and always will, look damn awesome in leather.

Edmundos

I do find it amazing that people, and I am neither commenting on your intelligence or claiming that you are numbnuts, do seem to miss the point of going to see a movie like...Van Helsing. I do realize that you are entitled to y'alls opinions and I would like to clarify something for you... A)A movie like Van Helsing is meant sole for entertainment, not for deep conversation. It did have a plot, mind you, not a very deep one, but you could follow it and get what its purpose was. B)It cannot possibly be the absolute worse movie any of y'all have ever seen because there have been some absolute bombs. C)Perhaps y'all should watch previews or wait for reviews to see if it is a movie you would be interested in it...before going to the movies, wasting your time, and b*tching about the money you spent. For what it is worth I found the movie enjoyable, going into the movie theatre to watch what I got...a CGI filled vampire slaying mindless action film. :)

title: Mary Shelley and Bram Stoker are turning in their graves!
review: I won't say that I had no expectations going in. I did. And coming out I thought, "Everyone knows that Mina Harker was instrumental in the death of Dracula." And when I look at it from a non-biased view point, I really must say... it still blew! The movie lost me when Jekyll/Hyde showed up. I thought, "Oh look, deleted scenes from A League of Extraordinary Gentlemen." Then the so-called "plot twists" kept getting worse and worse. How many movies does Kate Beckinsale need to be in that are werewolves vs. vampires? And how many roles does Hugh Jackman need where he has chops and Berserker claws? While the graphics and action sequences were entertaining, the acting seemed over the top and a little too comical to do anything but hurt the movie. Dracula was unsexy, his brides were just 90210 bitches with wings, and the whole vampire offspring twist seemed a little like it was the idea of a desperate Red Bull drinking writer. I thought most of it could have been done much better without changing it too much. And the rest would have sucked no matter what. Dracula met Van Helsing at a completely different era than the one in which Dr. Frankenstein was making his monster. And the Roman war "Gabriel" made reference to which was sited in the movie as being 73 b.c. was actually about 200 a.d. It all gave the impression that it was made too fast to be anything but what it was, a bad movie with good enough action scenes to gross billions. I just hope that money helps the makers sleep at night, cos it wouldn't help if it were me.

title: Fun and campy
review: Certainly not an award winner. But it was great fun. Seemed to realize they shouldnt take themselves to seriously. I was campy yes but it seemes to me like that was kind of the point, made it seem more like an old monster movie. Bottom line, it was an enjoyable movie to go to with friends and still makes me giggle to think about it. David Wenham, as the comic relief friar was my favorite. (granted, anyone from LOTR is usualy the reason I go to movies anymore; dosent hurt that they are usualy in movies my taste) I was annoyed with the costuming though. Couldn't they have had something even vaguely referencing fashions of the time period. I mean I realize that they were trying to do the whole action hero thing but ususaly they atleast try and follow some part of the shilouete or something but this - nothing. Ah well I guess it added to the campiness.

title: My Humble Opinion
review:
I saw the movie and ... where to begin ...

In my honest opinion it was a TOTAL CRAP! I HAVE NEVER SEEN A BIGGER CRAP IN MY LIFE! Maybe Dogma was also crap movie, but not like this one, this goes NR.1 in my charts (by the way the Web Site is also crap, too commercial and very slow too). It was not the mixing of all those fantastic creatures that bothered me but the mistakes, insults and insinuations addressed to my mother country ROMANIA really pissed me off. Let's see ... We will take it point by point. 1. I consider it common sense (shameful) that when making a movie with a budget of billions of US dollars you do not know or don't pay somebody to look at the map to see that the capital of ROMANIA is BUCHAREST not Budapest (which is the capital of Hungary) as it was presented in the movie! For the Director and the Producer of the movie especially, I want to inform them that ROMANIA and Hungary are different (neighbor) countries. And by the way we Romanians are around for 2000 years we but we never had a gypsy as a king neither such a capital. Gypsy Kings are a latino band, my dears! If you didn't know that you should have asked, or maybe take some Romanian in the movie crew. Or next time just ask me I will offer my advice for free. 2. In the beginning of the movie it was said that the action takes place in Romania (Tansilvania is province of Romania) 'a cursed land inhabited by cursed people'. This doesn't sound very good to me. It is pretty much an insult to country itself and to the 23 million inhabitants of Romania. We may be cursed (it is normal when the medium salary is 100 US dollars/month) but the county I can assure you is one of the most beautiful and rich (in natural resources) in Europe and is not at all cursed as it was presented. And off the record the images presented there were more suited to describe Romania in the 16th century not 18th. What will people think now about us, after seeing this movie? 3. I don't know about the others but I am proud of being Romanian and I think we are a nation as normal as many on this earth, and this movie is not quite a good presentation for Romania. Anyway I just wrote that just to defend a little our image and to let people know that we have evaluated a lot since the times presented there in the movie, we even got Internet now (80% of the youth use Internet and has a computer). :p I hope that our government will sue the producers of this movie!

title: A Waste
review: This movie was filled with so much potential and hype, but laughably falls so very short. Its wasn't the story that fell so short, it was all the details of movie making. The 150-200 million dollar film wastes most of that money on cheesy and unneeded special effects. When the vampires open their mouths they look more like cartoon opposums, and Dracula himself looks like an evil 1980s (U2's) Bono, complete with visible hair clip (don't worry his acting is worse). Not only that, the production company couldn't fit an even halfway mediocre screenwriter into its aircraft carrier size budget as the entire script probably took up one typed page, if you think I'm joking go see the movie. Just a poor movie overall.

title: Who needs story when you've got CGI!.....Van Helsing does.
review:
Stephen Sommers delivers the same old storyless, no brainer action film that I've come to expect from him (See The Mummy, Mummy Returns).

Another CGI world with no substance or emotion that is populated by people who talk in cheesy one liners that are supposed to be funny (Bruce Campbell one liners = funny, Kate Beckensale = WHY?). I will admit that it kept me entertained enough to keep me in the cinema until the end (a feat a few of the audience at my screening didn't manage) But this is purely because i like monster movies and I was sure they'd be a big wrestling battle at the end (And I Can be quite stubborn when I've paid Â£10).

On a plus point the CGI, although overused was of a high standard. And the action, although meaningless was slightly entertaining. Unfortunatley all this means nothing when you don't give a damn about the characters.

A note to Mr Stephen Sommers. Next time you get $170million dollars to spend on a movie use some of that money to develop a story, & if you've got time maybe even write a script! Youll find all the cool CGI you like is even more effective when it has a reason to be in a film.

I have to congratulate the people behind the marketing of this film as they've done an incredible job selling it to the public.

I was fooled into parting with my money!

3/10

title: Boots and bosoms - no brainer visual treat
review: I thought it was highly entertaining for the genre of film this represents. You really should know what to expect from this type of film and it was a awful lot better than the tedious Mummy movies. It was very pleasant to look at - especially the gothic clothing, heaving bosoms and bodices and long boots. The Budapest Ball sequence is also very dynamic and superbly colourful which is a credit to the director. It's fair to say their is no let up in the action, it's quite impressive really. No story as such to talk of - but you have to disengage your brain enter the spirit of it. I thought it was better than I expected - a no-brainer visual treat.

title: What a great film
review: I must admit I didn't know what or who Van Helsinger was about before I went to see the film. A moden twist to 3 horror villains and one of them ends up being a good guy - for a change! Extreme special effects were an added bonus to an in-depth tale and at times quite funny. Hugh Jackman was an excellent "slayer" with fantastic 007 style weapons. Makes you wonder if Van Helsinger also drank a dry martini - SHAKEN not stirred!!! It's been such a long time since I actually jumped in my seat at the cinema and there were a few occasions. There could be a possibility for a sequel!? Everyone has their own opinion but for me this was an excellent film definitely along the same lines as Bram Stokers Dracula/Raiders of the Lost Ark.

title: The summer movie onslaught has begun.
review:
"Van Helsing" tells the story of the titular character (Hugh Jackman), who serves the Vatican as a sort of black ops agent whose missions are to eradicate various unrepentant monsters. His primary task here is to destroy the horrific triumvirate of Count Dracula (Richard Roxburgh), Wolfman, and Frankenstein's monster. With his own medieval Agent Q (LOTR's David Wenham), our hero ventures to Transylvania to team up with the stunning Anna Valerious (Kate Beckinsale), the last survivor in a noble family that must kill Dracula or be condemned forever to purgatory.

Although I think the makers of "Van Helsing" tried to inject a dose of heart their work, they still produced little more than a good summer popcorn movie, and I don't mean that as an insult. Director Stephen Sommers also helmed "The Mummy" and its sequels, and while I would rate Van Helsing ahead of those movies, it is cast from the same mold. If you go in with expectations of greatness, you'll no doubt hate it and be utterly disappointed. But if you settle in looking for nothing more than 2+ hours of fun, nearly campy entertainment, you'll be thoroughly satisfied.

A large reason that it falls short of being even a good movie is the derivative nature of the entire flick. Although set in a dark neo-Victorian age (in which it always seems to be raining), "Van Helsing" contains countless scenes that bring to mind various classics. Whether it be Van Helsing's Batman-esque tools, his gadget room borrowed from James Bond, shots taken from Looney Tunes, or a scene straight out of "Get Smart" (yes, that's right), so much of the movie has been done before. More than any other, Van Helsing imitates The Indiana Jones Trilogy in ways ranging from the hero's attire to how certain characters die to the use of a map to display travel. Even Alan Silvestri's music recalls one of Indy's secondary themes. While this derivative nature prevents "Van Helsing" from being a truly good film, it does provide a alternative unique form of entertainment. Half the fun of the movie is pinpointing the pervasive cinematic references.

The other half of the fun comes from the overall appearance and content. While these well-known characters have been portrayed on the screen hundreds of times through the years, rarely are they seen so vividly in an action movie such as this. Jackman possesses a perfect look for the swashbuckling protagonist; Roxburgh not only twirls his mustache well, but does add some humanity to the blood-sucking count. Beckinsale, in a role not all that different from her turn in Underworld, isn't asked to do much but look vengeful and beautiful, and does just that, managing to fight ferociously in tight clothes while still maintaining her gorgeous and pristine appearance. Wenham, in stark contrast to his noble Faramir, fills the thankless comic relief role, and does so rather well, considering what he is given to work with.

The rest of the cast consists primarily of minor roles or special effects. Unfortunately while the physical appearance of the movie is excellent, the visual effects aren't always up to par. They're not bad, but also aren't quite seamless with the rest of the flick. Every once in a while something doesn't quite match or feels just a little too fake. With so many effects done by many different effects houses, perhaps this was inevitable, but the minor discrepancies are still occasionally distracting, which is the one thing that visual effects should not be.

The effects are not helped by the fact that the movie, at nearly two and a half hours, is twenty minutes too long. As enjoyable as the various people and fights are, one can only take so much of horror characters scurrying around doing battle. Trimming a few minutes out of about every scene would have made the remaining excitement that much more enjoyable, resulting in a more streamlined and bearable picture. As it is, everything drags on too long, permitting what could have been a taut adventure film to unravel into a messier and less cohesive movie.

As the movie that kick-starts the summer season, "Van Helsing" receives some leeway. Had it been released in August, it probably wouldn't have been nearly as enjoyable, following a summer of similarly action-packed but largely forgettable fare. But with cinematic tastebuds longing for fresh popcorn after a stale spring, Van Helsing survives its shortcomings to provide a satisfying if short-lived treat.

Bottom Line: Decent summertainment, at least as the first biggie of the season. 6/10, for fun as much as quality.

title: Well, i was warned and didn't listen...
review:
so i became a Van Helsing viewer. And again, like so often the last years i was assured that hollywood (and many other film factories) loves computer animated special effects, a story that can be written on one piece of paper by some guy who has writing skills like a talented child aged 5 or 6, and they still are not able to generate realistic fights with all theses bodies flying around like flipper bowls. After 2.5 hours of cinematrical climaxes hunting each other i noticed the end of this film when the lights in the room switched on and the ridiculous sounds and flashes diappered.

And after having 2 aspirines i swore to read the internet more carefully about movies i am about to join than i did it this time.

title: Van Helsing meets lots of other movies
review:
Don't read if you want to keep all the surprises. *little spoiler alert*

Great movie if you like the scared by surprise effect. In Van Helsing we see the Mr. G van Helsing as a lean mean vampire ass-kicking fighting machine. There are a lot of questions in my head after seeing this movie like:

-Where have I heard before something like the bad guy's father is the good guy? (I thought it was the other way around somewhere in a galaxy far far away...)

-Same moviesixtology; since when do we always burn the bodies of dead people? (Qui-Gon Jinn it was if I remember correctly. A pity ending for Ms Beckinsale.)

  • Wasn't there another movie in which the good guy had the ring of the bad guy, while the bad guys ring finger was chopped off? (In both the bad guy won't get it back by the way...)


And so on, and so on.

You should really go for the effects, it is quite a shooting, hooters helicopters-film, only no helicopters... guess they weren't invented yet then.But in stead you get loads of other flying thingies.

title: a concise psychological review
review:
Van Helsing is all about eye-candy, graphic visuals that rehash various moments in horror movie history, a crude montage of abstract and unrealized design that attempts to say something, anything really as long as it will sell tickets, but just ends up babbling incoherently, baiting us with vague and dramatic visual overtures that ultimately fail to connect with their integral emotional baggage.

if you like flat soda, then you might like Van Helsing, it's sticky, sweet and full of artificial colors, but there's no fizz.

p.s. after watching this movie i couldn't help but imagine kids 50 years from now commenting on the corny computer generated special effects displayed in this genere of uninspired revisitationism; in much the same way that most people today might make similar comments regarding the black and white classics that were at least for their time period creative and trans-original.

title: Big and dumb- and I loved it.
review:
I'd read quite a few reviews on different sites where people were complaining about the lack of substance and how the movie didn't take itself seriously and so on and so on. And, well. I really don't know what in the world those people were expecting from a movie with vampires, werewolves, *and* Frankenstein's monster directed by the guy who made The Mummy. Van Helsing was everything I expected it to be: big stupid monster fun. For crying out loud, it had villagers with pitchforks and torches in the beginning! How can anyone expect a film that starts off that way to be high art?

Speaking of the beginning, I was absolutely delighted with it. Some people might call it a rip-off but I thought it was a brilliant homage to Frankenstein (it's been a while since I've seen it, but I'm pretty sure up until Dracula pops up, it was shot-for-shot the same).

Also, Dracula! Quite a few people have expressed the opinion that Richard Roxburgh wasn't portraying him seriously enough, but, again, why would he? As soon as he began to speak, I was all, 'ha! Bela Lugosi!' and, oh, I loved the way he camped the entire thing up. Along the same lines, I also loved his brides. The scene of them all overemoting and wailing after the vamplings all exploded? So cheesy! It was fantastic.

Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale were okay, although I spent most of the movie wondering when Kate was going to say, 'Ve must get moose and squirrel!'

The best part of the movie, though, and the main reason I wanted to see it, was David Wenham. Absolutely darling and funny! And it was kind of weird because I've only ever seen him as Faramir, aka The Saddest Man in All of Gondor, but I loved it. Maybe I'm just easily amused, but I had a giggle-fit almost every time he appeared on-screen. I don't understand why Carl had to be so short, though. Well, okay, maybe I do a little, to make Van Helsing all the more larger-than-life and all that crap, but, still. My back hurt watching him slump around. awww, poor Daisy.

I do have to agree with everyone who said the CGI sucked. The brides weren't too bad but, god. Jekyll? bleh. Didn't like that at all. And the werewolves all looked...well. Fake. Come on, folks. If you're going to CG, at least make an effort.

So, yeah. overall, I loved it. I went in expecting non-stop action and lots of pretty, and that's pretty much what I got, plus some laughs (some maybe unintentional, like 'The roof, the roof, the roof is on fi-yah').

And I am all about a sequel. More Daisy! YAY!!!

title: Alan Moore's ideas, none of his talent
review:
I actually liked Van Helsing. It's a wild rollercoaster ride. And as an attempt to make something more akin to League of Extraordinary Gentlemen than Stephen Norrington's abysmally bad movie version of Alan Moore's work of genius, it worked.

Unfortunately, it didn't have Alan Moore, who could have made the dialogue work too and the character motivations more interesting. But who cares - the action was what it was about, there was plenty of it, and I for one at times even sat in the cinema wishing for a RWD button to take another look at what actually happened here or there.

A final aside: Now that Alan Moore has opened the can of worms that is public domain reworking of classic characters, we will see plenty of bad instances of it in the future. It's the way of the world (or Hollywood at least), and Alan Moore will regrettably never see one cent of the bazillions of dollars generated from his idea. Well, Alan Moore will most likely do very nicely on his own anyway, what with America's Best Comics and all.

How many times was that? Four? Not nearly enough, so here comes another three: Alan Moore, Alan Moore, Alan Moore. The greatest writer in existence.

title: disappointing
review: I looked forward to seeing this film for months.  The film editors that handled the trailers should get an Oscar! Hugh Jackman is appealing- as usual.  But he alone, cannot carry this film. Some of the dialogue was meant to be funny- but we laughed at parts that were meant to be serious. The picture of Frankenstein's monster escaping on a home-made raft was just too ridiculous. And Kate Beckensale's Transylvanian accent was horribly laughable. Has anyone else noticed that her hair was never out of place?  Even after she was hanging upside down.  We actually laughed and applauded when her character died. I think that this film was meant to be a merchandising tool-video games, toys, etc.  Even so, I think that the film could have been much better.

title: What is everyone's problem?
review: I went and saw Van Helsing recently and thoroughly enjoyed it.  So, I was surprised when the reviews I read completely panned it.  It seems as if the critics were expecting some deeply intellectual and thought -provoking masterpiece when it never tries or claims to be.  It is simply a fun, entertaining action/adventure remake of the old classic horror films of the 50's and I think that in that capacity it succeeds very well.  The critics also complained of what they called a "pixel overload" but, I thought the special effects were extremely well done and anything less might have made it as cheesy as the old horror films that it is paying tribute too.  True, the acting isn't oscar-worthy, but I don't think that was the goal of the film.  And, even if the acting wasn't superb, I still enjoyed all the portrayals of the characters immensely, even Roxburgh's (Dracula) cheesy transylvanian accent, but honestly who can do a transylvanian accent that doesn't sound cheesy?  All in all, if you want to go see an entertaining fantasy adventure; go see Van Helsing, you will be entertained.  But, if you want to go see something more "inspiring"; go rent American Beauty and stop complaining.

title: A film about cliches (so don't expect much else)
review:
This movie is only slightly better than that unwatchable mess, The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen. They're both quite comparable with each other.

While Van Helsing is visually impressive, and mostly fun, it's too stupid to recommend to anyone.

--If vampires could have babies like the rest of us, why would they all explode when their father dies? (an obvious plot cop-out)

--Who is Gabriel Van Helsing? What is the history behind him? They tried to tell us but then forgot about it.

--If Frankenstein's monster is such a badass, why is he always getting trapped or running away? I wanted to see him smash Dracula into little bloody meatballs.

The best feature of the film, and there's plenty of it, is Kate Beckinsdale's curves. She makes one of the best entrances I've ever seen, and eventually the pandering, topless-looking blouse she runs around in seems less crude and more like the cherries that top this banquet of fattening dessert.

Directed by Steven Sommers, Van Helsing also recalls his blockbuster Mummy movies (The Mummy, The Mummy Returns). Both of those films were great --and here's the proof. All of these features are about style over substance; about being fun rather than thought-provoking. But where Van Helsing is willing to lessen the depth of its script to the point where its entertainment value is barely skin deep --just so it can accommodate for more villains, The Mummy films were centered around only one villain, forcing them to write a script with deeper characters and better lines.

title: Not a bad movie, but a poor movie.
review:
After Stephen Sommers' "Mummy" movies (including "The Scorpion King", I had high hopes for this movie. Unfortunately, it didn't live up to them. For one thing, Sommers put too much into this one - Dr. Jekyll/Mr. Hyde, Frankenstein's Monster, Werewolves and Dracula - so the plot was convoluted and wandered all over the place. The "solution" to the problem defied the strongest sense of disbelief, and a lot of the rest of the plot was too bizarre as well. I'm being deliberately vague on this since I don't want to spoil it for anyone who hasn't seen it. I was also angered to see Kate Beckinsale's character, who is supposed to be a pretty mighty monster hunter in her own right, get pushed into a distant second role even after we see the kinds of things she can do - it reminded me a lot of what was done with Maid Marion's character in the Kevin Costner "Robin Hood - Prince of Thieves" movie where Marion very nearly kills Robin the first time they meet in the movie, but is completely incapable of taking the smallest part in her own rescue at the end (I distinctly remember someone in the audience screaming, "What the h--l is this? Two hours ago she was a f-----g ninja!"). It's too bad that Sommers forsook the ensemble cast approach that worked so well in all of the "Mummy" movies.

On the other hand, the movie sported the number of great performances you would expect considering the actors. Those of us who are only familiar with David Wenham from his portrayal of Faramir in "The Lord Of The Rings" get to see a wonderful comic side to his abilities. Richard Roxburgh again shows his ability as a villain; my only regret here is that that's the only thing we usually get to see him doing in the States. Another regret is that Robbie Coltrane and Samuel West, playing Mr. Hyde and Dr. Frankenstein respectively, get so little screen time. Kate Beckinsale again demonstrates a flair for heroic action and turns in an excellent performance, but gets pushed to the sidelines by Hugh Jackman. Jackman's performance was passable, but in spite of getting the title role, he got little material with which to work; I think Sommers must have told him to go out there and pretend to be the monster-hunting version of Clint Eastwood's Man With No Name (albeit a version who, despite being an immortal, monster-hunter, the supposed "Left Hand of God," cannot hit the broad side of the barn with anything but a shotgun, and then only if it doesn't really matter. Go figure), and that was pretty much it.

However, since I paid matinee price for it, it was at least a diverting afternoon, if not a really entertaining one. If I had paid full price, I would have felt utterly cheated.

If you like science fiction with a mixture of love story and some comical details, this is your film. The argument is quite simple, but there are some little details that make the film more interesting, such as the death of one of its main characters or the litters of bloodthirsty 'mini-Draculas'. The best of the film: Elena Anaya´s performance as one of Dracula´s girlfriends; the worst: a slightly different Dracula (nothing to do with Bram Stocker´s version) and too much makeup on Kate Beckinsale´s face. Hugh Jackman does it best in his role of a bad and affectionate guy, as he has already proved in other films such as X-Men. The question is: Would he be so good in performing other kind of characters? I thought it was going to be a quite more terrifying film, but otherwise it is an option to spend your time, if there is nothing better showing!

title: Don't do this to yourself
review:
Ah, the worst film I've seen in about 10 years.

What do you eat on Thanksgiving?

What do you call it when someone scores three consecutive strikes in bowling?

What country has Istanbul as its capital?

That's right....

Yes, it's that bad. I don't generally find any film so bad I would dismiss it as utter rubbish. But this one...........was utter rubbish. I wanted to leave pretty early on but decided to give it a chance. My mistake. Riding on the crest of its own wave of undeserved hype, Van Helsing blew into town with a big reputation, but rarely before has a would-be blockbuster promised so much and delivered.....well, little more than self loathing, self-pity and thoughts of "I could have spent this money on a hooker."

It was badly written.

Badly scripted.

Badly acted.

Badly cast (Come on, Dracula should be a gentleman, perfectly groomed with impeccable manners - balanced of course with an unnerving charm and devastating attack - but sadly we got nothing of the sort)

Badly edited (Never before have I thought, or even noticed, that a film was poorly edited)

Badly scored.

Van Helsing was very unlike Van Helsing - for a start, the guy did not have amnesia. The gadgetry was a trifle ridiculous, although in fairness one must remember to suspend reality to a fair old extent for such a film - but still, it seemed out of place - although I found myself wishing I had possession of that crossbow gun, and an appointment with director Stephen Sommers.

Kate Beckinsale, always easy on the eye, was unusually wooden in her portrayal of Anna, and Jackman lacked everything he brought to the screen in terms of coolness as Wolverine in the X-Men films.

Heed not the foolish mortals who boast of the film's awesome CGI effects - they were out of place and only served to further cement the poor visuals of the movie.

In Van Helsing, there is potential for an absolute cracker of a movie. They could have made it dark, almost sexy even, and given it a great soundtrack. Instead they made it corny and totally cliched, and the supposed comic relief of Igor made little impact. And the soundtrack? Just plain wrong - it only fits the movie in terms of being inappropriate.

If you must go and see this, be prepared to gnaw off your own foot to escape.

title: Underrated!
review: Although I have heard many remarks about the lack of quality of the film I have to say that I disagree with almost all of them! I saw this movie and the 2 or so hours flew past due to the captivating action, special effects, and way that Sommers presented his monsters. The black and white prologue clearly showed Sommers's love for the old horror movies, and the story line, although not as unique as the Underworld plot, was interesting. The acting by Hugh Jackman was very good, and, although Kate Beckinsale's accent was questionable, the chemistry between the two characters was unmistakable. If you want to see a straightforward, unimaginative, realistic movie there's no point in going but that was obvious from the start since it's a movie with vampires, werewolves, frankenstein's monster, and even Dr Jekyll and  Mr Hyde. However, if you wish to see an enjoyable escapist movie I highly recommend it!

title: Lame
review:
Okay, here's the deal - I am not a big fan of action movies. But I liked The Mummy. A lot. It was very good fun. Suspension of disbelief? No problem, can do. But Van Helsing? Lame. No heart. Stupid script. Waste of acting talent. Would have been a waste of money, too, but I went to see it at a cheap matinee and I can at least say I have seen it, now. So I'm entitled to my opinion, right? Wasn't there a line in it about Frankenstein's monster being made of seven men stuck together? Well, this was at least seventy movies stuck very badly and at odd angles together. Van Helsing gets my vote for most stupid movie of 2004, so far. Been there, done that, hope I won't have to see it ever again.

One positive thing: David Wenham. I hated him in LOTR, but he seems to have found his niche here. Good on him.

As for the rest, I repeat. Lame. Lame. Lame.

title: Van OH MY GOODNESS!!!
review: Ok I have to admit I like mindless action, but to some extent shouldnt there be a plot. I honestly liked the special effects and the non stop action but Why who what where when how and why is Van Helsing. We don't even get to know the character. Neither do we get to know the female lead. I understood she was from a long line of vampire hunters if I am not mistaken. Frankenstein looked pretty good but did he have Shakespeare's. He was more dramatic than anyone in that Titanic movie. Now from what I understand wasn't the wolfman only 1 person. He was about three in this movie. And the kicker is the ending....... WHAT IN THE WORLD WAS THAT PILE OF DOO?!?!?!? At that point I wanted to get a stake to the heart. Good grief. Now honestly the movie is watchable for those who love mindless action and pure mayhem. Now keep your eye out for when the guys turn into the Werewolf. Interesting stuff.

title: Weak Action Film with Weak Monsters
review: This movie is souless.  Its not bad and its not good.  In fact, its so boring it's barely watchable.  The writing is absolutely atrocious.  It's as if they piece the script together from other films.  It absolutely brings nothing original to the screen.  You seen everything here before done much much better.  The actors seem as if they are mailing in their performances. And that crap with the Friar and tying him into Q from James Bond almost made me want to leave the theater.  I've seen Van Helsing played better by older men with less effect and no modern weapons.  Obvious the blame is squarely on Sommers.  All he did was took his shell from The Mummy and inserted different characters.  He had no idea what to do with his leading lady and his leading man, as the same with the Mummy, is just trying to be a weaker version of Indiana Jones.  You will recognize all sorts of films in this movie: Mask of Zorro, The Mummy, Underworld (with all the blue in the movie), James Bond, Indiana Jones.  It's just a formula film whose formula needs to be retired.  There is absolutely no passion in this film.  No risk taking, nothing that WOWS you.  You would only see this movie once you exhaust all other ideals on what to do with your evening.  And guess what, you can tell it's lifeless from the previews.  And the funny part of it all, is that you pull for this film to be better while you are watching it. You want them to go that extra steps, but apparently the director just doesn't have the confidence to do so and in the end the audience gets cheated.

title: many flaws, but ultimately fun
review:
I took my kids (17 & 13) to see this on Friday. While we all had fun, on the ride back, pointing out parts of the movie that were not done well, in the end we all enjoyed it.

Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsdale were solid, if unspectacular, in the leads. The Friar was very good as comedy relief, Dracula's brides were alternately luscious and vicious, Frankenstein's monster was very well done, even with the steampunk edge to him. This was more the monster from the book than from the old Universal films, but, for me, it worked.

Dracula was a bit insipid and the CGI'd Mr. Hyde was almost cartoonish. As another reviewer pointed out, there were no scary moments, but this was, to me, much more of a CGI action picture, with a horror motif, than a horror movie. (Might as well complain about the lack of science in Star Wars, but then I have done that myself.)

In the end, we had a good time, the movie wasn't great, but it was a fun kickoff to the summer.

title: The last of the trilogy... I hope.
review:
No spoiler herein...

Again, Hollywood has released yet another boredom vehicle. Hopefully, many residents of the IMDB community will realize the fact that three exactly the same films were released during the past year.

These three films were League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, Hellboy and Van Helsing. All three sucked.

Exact same premise in all three. Exact same conclusion in all three. Several miniscule differences, but they were all pretty much the same. I want to cry.

Since I am a screenwriter, I go into films with a conscious self-perception of my emotions and the movements of the hidden script. I have realized that Hollywood's action flicks need to forget about the action and revitalize the innovation of good story.

What am I saying? I'm saying that action for the sake of action is boring. SWAT was boring. It had lots of action, but it was boring.

If any producer happens to read this ever, please, please, please envision yourself watching your own film. If you find yourself falling asleep, then think twice about spending 170 mil on another Hollywood Action boredom vehicle.

Stuff like Van Helsing doesn't keep people coming back for that crucial second and third and fourth week. It just doesn't.

title: High budget "porn"
review:
Yes, this movie reminds me of a porn flick: minimal plot which serves to string one scene into the next. In porn, it is sex scenes; here, it is action sequences.

Suspend disbelief? Sure, but what about acting? What about plot? Direction? This movie is nothing more than a justification to present high cost CGI and implausible action scenes.

On the other hand, given the success of action movies in general, and how much this movie is making at the box office already, I guess that's what people want: not to think, but to be awed by spectacle. If that is the case, then VH is on the mark. Kinda sad, really.

I am a fantasy fan, I love Anne Rice, and loved "Interview with a Vampire", both the book and the film. I was looking forward to this and was hugely disappointed. Good fantasy has depth; this movie doesn't.

Rating? Zero.

title: Boring uptight quadrospazes
review:
I'm sick and tired of people who rate a film entirely on whether or not it's a 'fantastic piece of special art'!

Van Helsing is fun. It's a laugh. Yeah it's no classic - not even within its own genre but it's thoroughly enjoyable, with decent action scenes (even though I'm sure the main actors must have got rope burns at some point), and decent special effects.

It certainly kicks the arse of the flacid recent "matrix" films (inverted commas my own)

Lighten up. I like good directing and acting as much as the next person but sometimes you want a brainless action flick. It does what it sets out to do. Nothing more. Nothing less.

Just like Dude Where's My Car. Next you're going to tell me that's not an amazing comedy!

title: One To Remember
review:
I had high expectations for this film, or at least I did until I read all the bad reviews. Yet I did go see the film today, and it definitely is a film that lingers in one's mind-or in my mind at least.

The film has some great sets and the make-up seemed to be pretty good (although probably not as masterful as Jack Pierce's classic creations). The plot isn't the best, but it's not too bad either. The acting was done fairly well, and Roxburgh makes a good impression as a semi-original Dracula. Shuler Hensley does the Frankenstein Monster justice, but does seem to be a bit under-used. The werewolves are ferocious, and the transformation sequences seem to be the best in horror films thus far.

There are inconsistencies, or things that do not make sense in the film. Or at least they are not given any rational explanation.

Now the nitpicky stuff. Kevin J. O' Connor was great as "Igor" who seemed very reminiscent of Bela Lugosi's "Ygor" (From "Son Of Frankenstein" and "Ghost Of Frankenstein"). Once more this film rewrites the end to "Frankenstein" just like "Bride Of Frankenstein" had rewritten it to better suit its story. On even more technical grounds, they even mess up the real life Dracula's years of birth and supposed death (in the film it is 1422-1462, in history it was 1431-1476). They also minorly changed the words to Curt Siodmak's classic Wolf Man poem, but is slightly noticeable unless you've practically memorized it.

All in all, it is a good multi-monster film, even if some characters are under-used.
