If you can look past some funny cliche-ish lines, constant stunt scenes, and some nitpicky details-it should be a fun film to watch and one that may captivate your imagination just like the original Universal films have captivated the imaginations of generations since 1931 (since 1925 for the famous "Opera Ghost" and 1923 I believe for the original French hunchback, but 1931 was the year that Lugosi and Karloff, Bela and Boris, gave us the cinematic gems that persevere in our hearts and minds...and in our fears and imagination).

Sincerely, Exchronos

title: Three Thumbs Up
review:
It was etertaining. It had old movie monsters re-spun in new and delightful ways, making them more entertaining that movies of yore. The story line was interesting, and kept me thinking up until the end. The ending itself was a surprise.

Then again, if you want something more along the lines of "The Hours" or "Girl With A Pearl Earring", I don't suggest this movie for you. If you liked Indiana Jones, you will more than likely love "Van Helsing".

I give this movie three thumbs way way up, because of the entertainment value. It's going to keep people coming back for more over and over again.

title: decent but nuthin spectacular
review: i have just seen the movie today 5/11/04 and I have a fair amount to say about it. 1) The action was good and kept my attention but everything you see in VH you can see in "Blade" and "Underworld". 2) The acting wasn't that great but how many action movies can you name where there was very convincing action? 3) After all the hype and what everyone said about this movie I should say that I expected just a bit more but it wasn't horrible for a PG13 action movie. All in all this movie was okay and definetly worth seeing but don't expect much groundbreaking special fx or original character design other then the werewolf(definetly better looking then in "Underworld" I might add). But for me and I'm sure the rest of the male fans are concerned the best part about this movie is the fact that Kate Beckinsale wears a very sexy outfit(but then again give her a trash bag to wear and she'd make it sexy) and kicks some major ass. She was my favorite chracter next to VH's sidekick who is, of course, the comic relief. But check it out, it's alot of fun to watch and good for a rainy day....

title: "Orlando Bloom, you should not be aloud to act. Legally." Why cant gut-pain hilarious stuff like that make it onto a poster?
review:
You know, from the point of view of 2003, 2004 looked like a historical year didn't it? I mean we had Brad Pitt in the Trojan War, we had the Mummy Man pitching the genius concept of a Hammer "Versus" revival, we had Ridley Scott going all epic on us again(!!!), we had a Gary Oldman Harry Potter movie and we had the curious idea of a Shrek sequel (so absurdly inappropriate we could only assume they had an ace up there sleeve) but this is ofcourse excepting the showstopper and king, Spider-man making a victory lap. What happened?

Lets hope Ridley gets the first good performance out of Orlando and lets hope Harry Potter and Spider-man 2 are as kick-ass as the trailers make out cause early word on Troy is potent, the Shrek sequel sounds like a phony they dont wanna release at all, the Spider-man 2 trailer gives me no reason not to be excited yet they've withdrawn it from competition, and Van Helsing sucks.

Tell me honestly that you weren't drooling when he pitched the idea? Come on, Dracula, Frankenstein and Wolf Man versus a gizmo-ed cross-wielding revision of the first (and coolest sounding) Vampire Hunter? And writer-director Sommers sounded like the man for the job didn't he? In our post-Mummy glow we assumed he knew what to do with it. Alas however it's an affront to logic but Sommers took exactly the same approach with Van Helsing as he did with Mummy 2. But Mummy 2 was pretty good wasn't it, so whats wrong this time? Dear me, where to start?

Firstly, check the cast list Sommers, Brendan Fraser isn't in this one. Without his irresistable goofy wit the one-liners are going to flatten right out. Without his reliable gung-ho approach to everything complimenting that wit, love for the hero is also sliced in half. Without 'it-man' Oded Fehr to back him up there's no co-adventurer we'll swear alliegence to. Without the adorable and hot-as-hell Rachel Wiesz there's no heroin we empathise with and feel aloud to love from afar. And we can't forget Johnathan and Beni, without them what do we have to chuckle at? Who does the hero look all the better beside? What did Van Helsing need?

Well the second I saw that early concept art of Dracula, Frankenstein and Wolf Man I thought Sommers DID know what to do. He was goth-ing it up, I was prepared to sacrifice the humour because I knew it just couldn't sit. I thought Van Helsing would be a convergence of Myths(capital 'M' intended). You can't nintendo it all up and make these beasties as commonplace as vermin. They should have delved into the Myst-rigue inherent and used the sheer value of these legendary characters to come up with a story that we wanted to watch. They could have chopped that $180mil in half, and put a few hundred grand into a powerplay that actually interested us on a cerebral level. So lastly, what does the movie have?

I cant believe he actually dared to use the same junk that not only every other adventure movie used but that his own leading man lived off. Come on, forgotten pasts, dark secrets, soulful quests thats not only Wolverine its the Mummy movies and its wanderer mentality which comes into nearly everything. We've had way too much of that already, he should have given it a miss. Sexy as Beckinsale is she cant be both the quest and the love interest and fellow-adventurer and the victim etc, thats just absurdly uninteresting. And Dracula, oh boy. As big a fan as I am of Ozzie actors penetrating Hollywood I'm afraid my countryman was miscast. Dracula HAS to be very tall and very menacing. We should feel as we did in 1898 when John Harker first encoundered this fogotten King who transcended centuries and fought historical battles (Vlad the Impaler). We should feel like a child that needs permission to leave their bedroom before him. Oldman was a stupid choice in 1990 for the "faithful" adaptation and so was Roxburgh. Short of suggesting who he should have cast I'll leave it at that.

And he cribbed from Godzilla!! I mean for goodness sake, there are some movies that should be completely off-limits for theft, out of pure common decency and what of all the $180mil flops of last 10 decades would top the list? Sommers tried to elevate the events of the movie to transcend Transylvania. He should have instead dwelled on the character that the entire "franchise" depended on.

Listen this could go on for pages but it doesn't need to. Here's hoping that the movie makes enough to warrant a sequel in which they might (but likely cant) improve things. Otherwise, and likely, Jackman is still looking for that much touted Indiana Jones to succeed his Han Solo (Wolverine), but my greatest fear is that this will be the finishing attempt at resurecting the Vampire King. Please, please no.

title: It's wham, it's bam and it's nothing else. Senseless CGI! A two and half hour computer game.
review:
I liked the Mummy. I even liked the Mummy Returns so when I heard Sommers was doing Van Helsing I thought great.

I went to see it. Oh My God!

The opening scenes - was Sommers watching The Extordinary League of Gentlemen? Seemed to me he just cut and paste.

Hugh Jackman was OK for the part he was asked to play. The leading lady Kate Beckensale was as wooden as she was in Underworld and Dracula was terrible. I like that guy Roxbrough and recently saw him a BBC version of Sherlock Holmes which was brilliant. He was miscast in this part which he camped up to the heaven's I was waiting for his henchmen the Queer Eye boys to fly in.

The script was poor at the best of times and the background story between Van Helsing and Dracula though mentioned wasn't settled up. I think Dracula said something inbetween the bangs and crashes of the last scene but I missed it because I was looking at my watch wondering why I'd bothered paying.

The brides had they're moments from a male point of view but I've seen a better performaces from a rubber duck.

The film over all should have taken itself a bit more seriously. I realise it may have been played up abit but aleast give some people credit for having a brain. It will probably spawn loads of franchises.

It's wham, it's bam and it's nothing else. Senseless CGI! A two and half hour computer game.

Overall rating 4/10

*Stick to Blade for some decent action.

title: Great Movie
review: I cannot believe what I have read about the movie Van Helsing.  Obviously all of these people who think that they are an authority on movies (usually under 25 years of age with no life experience) have no idea that a movie is for enjoyment and the reason that we go to the cinema is for the experience of it.  Not to sit and pick actors ability (when they have never acted themselves).  I found Van Helsing to be highly entertaining.  The lines that David Wenham had were hilarious. To give a movie such a bad rap is such an egotistical, self-centred approach to life.  I don't think of myself as a movie critic, I am there to enjoy myself.  If people have the time to write such a report (which I stumbled across by accident) then they need to get a life and realise that most of the world does not want to listen to their opinion.  Van Helsing was a great movie and should be enjoyed by all not critised.  Hugh Jackman was fantastic!

title: Could it be the worst s/f film ever made?
review:
I didnt have much of expectation on this move, only expected it to be decent entertainment, but I was terribly wrong. I like horror movies, s/f-movies, b-movies so I think it could be great fun, but this one wasnt.

Almost everything about this movie was extremely bad: the acting, the plot, the effects, everything. This one of the very few movies I have ever seen I wanted to go up and leave. I regret I didnt do so.

The only good about this peace of crap was that I could laugh about the stupidity every know and then, but that wasnt enough. If I had been in another mood I probably would have been pissed off and wanted my money back.

A great warning for this movie! Almost anything yo do for 2,12 hours would be better than watching this movie. It couldnt be more waste of time...

title: I THOUGHT this movie looked cool
review:
I was looking forward to seeing this movie when i saw the trailer. I went to see it the other day with my mate and it was so damn corny. i mean at the end when they are at castle dracula, how in hell can you swing on a wire one handed so much? AND catch a tiny little syringe thingie. Its impossible. The corny and quite unbelievable stunts ruined this movie. The cg was bad and could have been much better. the monsters almost looked animated.

I was very disapointed in the movie. The only thing that kept me watching it was the sexy appearance of kate beckinsale. the first hour or so wasnt too bad but it went downhill from there on. I hope HellBoy isnt going to be this crap.

title: An interesting twist and an unsolved mystery make VH an 8/10
review: Okay, I've said it before and I'll say it again, I go to a movie for pure unadulterated entertainment.  If you are looking for deep feelings or in depth character development, go see mystic river or something.  If you want a rock'em sock'em pull no punches action movie, go see Van Helsing.  I laughed, and I found myself intently watching, trying to predict the next move.  I left feeling I had gotten a good bargain for my matinee ticket... I would have paid full price, if necessary.  Remember, guy movies are action driven, and this is definately a guy movie.  So grab a tub of popcorn, but don't drink too much soda (like I did) and enjoy an inventive look at a vampire movie.

title: Jolly Good Fun
review:
What a gloriously outrageous film. The kind of movie that has you smiling from beginning to end.

I don't often laugh out loud at the movies but the opening conflict with Mr Hyde was hilarious. To come up with the idea of linking Mr Hyde with Shrek using Robbie Coltrane's wonderful Scottish growl is pure inventive genius.

Only The Simpsons challenge it for old movie references and surely a lot of the fun is spotting them all. I would even swear I have heard the GVH heavenly chorus before. Can't put a name to it but it was from some old biblical epic or other.

Hugh Jackman strutted his stuff as a Sergio Leonesque mystery man very well but I thought Richard Roxburgh was rather hammy, trying but never quite achieving the Gary Oldman menace. I thought Igor could have done with a few more dollars spending on his make up too.

A spectacularly over the top movie.

title: Shallow and Failed Experiment
review: The movie Van Helsing starring Hugh Jackman, who has had a pretty good career so far by doing such films as X-Men, X2 and even Kate & Leopold, fails miserably to impress even a monster loving enthusiast like myself. The story gives no respect to the actual historical events and connects three different stories of Wolfman, Frankenstein's monster and Dracula into a mixture that no one should have to swallow, if they haven't already. I'm starting to feel nausious. There is much to say about the movie from fail-to-impress script to the misfortunate directing job done by Stephen Sommers etc etc.... I personally could not believe how many times I wanted to get out of my seat and leave thinking that someone out there has approved such an atrocity to be released as a motion picture. Life is unfair and so are the previews that made this movie seem decent enough for an evening out. Au contraire mon frére! I will go now and forget all about this sad, sad night. Thanks for ruining not one, but three different fairytales. Anyone sees Stephen out, do let him know! Two thumbs waaaaaaaaaaay down for Van Helsing. Hugh, what were you thinking?

title: AWESOME!!!!!!!!
review: WOW this is one heck of a movie! absolutely worth your money to watch and i know i will see it again.  Hugh jackman and kate were the perfect on screen action partners!  9 out of 10 stars!!  the effects are really what make the movie but the plot is pretty interesting too. There were a couple of moments when i was surprised and almost fell out of my seat!  My favorite character was the "friar" lol he was funny!  my favorite monster in the show was the werewolf but it was almost a tie between the werewolf and count dracula. n e ways it was AWESOME!!!!!!!  if there is a movie out there like it i want to know so i can watch it.  But like i said worth your money and it rocks 10 stars!

title: One monster turkey.
review:
Van Helsing will strike fear into any sane movie-goer's heart. The movie is one incredible failure that should never have seen the inside of a cinema.

The premise is cheesey, but at least has potential for some light entertainment. The concept of bringing together a collection of famous, nay infamous, horror creatures for a piece of cheesey villainy could have been carried off so much better.

However the complete lack of story-telling skill, the overwhelmingly tedious computer generated effects, and the absence of any sense of threat from Dracula himself render the movie simply a waste of time.

Events happen that have no bearing on the remainder of the film, and action sequences are dragged out for what seems like hours. Plot threads are created, and then abandoned and ignored when they no longer suit the director's requirements. The entire end sequence is one example - a clearly expressed deadline is simply forgotten with no ill effects.

The only redeeming features of Van Helsing are the black and white intro sequence - cheesey and corny, but at least entertainingly so - and the sight of Kate Beckinsale in a fabulously sexy outfit.

For all the monsters Van Helsing has slain, the one he missed most was the one that should have died at birth. This enormous monstrous turkey of a movie.

title: Overdone
review: You're going to read a lot of reviews saying how bad this movie is...You're going to read A LOT OF THEM, because it's TRUE. This movie just does not know when enough is enough. Overkill. Overdone. Too much of a bad thing. All style, and zero substance. Are all phrases I would use to describe this way too expensive movie, that had some promise. I will give the director this: the visuals in this movie are amazing. I will admit that the music was solid. But when action scenes, become layered on top of action scenes, which become layered on top of two or three more actions scenes, all at the same time, there is too much going on (Learn from Spielberg in Indiana Jones and learn that much of a good thing is good, but also learn from Godzilla that too much of a bad thing is bad!). Not enough in this movie to make me want to care. If you are going to focus on several characters, make me care. Yes the person I was with jumped a few times, and at times there were very creative thoughts mixed in with a whole lot of crap. The whole baby spawn of dracula was such a bad idea. Van Helsing is a regal character deserving of a regal movie. This is just the REGAL BEAGLE with special effects and Larry is still a poor man's Jack Tripper...;)

title: Many-Monstered Movie Misses Mark
review:
An homage to the classic Universal monsters of the 1930s and 40s, the opening ten minutes of Van Helsing - filmed in glorious black and white, and full of torch-toting villagers - are oddly reminiscent of Mel Brooks' Young Frankenstein. Both films play into a set of pop-culture expectations that we have of our beloved movie monsters; both recall a time in Hollywood where any combination of them - Dracula, Frankstein's monster, and/or the Wolf Man - was a sure way to put keisters in the seats. And where Brooks turned so adeptly to comedy with his homage, writer-director Stephen Sommers (The Mummy) here resurrects his particular forte: action and adventure. Indeed, once Van Helsing switches over to color, this special-effects laden juggernaut never lets up. And its many-monstered minutes - over 200 of them (minutes, that is [though there are seemingly just as many monsters]) - are a spectacle to behold.

Still, spectacle wears thin with a plot this threadbare. Seems Dracula is looking to use the Frankenstein monster to give life to an army of the undead, and (partial spolier) only the secret of the curse of the werewolf can stop him. Is it fun? Sure. In the title role, an athletic Hugh Jackman (X-Men) seems to be having a blast, and his equally agile co-star, Kate Beckinsale, appears much more comfortable fighting vampires than being one (as she did in the somewhat over serious and less entertaining Underworld). Perhaps what's missing here is something Lugosi, Karloff, and even Lon Chaney Jr. brought to the screen over half a century ago that the age of CGI often overshadows: that atmosphere and exposition are still important, especially when dealing with cinematic icons.

title: "A Unique & Fun ride full of Adventure!- 'V. Helsing' Rules!"
review:
Around 15 minutes before this started I witnessed a disturbing fight 'with words' between Mother & Daughter. In the end, it put me in an awkward position and left me shaken! The result was me seeing the film alone! During the previews I felt sick and out of place. Then "Van Helsing" started!

It's a beautifully made film. The score is excellent! This film has everything! Continuous Adventure, Eye-popping Action, Great Characters, and Exquisite Special & Visual Effects. Kate Beckinsale was deliciously wonderful, as always! While Jackman gave a risky action-filled performance.

The plot wasn't Oscar-worthy, however, was interesting! 'Helsing' has been criticized dearly by critics and Imdb Users alike for the fact that there's no plot, average acting, and cheesy monsters. I beg to differ.- Movies containing deep, well-written scripts, mesmerizing performances, and, in this case, extensive care in the visual aspect of creatures, and enabling the film to go overboard are excellent critically acclaimed films, which I enjoy most often. However, not every single film made has to fall under those expectations. We desperately need films where their main goal is to take you on a fun ride! I know I had a good ol' time while it made my troubles, before the movie, disappear! Simple as that!

My take on it: 8.5/10

title: This did not suck enough and yet to much!
review:
What ever happen to Vampires that suck blood? This demo reel, can't call it a movie, lacks... EVERYTHING! I like my Vampire flick's to be about blood lust, creepiness and sucking. Didn't Abbot and Costello do this back in 1948?

Special effects should enhance a movie not drive it. Some of the effects were not that good anyway.

Did you notice the glaring images stolen from "Beauty and the Beast"? Maybe what this movie need a few show tunes?

This "Demo Reel" contains a five-finger gagger of an ending like I haven't seen since "Somewhere in Time". What a sicken-sweet ending, oh go puke on a poop stick Van Helsing!

Hugh Jackman should be ashamed!

title: A Spit in the Face to all Classic Monster Fans
review:
There are three things I liked about VAN HELSING: the first ten minutes, Kate Beckinsale's ass, and... actually, those two are it, unless you count each butt cheek separately.

What is with Hollywood? Why are they incapable of making action or horror movies of anything remotely resembling quality? Why do they feel that a couple of "popular-this-month" stars and overuse of lousy CGI effects make a movie? The fact that this movie is doing as well as it is just tells me that general American audiences are morons.

The director of this abominable piece of crap deserves to be drawn and quartered. I have never seen a movie that set up so many potentially great scenes, then proceeded to do nothing with them. You've got a movie featuring Dracula, The Wolf Man and the Frankenstein monster, and the monsters never fight? Frankenstein's monster gets to beat up a female vampire in an all-too brief scene, Dracula and Van Helsing-turned-werewolf also duke it out in a mind-numbingly dull CGI-laden battle that looks like a video game. And why does Dracula have to turn into a giant bat monster to fight a werewolf. Wouldn't it have been more interesting to juxtapose Dracula in his human form duking it out with a hulking werewolf? Sure it would, which, I guess, is why they didn't do it. They're not interested in pleasing monster movie fans. They're interested in holding the attention of video game-jaded pre-teenagers. ABBOTT AND COSTELLO MEET FRANKENSTEIN had more effective action in it.

The beginning of the movie is great. Shot in beautiful black and white (which contemporary audiences are far too stupid to appreciate), it plays like a loving tribute to the classic Universal monster movies. However, it comes off like a mean joke to everyone who actually believed the filmmakers who swore this movie was in the spirit of the Universal and Hammer monster movies, when it suddenly turns into your typical post-MATRIX pseudo-goth action flick.

Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale are both incredibly dull. Other than Beckinsale's aforementioned buns, which look great in her tight pants (which I'm sure were all the rage in early 1800s Europe), she is as boring a character as I can recall having seen in a movie. The screenplay is so awful, though, it's hard to blame it all on the actors. Van Helsing's sidekick, supposedly there for comic relief, is one of the screen's most hideously obnoxious characters in many years.

It's two hours of throwing glitzy hubbub at you to trick you into thinking something is happening, and about five too many scenes of people swinging through the air on wires. This movie sucks. I can remember, in my lifetime, when Hollywood had balls. It wasn't afraid to offend. It wasn't so obsessed with making money as to forsake making a good movie in the process. VAN HELSING is a good example of everything that is wrong with Hollywood. Too much money, too overblown, hokey humor, targeting the general demographic rather than the true fan, sacrificing intelligence in favor of spectacle. The filmmakers' contempt for their audience is worn on their sleeve.

And who thought Mr. Hyde should look like Shrek?

title: Crap on a stick
review: This movie is absolutely atrocious.  I had high hopes that Van Helsing would kick off the blockbuster season, but my hopes were dashed as I sat through this mindless drivel.  The movie was extremely disjointed and had too many things going on at one time.  As such, it seemed like they changed from scene to scene every couple of minutes which never allowed any part of the storyline develop satisfactorily.  With such a poor script, the actors were working at a major disadvantage from the outset.  Hugh Jackman (X-Men, X-Men 2) did as well as he could in the title role, but this movie was so poorly plotted and written that no actor had any hope of saving it.  Kate Beckinsale (Brokedown Palace, Underworld) portrays Jackman's love interest, gypsy princess Anna Valerious.  Beckinsale's role appeared to be to walk around in a tight leather outfit and to talk in a horribly stereotypical "gypsy" accent.  Richard Roxburgh (Mission Impossible:2, Moulin Rouge) plays a horribly ineffective Dracula.  Roxburgh's Dracula comes across as wimpish and not as the embodiment of evil that past movie Draculas have been. David Wenham (Lord of the Rings) is horribly miscast as Van Helsing's assistant, Carl.  The only saving grace of this film is its use of CGI to create visually stimulating scenery and monsters.  If the film had been written and produced by a Hollywood novice, I could understand.  However, Stephen Sommers wrote 1999's The Mummy which is one of my favorite films.  Of course, taking into consideration that I was disappointed with his follow-up efforts in The Mummy Returns and The Scorpion King, I shouldn't be surprised.  I give Van Helsing a meager rating of 1.5 out of 5 stars. Save your money for some of this summer's upcoming films and wait for Van Helsing to hit video if you really must see it at all.

title: Wolf(erine) Man Jackman?...this one bites the silver bullet
review:
So the dialogue is canned, the story is lacking humor, and the direction is weak. I cant really blame the actors too much here you can tell its what they had to work with, but the whole movie takes itself too seriously for what would be, sans the budget, a B movie. These guys should have taken a cue from League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, another compilation of characters, that movie has a strong comic relief type character to balance all the unbelievable action, there was no relief here. Also it was hard not to make fun of the way too depressing Frankenstein. All and all this movie could have been done much better, but any time you have a writer, writing and directing, you are gonna lose perspective.

I gave it a 2. And I usually give marks for special effects, but I even saw a group of 15 year old boys walk out of this movie.

title: Dross
review:
Well, I beg to differ.

I went expecting a darkish, stylish(ish) movie that would appeal to both kids and adults, light on plot and attention to detail. I was mistaken in my assumptions.

Hugh Jackman's Wolverine was cool, hard, and got the best lines. Hugh Jackman's Van Helsing... well, he was relatively hard I guess. Actually, he was a little too much so.

The old-school vampire hunter is an iconic image with his long coat, wide-brimmed hat and crossbow, even if this image has not been realised fully in cinema (Vampire Hunter D comes closest, but that's Manga crap). A guy decked out like that should be, well... cool. If Jackman, Sommers and the rest responsible for this debacle couldn't even pull that off, then the rest was doomed from the start.

Whilst the plots of most monster mash films are usually only scaffoldings for some set-pieces VH appears to have drafted in the storywriting talents of some actual scaffolders. Gosh! Frankensteins monster died really quick didn't he? He won't be coming back at all! Gosh! The Gypo prince died quickly, plummeting off-screen with a werewolf like that and all. I wonder if he was maybe bitten and might turn into a werewolf? No - surely not.

The real gripe of the film for me has to be the sheer level of 're-imagining' that has gone on. Obviously, the characters (Dracula, VH et al) are not going to be true to the source material, otherwise you wouldn't have a film. But if you are going to use the name of an established character there has to be SOME element of the original character in it. The 'real' literary VH was a) Dutch b) old and frail and c) a professor of medicine. This is slightly at odds with a hard transylvanian guy who killed Dracula when he was still a mortal. And who has been alive for at least 1800 years. Call me picky...

And whilst I'm being picky...

Yes, the crossbow looked cool. But why did it have a strut at all, given that it didn't do anything?

Gosh, what could an invention that produces a light as bright as the Sun do? And why couldn't the story monkeys work out whether vampires could cope with the Sun or not?

Anyone notice the ripping-off of the concept of Mr Hyde as the murderer at the Rue Morgue? And my, it was humorous to have him look like Wolverine, wasn't it? My mistake.

Overall, in MY humble opinion this movie was about as attractive and aromatic as a freshly laid dog egg. I haven't begrudged Â£5.00 as much as when I saw Dungeons & Dragons (I know - I got what I deserved with that one). Avoid.

Oh yes, my fiance loved it - something to do with the lead. (And Frankensteins monster was well-realised).

title: Whatever happened to building to the big ending?
review:
Whatever happened to building to the big ending?

I watched `North By Northwest' a week ago, a film that was generally regarded as the best `action thriller' ever made to that point, (1959). It has, basically, three action scenes. The first is a semi-comical trip down a highway after the bad guys have kidnapped Cary Grant, drugged him up and put him in a car so he will crash and die. That comes about 15 minutes into the film. Most of an hour later comes the famous `Crop duster scene' where an innocent looking plane tries to do Cary in by clipping him with it's wings, machine gunning him and then fertilizing him to death before crashing in a ball of flame. Then, about half hour later, we get the famous escape over Mount Rushmore, where they wind up clinging to George Washington's nose. The rest of the film is a cat and mouse game between Cary and the bad guys and a romance between him and Eva Marie Saint. The whole thing doesn't make much sense but its fun and entertaining nonetheless. Still, to the kind of audience `Van Helsing' was created for, it must seem like pretty tame stuff.

Van Helsing is undoubtedly the first of many films trying to clone `Lord of the Rings' with its huge computer generated monsters and mass battle scenes. Like LOR, the special effects are amazing. But like LOR, the whole movie seems an exercise in special effects, as if that's all the audience came to see so that's what we will show them. There are perhaps a dozen action sequences in this picture, one right after the other, each one spectacular enough to have been the climax of a perfectly good action film. But because they are all so spectacular, their cumulative effect is to make each scene less amazing and less enjoyable. The lack of build up to them and the lack of character development to give them depth makes them less meaningful. It's like reading a comic book for two hours. When at the end, we realize how much Van Helsing has grown to love Anna, we wonder when he ever had time to do that between all the chases and battles with monsters.

Still, I like this picture better than Lord of the Rings because it doesn't take itself so seriously. LOR was like a Wagnerian Opera. This film comes off as pure adventure because the characters have a sense of adventure and a sense of humor, if a sardonic one. But I would have liked it a lot better if it concentrated on developing character and atmosphere and saved the fireworks for the end.

In commenting on another action film I observed that the modern action film has become what the old fashioned Hollywood musical used to be. Whereas the musical used a slight plot to draw together the musical sequences, the modern action film does the same for action sequences. We used to see Fred and Ginger dance. Now we see stuntmen and CGI creations fight. But now it seems we have gone past even that to what amounts to a `clip show', virtually eliminating the plot, except for some shouted exposition, and giving us simply one breathless sequence after another. It all gets to be a little too much after a while. And there just isn't enough meat on the bones.

Those few action sequences in North by Northwest meant more because the people in them mattered to us. Now, who cares?

title: A Monster Disappointment
review: I was really looking forward to this - it sounded like it had all the ingredients for a fantastic monster movie. Saw it on Thursday preview night - couldn't wait. What a waste of time! The ideas were there, and there was the glimmer of the movie it might have been shining through from time to time, but for the most part I laughed with incredulity at how poorly it was executed. The CGI was terrible, the design of the monsters left an awful lot to be desired, and there was no dialogue or characterisation beyond what was necessary to move on to the next "big set-piece". I can't believe actors of the quality of Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale were wasted so completely on roles which did not require them to act. Somebody stop Stephen Sommers from making movies - or at least stop me going to see them - please.

title: Flawed, but entertaining
review:
If you want to hate this film, it gives you plenty of ammo. The pacing is abysmal, it's full of pointless sub-plots that don't go anywhere, including a horde of evil monsters whose sole purpose is to explode pointlessly (err, make that three hordes in fact), so many 'deus ex machina's it's surprising they didn't all fall over each other, dreadful dialog, and everyone's favourite annoyance: gratuitous use of CGI.

So my advice would be: DON'T WATCH IT. That is, unless you just want to sit back, switch off artistic judgement, suspend all belief, and just enjoy the show for what it is: a cheesy action flick with a few novel ideas. See it with friends; laugh at how stupid it is; laugh at the cartoon laws of physics; laugh too at the witty one-liners, occasional comic timing, and joke references to other stories.

It's a shame that with better script-writing and direction, this could have been an excellent film. It certainly had some of the right ingredients.

title: It's fun, but not perfect.
review:
This kind of movie is not intended to be taken too seriously, but what it does intend to do, it does well. Action, adventure, a little comedy and even a splash of romance round out this film.

It's too dark for the kids, but if you're not afraid of heights, you'll get a cheap thrill out of all the swinging, falling, and flying. If they haven't already, I imagine Disney will make a Van Helsing ride. I'd pay!

The CG is well done, but not perfect. I think the subject matter makes that forgivable, however. I already know it's a fantasy, and as long as you choose to get into the movie, you won't mind at all.

title: Don't waste your time- Wait for it to come on cable
review:
It has been proven... not everything can cure boredom! Hmm, no that's not true Van Helsing cures boredom but unfortunately replaces it with disgust. If it were possible to get a refund of my time, I'd be the first in line.

What was so horrible you ask? OK, maybe I'm being a little hasty. It was not the worse movie I have seen, but it might bump Oscar (with Sylvester Stalone) out of the number 3 spot. The story, if you look at it in a very vague and abstract way COULD have been great. Yes, one might call the plot a bite trite- the same story has been done in one way or another several times that I can think of, but with just a bit more imagination, it could have worked. However, the writing was only adequate at best, and the acting, well... let's just say I enjoyed Hugh Jackman better in Kate & Leopold! Kate Beckinsale- the best thing I can say about her is at least she's pretty! Her acting was horrific and the poor girl couldn't have been costumed worse if my seven-year-old cousin drew the clothing on a paper towel!

Each character seemed to be ripped from the pages of every bad Dracula/Frankenstein knock off ever made. Bram Stoker's Dracula it is not! Gee, it's not even Buffy the Vampire Slayer TV series(even I wouldn't say Van Helsing was as bad as the Buffy movie)! The three brides of Dracula, think the movie Hocus Pocus (Bette Midler, Sarah Jessica Parker) add 5 cent vampire teeth from a vending machine and there ya go.

The overall feel of the film reminded me of a bad 1980's B horror film with just a bit of the old soap opera, Dark Shadows. You could have given be a computer from 1974 and I probably could have come up with better graphics and special effects.

OK, OK it wasn't a total waste. There was one bright spot. David Wenham was absolutely adorable as Carl, the geeky genius friar side-kick. He was funny, lovable, witty and if the rest of the film was even a trifle better, he'd have been a brilliant supporting actor. As we all know however, one actor can't save a film.

Now, I never said I did this for a living, but I know what I like and I can tell you, VAN HELSING IS NOT IT! There's no reason to spend any money or your time running out to see this film. Wait for it to come on HBO/Cinemax/Showtime/TMC/Starz real late at night when you can't sleep. THEN, and MAYBE ONLY then would it be worth it.

title: I can't make up my mind
review:
And neither could this movie.

Now I appreciate it when a movie does a good job of combining several genres, and I could see what the makers of Van Helsing were trying to accomplish. Unfortunately that seems to be the theme of movies today. Trying.

The first try was the horror aspect. There were times when I literally jumped in my seat from fright. At one point I almost screamed. But these moments were so few and far between that calling this a horror film just doesn't quite fit.

The next try was the CGI. A bad try. The effects were sloppy at best, and so over the top in their attempts to make the actors look like they were the greatest gymnasts ever born that they were laughable. Come on moviemakers! Whatever happened to a good old fashioned fight without having to hurl characters all over the horizon?

The third try was comedy. This actually worked. The friar who was a Q ahead of his time was hilarious. If only we could have seen more of him and less of the action sequences!

The fourth try was action-adventure. The problem was, instead of making Van Helsing a truly original character, they made him into a Wolverine brooding, Indiana Jones wannabe who dressed like a character from the Matrix. Now I'll give kudos to Kate. She looked awesome. Better then I've ever seen her. And the vampire brides were absolutely stunning on the ground. Too bad they turned into really bad CGI whenever they took flight.

So, what did I think of the movie? I found it trying.

Rank: 6 out of 10

title: It was as good as it was bad
review: I got sucked in by the trailer and thought what the heck. Some people from work were going and we all can use some check your brain at the door fun. There were some parts that were great but it seemed that they had 3/4 of a movie when they started and figured they will just rap it up in the end. Some of the fight scenes were just right for what you would think these mythical characters would look like getting it on and they tie the charicters together very well. For the most part the CGI was good enough to not distract but like I said up top during the last quarter of the movie you will look over at the person you came with and ask "what the heck was that." 5 1/2 stars

title: And I wanted to like this movie so bad...
review: Alright, well to be completely fair, I walked into this movie pumped.  I had been looking forward to it since I first read the rumors.  Hugh Jackman is great and Beckinsale isn't too bad either, but they just couldn't pull this movie out of the rutt.  The movie got into this early pattern of dropping people from the top of things and just didn't seem to be able to stop.  I can't remember the last time falling was a chief plot device in a movie! Anyway, we are grounded in a certain love for the classic horror creatures (Drac, Frank, Wolfie) and to cheer against them we need to be given a certain motivation, i.e. connection to the hero who battles them.  Van Helsing just doesn't offer that.  I didn't care what happened to either of the heroes in the movie, no matter how many times they fell off of things. Thrills were not delivered, special effects were only semi-impressive while not realistic, and they played on the same old monster mashing traditions. Beckinsale seems strangely doomed to make Underworld over and over as it seems this was another werewolf versus vampire movie.  Weak plot, weak characters, weak movie, little or no originality.  Luckily, the constant action is just enough to keep you from realizing what the movie is till it's over.  In the end, it really feels like an episode of a Van Helsing cartoon than anything else. 5/10

title: excellent in comparison
review:
There is nothing else out there that even mentions the classic movie monsters for many years. For years films have dominated by Jason, michael Meyers, and psychos. This film revives Frankenstein, wolfman and Dracula.

Obviously the film maker has much respect for the monsters of the past. This film, though, puts in intensive CGI and wild action to bring in younger viewers and does not have the subtle horror of the Hammer films and is not scary in that way. I love films like The Ring or Mothman Prophesies or The Innocence. This film is nothing like those. It is more in the style of Cutthroat Island and like League of Extraordinary Gentlemen. This film plays more like an adventure or science fiction. Jackman is super as van Helsing fresh of his debonair performance in the good film Kate and Leopold. He plays the part nothing like Peter Cushing but I think Cushing would like this film.

I have seen almost all the Dracula films including the old wolfman verses Dracula, Billy the Kid verses Dracula, and even the Laurel and Hardy monster films. I believe the director has also. I believe this current actor who played Dracula was the weakest part of this film but the film still holds up. Of course the most classic Draculas are the Christopher Lee and Peter Cushing Hammer films. They are beyond good. This new film keeps the interest going in these interesting monsters for a new generation. There is also little gore or explicitness compred to so much out there so kids can see it but is is very intense.

It was also exciting and actually had a powerful but sincere ending. I think an interesting thing this film changes after decades of beautiful enticing vampire women is to make the vampires more grotesque and less desirable. This is a major change in the treatment of the vampiress. In this film the vampire hunter was the gorgeous girl. Also the Vatican is portrayed positively in the film as they are very concerned with fighting the forces of evil. The Vatican hires Van Helsing to go and destroy Dracula. The Vatican even has a secret factory that makes gadgets to battle evil kind of like James Bond.

I hope they make more of these but lets give Christopher Lee a part.. Also this may propel Jackman as van Helsing into consideration for the new James Bond. This film is full of imagination and not boring! Helsing stays true to tradition with lines like "I can only kill something controlled by evil" and has honor. Also considering this is an action film there are some interesting philosophical lines. Highly recommended!

title: Fine Adaptation Of Movie Horror Classics
review:
I was waiting with anticipation to see this movie since I grew up watching these characters in old movie re-runs. Seeing them all together one one spectacularly well adapted movie was definitely a treat.

Hugh Jackman (Wolverine from "The X-Men") plays Van Helsing rather well, the story line was rather intense and the special effects jumped out at you. This is a great flick for those who are fans of horror, especially fans of classic horror.

Go ahead, treat yourself to a nice movie. You won't regret it and you'll have loads of fun. It's well worth the money and definitely should be seen on the big screen.

title: Is this the film itself or the spoof?
review:
I wanted to like it so much, being a huge Dracula fan. And to be honest, it wasn't the 'interpretation' of Dracula and Van Helsing that got me.

No - it was the God-awful excuse for a plot, terrible CGI, some hideous 'acting' from certain quarters. Jackman appeared to be almost the only cast member

who even attempted to act, while Beckinsale was apparently under the

impression that her job was to make fun of Romanians. It was the blatant

plagiarism from every other movie ever made, from Shrek to The Lion King to

The Matrix. Seriously. And I strongly believe that an actor of Hugh Jackman's calibre deserved a better film than this one to launch him as somebody capable of carrying a whole film on his shoulders.

And yet, after all that, it never intended itself to be taken seriously. I suppose it is mildly entertaining, the ultimate B-movie, as it was put. If you go in with no expectations, you won't come out disappointed. Maybe I should go again,

knowing what's coming, forgetting that I waited months for this and remembering that yes, some of the laughs in the cinema were unintentional and came out of such things as a kiss more wooden than the one in Attack of the Clones, but

some came out of genuine jokes in the film. Give it a chance, make up your own mind, but don't expect anything Oscar-worthy.

title: Cartoon Movie
review:
This isn't a good movie, but it aint particularly bad.

The actual premise had potential but the way in which is was realized was so OTT that even the escapist movie goers have trouble believing what they are watching.

It took a while for movie makers to get to grips with CGI but now it seems they are using it to gloss over poor storylines and miscast actors/actresses.

Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsdale are good actors but Hugh seems to say about 10 words in the movie (and one of them was an embarrassing howl at the end) whilst Kate does well at keeping a straight face while she talks in her 'east European' accent.

We now seem to live in a cartoon movie era. I don't mean that allot of the films are based on cartoon characters (i.e. Spiderman, batman) but the actual way the films are made are cartoonish. Dialogue is whittled down to a few choice expletives and catch phrases and the physical action (jumping 50ft doors in a single leap) has reached totally ridiculous levels (even Spiderman thinks twice before swinging from a skyscraper).

It may sound daft but there are boundaries to which the average movie goer can reach before coming out of the virtual reality of a film.

The trouble with this film is that you snap out of the Helsing reality in the first 10 minutes and end up just smiling wryly through the rest of the film.

title: Great Fun!!
review:
Unlike many of the reviews in which this movie is seen as bad, I must differ. It made perfect sense to me and had a simple plot with alot of action and some campy humor! I think the best way to see this movie is without any expectations or preconcieved notions. Like so many legends these days, they are either updated or totally redone, from King Arthur to Batman; what you see in the movies usually differ drastically from the legendary heroes.

Overall, this movie was fast paced with implied gore and a nice ending, for those not too hardened by all these revenge movies and reality based dramas; a nice adrenaline rush, like Van Helsing, is a great change of pace!

title: Entertaining, but homage or rip-off?
review:
Van Helsing was a decently entertaining movie. It does not start off too well, but improves once the action picks up a little bit. It does seem to use parts of other movies, but not necessarily monster movies as you would expect. I definitely noticed scene or line similarities with LOTR: The Fellowship of the Ring, The Fifth Element, and The Good, the Bad, & the Ugly among others. This is not a good thing. It's OK to pay homage to classic movies of the same genre, but to take from a spectrum of different ones does not help a movie.

A lot of eye-rolling scenes, but entertaining enough. 7/10

title: Over blown tosh
review: Only going to mention a few of the reasons the movie lost me. 1 After the failure of league of extraordinary gentleman why bother using another failed Jekyl/Hyde CGI disaster.  Did not add anything.  2 Why add more rope swinging than a Tarzan movie.  3 Why waste the fantastic sex appeal of both the leading characters.  Costume design one high point of the whole thing.  Such a shame as you could see the care in the opening that it led to overblown shots that wasted the truely sinister nature of vampires and their blood sucking biology.  I am truly upset and angry about this movie.  A big CGI budget should be used sparingly.  The Mummy let you marvel at flesh eating scarabs and sinister sandstorms but here the effects just bored.  Remember less is sometimes so much more.

title: Too much action - lack of story
review:
After being served for nearly two hours of constant action, I could finally relax and breath. "Van Helsing" is filled with constant action, wicked combats, endless effects loaded together with some quick comments. I do think the whole movie started up well, but the more it developed the bigger the lack of story got, and the more action I was fed with. I think they went to much "Matrix" here, and lost the very important balance between having a good (deep) story and having awesome scenes of combat. Anyways, I experienced this piece at the cinema and I think that is a big plus, at least that is my conclusion. With all those visual effects and the astonishing audio experience it must be experienced at the cinema (or perhaps at home with some awesome audio equipment).

As my head still feels a little wicked and as I probably haven't really melted the piece yet, I still think that 6 out of 10 is a fair grade for "Van Helsing".

title: Bad bad somewhat entertaining
review:
Van Helshing could have been a great movie. Come to think of it, is had everything a movie needs to provide a fun couple of hours: vampires, women in sexy clothes (all hail Kate Beckinsale), vampire hunters and more women in sexy clothes who also happen to be vampires... So where did it all go wrong?

First of all the story is godawful and at times it feels like it was written by a 5 year old. First of all it is cliched to the point of stupidity a thing which is obvious right from the beginning since the movie starts with an angry mob carrying torches and pitchforks and heading to lynch Dr. Frankenstein. The first line we hear in the movie is the good doctor shouting "It's alive, it's alive, it's alive". Also In the same sequence Dracula uses the most used line in vampire films "you can't kill me, i'm already dead..." (note to writters: please stop using this line and its variations in everything about vampires, honestly, it's not even remotely funny anymore...) and of course Frankenstein is aided by Igor who (yeah you guessed it) is a midget with a hump on his back... The story also makes no sense at all: Dracula and his brides wants to release upon the world a horde of his offsprings (some gargoyle like small creatures) probably just for the fun of it since no reason as to why he wants to do it is given. To do that he needs to strap Frankenstein's monster in the machine that Dr. Frankestein used to give life to it. Van Helshing of course has to stop him and kill him before he or his minions (including a werewolf) kills Anna, Kate Beckinsale's character. Brace yourselves for the stupidest plot device yet: Van Helshing works for the Vatican and Anna's family has made an oath to kill Dracula or forever rot in Hell. After an expected turn of events Anna is the last of her family and because her family has helped in the Vatican's war against monsters they can't let the eternal damnation of her family happen so they send in Van Helshing... The titular monster hunter is probably one of the swallowest characters ever seen in cinema. He kills monsters because... well because he is told he has to do so by the Vatican since he suffers from amnesia (amnesia seems to love Hugh Jackman since this is the second character (Wolverine was the first) he plays in a major movie who is troubled by it). To make matters worse, the audience is never given an answer to the most crucial question of the movie: who, or rather what the Hell is Van Helshing anyway?

The script is also dreadful and at times makes absolutely no sense. For example, two of Dracula's brides corner Anna and even though they are hell

bent on killing her, they chat with her for five minutes... I can imagine the end of the dialogue: "Sooooooo and now that we've told you what Count Dracula is like in bed, we have to kill you. If that's ok with you, if not then we're obviously open to discussion..."

Then there's the acting... Acting is the movie's second big flaw. The only one of the major actors who manages to come out unscathed is Hugh Jackman. Kate Beckinsale and Richard Roxburgh (Dracula) are nothing but ridiculous with their very fake Romanian accents. Roxburgh's over-acting, especially in the first minutes of the film, along with some very bad dialog, render Dracula nothing short of a caricature, a thing that would be acceptable if the movie was presented as a parody, but unfortunately it isn't.

The film does have some good things going on for it. The amounts of action presented are huge and will satisfy even the hardest action junkie. The fact that the character's have no developement what so ever diminishes the amount of dialogue and raises the number of action scenes. In fact most sequences go a little like this: Van Helshing has an about one or two minutes long dialog with another character, usually with Anna, a monster attacks and an action scene ensues... So it never really gets boring. Most action sequences are good but some, like one involving six horses carrying a carriage and jumping in perfect unisson across a chasm, are plainly illogical and cause laughter.

The film's other high point is the way it looks. The cinematography is excellent especially an early vista of Paris with the Eiffel tower under construction in the background and Dracula's Ice Fortress do manage to create a dark atmosphere. The costumes are also very good. But what steals the show are the special effects. The CGI werewolves are very realistic even up-close and the sequences of vampires turning to bat creatures and humans turning into werewolves as well as the final Dracula and Van Helshing showdown are breath-taking. All in all, the film is excellent eye candy.

Van Helshing is a bad movie almost in every aspect. If you expect a dark and most of all serious movie about the famous vampire hunter then avoid it at all costs. The film is so campy that at times it feels like a Saturday morning Cartoon (Toonsylvania sprung in mind when i heard and saw Igor...) If you want to see some really cool action scenes and SFX and you don't care much about trivial things like say a good story and plot than don't miss it. By the way, a note to Steven Sommers: there's a reason why people don't make movies like the monster movies of the 30s, that's because they now seem campy and ridiculous... Some things belong in the past. And a closing note to Kate Beckinsale: whatever they pay you, never, NEVER play in a film without using your native accent! Believe me it's for your own good.]

So from me Van Helshing gets a very generous 5 out of ten.

title: *SPOILERS* Not quiet the same old
review:
I liked watching Van Helsing, the director created a dark, forbidding environment, and gave some of the characters a life and depth I wouldn't expect from a typical action flick. I found myself actually sympathizing with the 'bad guys' in the movie. *SPOILERS* For example, the Count seemed to be a father desperate to give his offspring life. His Brides also seemed a part of this,... less like scary monsters than predators higher on the evolutionary food chain. The 'humanizing' aspects of Frankenstein's monster and the werewolf seemed scripted, but understandable.

While Jackman was sexy as Van Helsing, I just wish Jackman's character was more developed, not just the typical 'well armed' muscle that runs around shooting things. Granted, he was very good at running around shooting things, but I thought his friar side-kick Carl showed more personality! If you are thinking of seeing this movie, go for the friar.

title: Special Effects Bonanza
review:
A lot of special effects and a storyline that tries to justify them all. It was typical summer fare. Hugh Jackman gave an admiral and strong performance as did Richard Roxburgh. There were just some terribly annoying things to watch throughout: (1) Kate Beckinsdale's perfect make-up, especially eyeliner, (2) her ridiculous clothing (3) the horrendous make-up job on Igor.

I viewed it as the first movie of the summer and gave it leeway as such. I thought Hellboy was a much better movie (considering what is in theaters now). I expect spectacle for summer. This had the spectacle effects. However, I've seen bigger and better and will expect that from each movie in coming weeks.

title: Eh...
review:
This just felt like an "ehh" kinda movie. There were so many special effects that I felt that the theater seats should have moved around, like in those amusement park rides. Dracula's wives were, IMO, the WORST part of this movie. I've seen better acting in high school plays. Campiness is good at times but they were beyond campy to being just dreadful. And those things that help Dracula, whatever they're called, looked like evil, demented Umpa Loompas. And Igor just had a horrible make-up job. And this Mr. Hyde business, can anyone say Shrek rip off?

Okay, now to what I liked. Yes, shocker, I liked parts of this movie. The score was THE BEST part. While I may never buy the movie I'm seriously considering purchacing the music. I also liked the camp, when it was done well. But I found myself laughing in weird places.

*SPOILER*

I couldn't help it when Kate Beckinsale's character dies. The howl of the wolfman/Van Helsing just made me giggle. I thought it was incredibly funny. I don't know why.

*END SPOILER*

AND I liked Hugh Jackman although his accent threw me. I wasn't sure if he was trying to go for German or English or what. I've heard people say Kate's accent was bad, I think his was worse. Ah, but I didn't mind the way he looked. That HAIR! *faint* It's funny that anyone who had good hair never seemed to mess it up. Again, camp. Too bad there wasn't more of it, the movie would have been better. Campiness is what makes the Mummy good and that's why I like it. This movie just didn't seem to have enough or the camp it had just didn't seem to fit.

IMO, this movie gets a 5.5 out of 10. It wasn't horrible but it wasn't great either.

title: entertainment through and through
review:
ive seen reviews. ive seen the trailers. i wanted to see this film. hugh jackman. check. kate beckinsale. check. good plot? hmm. debatable! id heard feedback from this film from friends, and they were saying not to bother, but i wanted my own opinion. and this is it. the opening had me trying to guess the voice of mr hyde. (eventually found it after looking it up on here). throughout the film it is very implausable. the brides of dracula were too over the top. the monsters were spot on however. richard roxburgh as dracula..at 1st i could only see the duke from Moulin Rouge, but it only took a second, then i was entranced by his character. he was played perfectly, very believable. however the best character by far was Carl the frier. it is so easy to find 5 minutes of the best bits for the trailer, and Carl was virtually missed out, a very good little treat for the viewer. easily the best action part of the film, was the horse and carriage sequence.

this was entertainment through and through, no plausibility beyond fantasy and an over active imagination. well done stephen sommers. 6/10

title: monster movie fest
review: Granted this movie was not as great as it could have been--the vampire teeth were cheesy and the wicked witch of the west laugh got old--it was still a good movie, based on the tradition of the monster movie.  Considering Bella Lugosi worked with rubber bats on strings, this movie is a lot better. For those of you who hated it-did you actually watch it or are you being obnoxious and just making posts?  And if you did hate it that bad, why did you stay for the whole thing.  The fight with Jekyll should have tipped you off as to what kind of movie it was going to be...and yes, I do think there will be a follow up movie, but it will more than likely be a prequel as there is more material to work with there.

title: Wasn't BAD....Wasn't GREAT...But Wasn't BAD!!!
review:
I LOVE Hugh Jackman so I really couldn't wait to go see this one!

The movie wasn't bad. It was pretty exciting...although there just wasn't much in the way of a storyline. There were all sorts of cool monsters in this flick and I have to say, I really LIKED Dracula! I don't understand why everyone is slamming him and Kate's accent. I think the entire ensemble did a great job. Also...for the person who mentioned Anne Rice rolling over in her grave....SHE'S STILL ALIVE! Worth a rental and a matinee...don't pay full price.

title: Great monster movie throwback, fun movie on its own.
review:
I keep seeing bad reviews for this movie, and I can't help but wonder why. I came into the movie expecting the worse. I've been disappointed by movies often lately, and the trailer for this one had all the symptoms. I wasn't even comforted by the fact that it was directed by Stephen Sommers, whose Mummy movies I really liked.

However, I can safely say that I left the movie completely satisfied and my faith in Stephen Sommers as a great "adventure" movie directory has been solidified.

Maybe people are looking to get too much out of this movie - I don't know. I never expected it to be an award winning movie. I just went into it to have fun. I'm a big fan of old monster movies, and this movie has numerous throwbacks to the old movies... I started laughing out loud at a lot of the camera work because it felt so much like a classic monster movie. They did an excellent job at paying tribute to a lot of the classic moments from these movies without obviously straying from the story.

The story was decent to good. There were a lot of elements I liked, but there wasn't a HUGE amount of depth to it (not necessarily a problem, in my eyes). My only real problems with the story were some rather large jumps they did from one scene to another without explaining the events in between very well.

The action was very well done, as was the accompanying computer graphics that made a lot of the scenes possible. The special effects weren't always on par with other recent movies, such as LGX, but they were definitely believable for the most part.

My vote for this movie was 8/10. I think it did what it set out to do - make a movie that paid a tribute to the monster movies of old, while giving audiences a fun filled two hour ride through a large cast of characters. The movie was just the right length, and besides some plot holes and CG problems, I was a happy movie-goer at the end of the experience. If you liked the Mummy, I can definitely recommend this movie.

title: CG's Gone Wild-spoiler
review: When a movie depends on Computer Graphics as much as Van Helsing did, you know there's a big problem.  Some of the dialog was witty but it  just didn't move in any direction that made sense. Kill the vampires. Okay, I'm with that. People running outside to SEE the vampires come to get them? Not so much.  Nothing much between the characters that would make you think they had a thought for each other.  When Van Helsing transforms into a werewolf and attacks Princess Anna, shouldn't she have looked a little more.....well, ATTACKED?   The best part of the CG glut was the wives of Dracula transformations.  That I enjoyed. But basically it was a loud, violent, mishmash of monsters.  No,  I pass on this one.

title: Wow! - Spoilers
review: i saw this movie Saturday and it was one of the years best movies or one of the best movies of all time! The special effects blew me away and i can not believe how awesome the movie was. i would give this movie ten out of ten stars. Kate Beckansale is one of the hottest actresses i have seen in a movie (besides Halle berry) but Kate and Hugh were the perfect on screen duo for this film. i am going to go see this movie again and surely will buy it when it comes out on video. the best scene in the movie is at the END when Van Helsing is fighting Dracula! I was really surprised to see that in the beginning of the movie it was in black and white, but like i said 10 out of 10!

title: A Specialist beats a generalist, and this is not a specialist
review: This movie tries to be too many things.  It tries to add way too many monsters into it.  The whole movie is CG and that's all it has going for it. The plot is only furthered by occasional dialog.  The Special Effects are LOADED with over the top explosions and pyrotechnics.  The sound effects are repeated over and over throughout the movie.  I honestly didn't think the movie was going to end.  The goths sitting behind me in the theater laughed at the movie the whole time...it's not a comedy.  And the worst part, think of every cliche in every movie that's been done a thousand times and they put it into this movie.  From the jittery comic relief guy trying to walk away when it gets frightening, to the cheesy walking off into the sunset ending.  Do yourself a favor, if you must see this movie, wait for a rental.

title: A Waste of time and money.
review:
This was not only a waste of $8.50 per ticket and my Sunday afternoon, it was a waste of Hollywood's cash and Hugh Jackman's time.

There were more holes in this movie than Swiss Cheese. It is one of the most poorly written scripts I think I have ever seen. Nothing was developed well, be it the characters or the plot. I wanted to leave after the first 30 minutes, but figured that it would get better. Boy was I wrong.

I can't say much about the actor's performances, because they were given so little to work with. Roxburgh was the highlight of the film, as he was somewhat convincing given the script.

I gave it 2 stars, and only because Kate Beckinsale and the vampire girls are smoking hot.

title: Almost what I expected
review:
I am not going to beef on about what happens int he film or what certain parts meant to me.

All I shall say is that I went to the cinema expecting a real "Brain at the door" mindless action romp with a tiny bit of pointless humour and some nice stunts.....that is exactly what I got.

The humour factor, basically being the friar, is pathetically camp - think The Mummy. The action is quick and fast and pretty exciting.

But the one thing I MUST mention is the ending. **Spoiler**..... The moment when Anna Valerious (Kate Beckinsale) is placed on the pyre and burned, and her 'soul' floats into the air and meets her family? I was on the brink of walking out of the cinema. I cringed and i hid my face in shame for fear of being seen watching such a truly, painfully awful scene. Whomever decided to put that in, I soooo hope they lose their job 8o) **End Spoiler**

All in all though, a fun mindless film on the same vein as The Mummy which is worth seeing in the cinema purely as the small screen will not capture the good parts as well.

title: Average CGI, Horrible Acting, Below average movie.
review:
Ribbed Turtleneck Sweater??? WTF!!!!!!

Van Helsing (Hugh Jackman) has only one outfit throughout the entire movie. It consists of a leather trenchcoat, leather hat, leather boots, and a grey, ribbed, turtleneck sweater. It looks more like a Berlin clubbing outfit than anything else.

This movie takes place before the 20th century obviously, so how on earth did Van Helsing get his hands on a grey, ribbed, turtleneck sweater before the 1960's! The people behind this movie could have at least TRIED to make the outfit look like it came from over a century ago.....instead of raiding Ricky Martin's closet from 1998.

Moving on (thought I don't want to), the rest of the movie is just below average. Details:

The CGI comes off as just average. The good points are the fusion of CGI on the vampires faces when they open their mouths wide to take bites. Also the CGI artwork of Dracula's brides are also done quite well. The backgrounds are also excellent, but alot of fog effects cover up any mistakes. The bad....Dracula for starters. He looks like he just walked off the set of the Golden Child. Extemely cartoony...just plain bad. The werewolfs also looks cartoony as well. And Dracula's spawn just look like little video game monsters.....too cartoony.

The acting. KILL ME NOW before I here anymore horrible eastern-european accents. The guy who played Dracula was the worst...by far....so cheesy. Hugh Jackman did fine, but his role was limited to the serious action hero and all he had to do was not deliver his lines like Vin Diesel. Kate Beckingsale had the only role that showed a great range of emotion and had the ability to show acting prowess. Unfortunately, with a cheesy accent and forced emotion, she failed at this.

Story....what story? Why was dracula releasing werewolves? Why did Dracula need Frankenstein if had the Doctors equipment? Could Frankenstein have been anymore pointless? Why does Dracula even care to kill off Kate Beckingsale's family? Finally, don't expect any suprises. The movie tries, but every twist can been a half hour before it happens.

title: too much dumb comic relief
review: this movie would have been better if it was taken a little more seriously. why did Van Helsing have that stupid monk as his sidekick? the monk constantly made one-liners that were corny and adolescent. was there any purpose either in showing him the morning after he had sex with the woman from the village? come on, the writer could have come up with something a little more interesting for that scene. and why was Frankenstein's monster such a nice guy that always swung from a rope in every scene he was in? he should have been a ruthless, vicious killer that was one of Van Helsing's targets. other than that lots of great action with incredible CGI. but i only give it a WEAK 3 stars.

title: Or... How to make a movie out of others!
review:
OH MY GOD!

This has to be one of the worst movies I've seen over the last couple of years... And believe me: I watch almost everything. I was really excited when I saw the previews, but I think, that the picture itself couldn't actually live up to the promises the preview made.

The good points of the movie: Nice Art-Direction, good SFX, but that's about it. I feel so sorry for Hugh Jackman, because I consider him a great actor. Now for the bad ones:

And now... For all the stuff, they took out of other movies (in no particular order; including the obvious ones like Dracula & Frankenstein):

1.) Childrens Cocoons... "Alien" 2.) Van Helsings Weapons (Lightbomb, Handshredders)... "Blade" 3.) Frankensteins Coat & Dressing... "Mary Shelley's Frankenstein" 4.) The Laboratory, where Van gets his weapons & Carl... "James Bond" (& "Q") 5.) Draculas Handymen... "Star Wars" (Jawas) 6.) The Fancy Dress Ball, including the dance in front of the mirror... "Roman Polanski's Fearless Vampire Killers" 7.) The ritual burning of dead Anna, including her appearing in the heavens above... "Conan The Barbarian" 8.) Mr. Hyde... looked absolutely like the one from "League Of Extraordinary Gentlemen" 9.) The Mirror-Door to "Dracula's Castle"... Reminded a bit of "Stargate", but was rather like "John Carpenter's Prince Of Darkness" 10.) and so on...

Plus: The dialogues were lame, the direction of actors in parts very awkward & Van Helsing's Hat looked so gay! ;-) Oh yeah... And what was that "Dancing Dracula" scene about? I can't help it... this movie just sucked. A shame considering the nice idea. Also, the story really left some questions open, like: what actually WAS the relationship between Gabriel & Dracula? Is Van Helsing Arcangel Gabriel? All left up to your imagination...

I was very disappointed, so use my experience and save you money for a burger or something. I put this movie up for hottest contender of the raspberry of the year! Who's with me?

Greets, Al.

title: Non stop Nonsense
review:
Overblown action, little plot, awful dialogue and poor characterisation, with stock figures such as 'Carl' make this a very poor effort. For much of the film I thought I was seeing a very inferior version of LOTR. Stunning though Kate Beckinsale looked, even that was not a good enough reason to see this film. I liked both the 'Mummy' films, and know that this shouldn't be taken seriously, but it should at least be done well. Please don't make a sequel - though given the quite full theatre I saw it in, I've no doubt that they will. Surely it can't be any worse that this ?

Btw - who was doing Mr Hyde in Notre Dame ? I couldn't remember his name, but his face rang a bell !

title: Action Packed Smash hit movie of the year
review:
Brace yourself for a non-stop, jaw dropping, melee of action/fantasy/horror/thriller heart pounding film, full of excitement. Visually breath-taking scenes from start to finish. Whether it be the stunningly cast, beautiful scenery or the fantastic Computer Graphics(CG), there is something for everyone. Many twists and plot changes combined with several different classic stories to make a melting-pot of entertainment, enjoyable for most movie buffs.

Definitely a BIG SCREEN movie. There are a few mistakes, such the odd scene with bad acting/scripting flaws, but on the whole the performances were more then appropriate, this is a great movie. Some familiar faces, some new. all combined to make a very entertaining flick.

9/10

title: Save Your Money!!
review:
I am a long-time fan of horror movies, and I like Hugh Jackman. The previews for this film looked pretty good, and the premise sounded interesting as well: monster hunter takes on some of film's most notorious bad guys. I figured this would be a fun ride, so I plunked down my cash for an opening-day matinee. I wish I hadn't....

Unfortunately, Van Helsing is one of the worst films I've seen in years. The plot is surprisingly uninspired, character development is weak, and the major conflict of the story is so dull that I couldn't wait to get out of the theater. The action is like a bad video game, packed so full of miraculous stunts and escapes that it is utterly absurd. Any sense of tension when the main characters face monsters is lost fairly early in the film and never recovers. Halfway through the movie I was checking my watch and counting down the minutes left in this 2 1/2 hour long disaster.

Was anything good? Well, some of the special effects were OK. There were a couple funny lines. That's probably about it. Frankly, it's not even worth a rental. Save your money, or use it for a better breed of horror film like Bram Stoker's Dracula or even Fright Night.

title: Don't waste your money or snooze time
review: I dozed off twice in this one. The closing credits were as creative as the animation in the rest of the movie. The continuity was lacking in a number of scenes, which is critically important because of the constant jumping from human to animated action. The soundtrack was actually the best part of this movie. Acting was terrible. I kept being reminded of other movies' characteristics: aspects of James Bond and Alice in Wonderland; Wild, Wild West (failed attempts at interesting 19th-century technology) and Jumanji (CGA was outdated); Indiana Jones (anachronistic wisecracks), Frankenstein, and Young Frankenstein (an erudite monster). The main characters are all attractive but hardly three-dimensional, Save your $$$.

title: Van Helsing Is AWESOME!!!
review:
I'm also a huge fan of Hugh Jackman. I love his movies! I'm also a huge fan of Kate Beckinsale. I love their work, and I admire them.

I only go to see action-adventure, horror, and comedy films. I believe this movie has all three characteristics.

I love vampire and werewolf movies, and I think this is probably on the top of my list. There's just something about this movie that just draws you into it. I've seen it almost five times now since it came out on the seventh! I never get tired of all the action.

The end of the movie is probably the best. Mostly because of the fight; Werewolf vs. Dracula. That single part of the movie is worth the money you pay to see it. Dracula may look a little faky at times, but he still looks pretty sweet.

I just wanted to say how much I enjoyed this movie. It has some great comedy in it, David Wenham is hilarious, and some of the best fighting sequences I've seen in awhile.

I recommend seeing this movie if you enjoy a lot of action. If you've already seen this movie, I also recommend Kate Beckinsale's Underworld movie that came out last year. Also a great vampire vs. werewolf film.

title: Lack of Depth
review:
Not quite what I was expecting. I was expecting much more. Considering Hugh Jackman was in the film, I was expecting a X-Men quality movie. My hopes were sadly disappointed. Richard Roxburgh played also in League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, which fell into the same category.

The characters were shallow. The film was 2.5 hours of a lot of comic book style action, which was great to watch. The only character which had the most development was Frankenstein's monster. He actually had dialogue. The rest of the characters were lacking in dialogue and depth. One scene had Hugh and Anna kiss, which practically came out of nowhere. I just wish Hugh signs up for X3.

title: WHAT! WHAT ! ... I demand my 7.50 back!
review:
SPOILER!!!!! POSSIBLE SPOILER!!!!



... the severity of this movie is uncomprehensible. How could someone butcher three classic characters and make them completely strip them of their awesomeness... just go spend $7 at your local theater. The cheese in this movie was oozing out of the screen it was unreal. They shouldve gotten the actors dialect assitants, they were soooo bad, good lord! How could anyone let this happen, the gopher should have said something, anyone, the nameless vampbride #1, someone SHOULVE stopped it from reaching the box office. SMILING DOWN FROM HEAVEN! come on PEOPLE! it would have been awesome if all the weapons were old school. Electricity in the 1500's? Kodak picture profiles on the cursed family? give me a break. I dont think vampires can mate, I mean how can something grow inside of you dead? its dead, its not growing.CONFUSING.
