This movie may be fun for some people, but overall if your over the age of 7 I dont reccomend it...

p.s. HUGH JACKMAN, take some crying lessons...

title: Let's Keep Things In Perspective...
review: First off, let me say that I am a HUGE fan of the early Universal horror movies. These movies created the genre. My understanding was that Van Helsing was a modern, CGI-heavy homage to those early movies. The movie even begins where the Son Of Frankenstein left off. Except for the stellar perfomance of Karloff in The Mummy and the first 2 Frankenstein movies, almost all of the rest of the early Universal Dracula/Frankenstein/Wolfman movies were fun (and sometimes silly) popcorn movies. True, there was not a lot of room in this movie for deep acting and the story might even be considered campy, but that's ok. It was a fun addition to the Universal horror tradition.  I liked Jackman's Van Helsing character and David Wenham was great. There were a few questionable bits of dialog, a bad accent here and there, some borderline CG, etc, etc...but I enjoyed the movie a great deal.

title: If your idea of "fun" is stabbing yourself with red-hot needles, this movie's for you.
review:
I'm glad I went into this movie knowing it was bad, so I wasn't disappointed. But still, I was unprepared for the horrors that ensued. Not from the monsters in the movie, but from the monster that WAS the movie.

There was NO plot or character development. I wasn't expecting much, but I thought there would at least be a linear set of events... instead, this movie jumps from one scene to the next with no rhyme or reason. Is it so much to ask that events follow some sort of order that makes sense?

The dialogue was amazingly cheesey. I've heard better dialogue from passed-out drunkards lying on the bathroom floor. The worst may have come from the Frankenstein monster, as he shouted out random Bible passages (Though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death...!") and screamed "I will have my revenge!" in a rather menacing manner. Except he was addressing Dracula's "helpers," these small Jawa-like creatures that were, apparantly, quite flammable. I have to hand it to the actors, though; they delivered all their lines without cracking up.

And the CGI. Dear God. What happened to guys running around in monster suits and stunt doubles beating the s*** out of each other? Must EVERYTHING be CGI? A CGI fight is hardly impressive. And if they must use it, why not try to make it look somewhat realistic?

Anyway, enough ranting. This is a fun movie, if you think stabbing yourself repeatedly with needles is fun. By the last third of the movie, half of the theater had left; only a dozen or so people remained when the credits finally rolled. It was bad. Really, really bad.

title: Lots of flash and not much plot don't necessarily make a bad movie.
review:
Director Stephen Sommers has always turned out unique movie gems, so I was looking forward to Van Helsing when I went to see it this weekend. I had read some bad reviews for it and didn't have high hopes, but I was pleasantly surprised.

Van Helsing is possibly one of the most beautiful movies visually that I have ever seen. The special effects are wonderful, executed with finesse and talent. Sommers' vision of the creatures he has chosen to use in the movie makes them fresh, rather than the same tired old thing. All of the scenery is amazing, and I love the black and white sequence in the beginning that is a throwback to old horror movies. The camera angles and cinematography show that this crew knows their way around a movie set, and that's enjoyable.

The same can be said for Van Helsing's stunts. This movie is chock full of action, and the sequences are different each time and very charged. I jumped a few times out of surprise, and that doesn't happen very often. With lots of different locales for the fights, you get a variety of techniques and skills, and the fight scenes aren't so short that you find yourself disgusted at the character being invincible, but not so long that you're looking at your watch waiting for it to be over. Each character also gets equal pieces of the action, so it's not all Hugh Jackman running around beating people up.

The movie is very well-cast. Jackman plays an excellent hunter of evil, with just the right amount of spunk for a man in his position. Dracula is appropriately devious and cunning, with even bigger schemes than Bram Stoker imagined for him. The surprise fun character is Carl, the equivalent of 007's Q. He makes all the gadgets and is the brains of the operation, even managing to throw a few punches himself. Kate Beckinsale (who I admire for not passing out in that tight costume) is much better as a spirited princess than the brooding vampire she played in Underworld, and proves that she can tackle the fantasy genre successfully.

The one disappointment I had with this movie was that it has very little plot. I was left at the end wanting to know more about Van Helsing, where he came from, and why he ended up the way he did. To be fair, Stephen Sommers may be planning a sequel, but it is confusing when you don't have a lot of information at the end of the movie, because the Dracula mythology is wonderfully woven and detailed. I'm interested to see if there is more to this franchise than just the first movie, as there was with Sommers' hits (and movies I loved) The Mummy and The Mummy Returns.

Overall, this movie gets an 8 out of 10 from me, and I'm interested to see where it could go in the future.

title: A film for everyone!
review:
If you go to this movie intending to have FUN, you will not be disappointed. Silly, campy, noisy, you can laugh and scream and jump and have a good time.

If you are going for the eye candy, Jackman delivers. Wait for it, the view improves as the movie progresses. And Jackman isn't the only pretty face in the film.

If you are a fan of old Grade B horror films, they've brought in almost all of your old friends. Only one is distinctly missing and I couldn't figure out how to bring him into the story either.

Having only every seen David Wenham as the noble Faramir in Lord of the Rings, I was totally unprepared for him in this role. What a versatile actor. As Carl he is just adorable.

Now, if you are an unhappy or frustrated critic, this is the movie to go to as you can see by some of the other viewer's comments. Apparently, there are all sorts of things to pick apart and run down in the movie. You'll have a blast making your own list.

I recommend that you go to have fun, it is a kick! I would see it again and I'll happily go to the sequel or prequel.

title: Kick It, Hugh
review: Hugh Jackman seems to be going for as many franchises as possible.. which, all things considered, is fine by me. He's fun to watch, and probably the number one reason I even went to see "Van Helsing". Number two reason was, after I read the original "Dracula" I found out that Van Helsing was a great character. The movie Van Helsing, while still a worthy character, needed a lot more development and depth than the screenwriter and director went for. Coherent dialogue would have helped.  The writing was pretty bad all through, and the accents were *terrible*, especially Anna's. Richard Roxburgh was entertaining but not particularly scary... actually, nothing in this movie was very scary. David Wenham has definitely crossed wide rivers since his stony, slightly boring Faramir in the LOTR movies, and ended up being my favourite thing about this whole debacle. The special effects only succeeded about half the time, but some of them were quite impressive--- such as the shimmery air around the vampires as they flew, and the light shooting out of Dracula's townhouse after the ball. My one really big problem with this movie, though, was the fact that it didn't *really* star Hugh Jackman. It starred his microphone. I've never seen so much microphone before in any movie, and it took an awful lot away from scenes that had a hard enough time as it was anyway. I don't really want to complain. This was just a summer movie, and summer movies are never great. They could have put a lot more into it, though... oh well. Maybe for the sequel.

title: "...I'm just a friar; I can curse all i want...damnit."
review:
Just saw it tonight.. and you don't get much more than you'd expect. Which is good in most ways. Hugh Jackman is perfect for the role.

The bads: some of the accents are terribly overdone and/or way out of place. They changed the dracula story slightly (not on the original Vlad the Impaler, at least not quite... the guys name was Vlad, though) The dialog from the "brides" was mostly TERRIBLE. But hey, they're she-devils, so what... I could be (more of?) an obsessive critic and take the point of watching a movie out films, but I won't. I only mention those cons because they really got my attention. Others may not mind the accents...

The rest, even the excessive swinging from ropes, (plenty of "yeah right!" but big deal... the whole "Dracula/Frankenstein/Wolfman plot is a whole bit of that, isn't it? ..so no use complaining) was good fun. A good mix between Indiana Jones and the classic supernaturals, as well as some humour. At first when I saw that werewolves and Dr. Frankenstein were going to be in this I groaned, but they were written into the plot fairly well.

Overall... a B+.

title: A solid and fun monster hunting movie to usher in the summer season
review:
I did myself a great disservice by reading many of the negative newspaper reviews of the movie Van Helsing, because I couldn't watch the first twenty minutes without noticing the supposed flaws of the flick. However, that passed and I was able to enjoy the 2 hour-10 minute film (2 hours and 23 minutes if you can't the end credits). Let me say that the critics are being unnecessarily harsh on Stephen Sommers and Van Helsing. It is not an Oscar-worthy that will be remembered by the AFI thirty years from now, but it is a film that will take you out mind.

The plot is a very simple, but not so simple as to offend your intellect. Hugh Jackman (of the X-men movies and the Tony-nominated musical "The Boy from Oz") plays Gabriel Van Helsing, a monster hunter for a secret sect of the Catholic Church. From what we see of the sect's headquarters, it isn't only the Catholics who are employing Van Helsing to save the souls of those possessed by evil. It is in these secret headquarters hidden in the Vatican City that the audience learns that the Church rescued a broken and amnesiac Van Helsing several years ago, and it is through his monster hunting/soul saving that he will recall his forgotten past. (POSSIBLE SPOLIER HERE!) We also learn here that his past goes as far back as 800 years from the present 1888 of the movie.

Van Helsing is then sent to Romania to help a gypsy princess, played with butt-kicking and back-flipping furor by Kate Beckinsale, defeat Count Dracula. Kate Beckinsale's Anna Valerious is the last one in the family who is cursed to eternal damnation unless Count Dracula is killed by them. Dracula and his three vampire brides have it out for the Valerious clan, and the reason why is a surprise. During their mission to find and destroy Dracula, as well as his undead children that he is trying to bring to life with the help of Dr. Frankenstein's technology, Anna and Van Helsing fight vampires, the werewolf, an angry crowd, and Frankenstein's monster before befriending him.

Like "The Mummy," director Stephen Sommers does not allow his heroes to have a healthy fear of their enemies. They have too much of a jaded, 21st Century attitude. If the characters aren't even a bit afraid, how is the audience supposed have a suspension of disbelief? Aside from this flaw and the obvious set up for sequel through several of Dracula's allusions to Van Helsing's past, this is a solid and fun summer movie. It is to his credit, that Sommers doesn't make the movie as serious or as dark as other vampire films of recent history (like "Interview with the Vampire," "Bram Stokers' Dracula," and "Underworld"). Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale play the swashbuckling roles with the right balance, and Shuler Hensley's Frankenstein's monster gives the movie a soul. In helping to keep the film light, Richard Roxburgh does an excellent job of camping up Dracula but not to the point where he can't be perceived as a formidable foe. The movie is not as overblown, bloated, or as weighed down by special effects as the critics would have you believe. Aside from the CGI that makes the simplest human movement appear as supernatural and too perfect, the movie makes good use of its stunts and F/X budget. This movie is a way to usher in the lazy, hazy days of summer. Just pray they don't do a sequel.

title: Jon Monsarrat review: Good acting, silly action
review:
I love action films and I don't need a lot of drama -- Jackie Chan and Arnold Schwartzenegger are fine. But I like the action to be clever, with some plot twists and powerful tension. Not in this film. Van Helsing has some strong acting by Hugh Jackman and Richard Roxburgh, but it's just tremendously silly. Sort of like "The Mummy", where someone shouts "Place the amulet into the magic box and make the secret cross and spinkle some sand over the tomb quick before the pharaoh ghost of the hell people blinks twice before midnight!" Yadda yadda yadda.

A lot of films get caught up in this trap. Rather than making a dramatic impact with a rich personal story (something that Hellboy attempts, but fails)... they try to shock us with a lot of monsters. But there are so many of them and different types and exceptions and silver crosses work on some but not others... it all melts down into so much uninteresting bother. Where's the dramatic tension if the plot is too silly to be believed?

There is a touch of bona fide action in the movie but a lot of it is hammed up as well. You know, conveniently placed ropes for swinging. There is a lot of swinging in the film. Apparently if you grab someone at the end of a 10 story fall the instant deceleration doesn't kill them. Huh. What do you know.

I did feel the visual flying effects worked better than Spiderman (which just left me dizzy and disoriented). Kate Beckinsale isn't given much of a role, and she does nothing with it. I didn't see any chemistry, romantic or otherwise.

Who should see this film:

-- Hugh Jackson fans, but only on a rainy day.

-- Tall guys whose heads blink but they're really good, not evil

I nearly gave Van Helsing a 5 out of 10 but those silly Eastern European accents... argh... I'm giving it a 4.

title: Evil without reflection
review:
We all know that Dracula, or any vampire, cannot be seen in a mirror. "Van Helsing" is the same. It is evil without reflection. At least Dracula has the excuse of being undead. "Van Helsing" is far worse. It is brain-dead.

The film never pretends to be anything other than park-your-mind-at-the-door entertainment, in the tradition of fast-paced, car-chase-filled, action-adventure flicks. Given its subject matter, "Van Helsing" could and should have tried to be something more. Its failure to rise above the abysmal is an abdication of moral responsibility.

The film offers the semblance of evil without examining its nature or reality. It trots out all the classic ghouls - vampires, werewolves, Jekyll and Hyde, Dr. Frankenstein and his monster - without stopping to consider what makes them such powerful archetypes, or why they are deemed the embodiment of evil.

Even a cursory examination would have revealed the answer. All of them are unnatural exaggerations of an aspect of human nature. Both Dracula and Dr. Frankenstein represent people's wish to "be as gods" - to quote Genesis - to be immortal or to unlock the secret to life. (Van Helsing himself seems to live forever. He remembers fighting Romans at Masada in 73 AD.) Hyde and the werewolf, on the other hand, show us at our worst, when we allow ourselves to be dominated by our animal instincts.

Frankenstein's monster holds out a ray of hope as the one creature that is non-human yet not inhuman. Van Helsing says he cannot kill Frankenstein's monster because, although it may be the fruit of evil, it is not ruled by evil.

Apart from this one bright spot, however, the film's moral vision (if you can call it that) is chilling indeed. Ultimately, "Van Helsing" suggests that evil must be defeated and destroyed by evil itself. The film offers no choice between good and evil. It allows us only to choose the lesser of two evils.

The film uses the props of Christian theology without its underpinnings. Churches become mere architectural splendors, not holy but hollow. No divine worship takes place beneath their vaults. God and the devil are mentioned in passing, but neither has any real presence. (I use the term deliberately.) Reference is made to sin and salvation - but they are merely meaningless buzzwords. Holy water and the crucifix no longer vanquish evil.

At no time in the proceedings does "Van Helsing" ever manage to be scary. The only truly frightening thing about the film is that, as the saying goes, it "sees no evil". If this is any indication of how far our society has lost its moral compass, then we must indeed "be afraid - be very afraid".

title: Oh Dear
review: What was easily one of my most eagerly awaited films to see at the cinema, this poor excuse for a blockbuster came as a huge disapointment. It's all CGI nonsense with no thrill at all. Jackman is ok but Van Helsing has little to do except point gadgets in the right direction, so comes across as a poor man's Batman. Kate Beckinsale is good in a thankless role. CGI Monsters are pathetic Mr Hyde is a cross between a giant leprechaun and that fat character from Austin Powers. As for Dracula he sounded like Steve Coogans Tony Ferrino character, i would go on record as saying this is the worst Dracula i have ever seen, a pathetic performance. The Werewolf and Frankensteins monster are given nothing to do after a bright beginning that could of done with being in colour. I Loved Deep Rising, I loved The Mummy. I did'nt enjoy The Mummy Returns and this is actually worse. And for it's big budget, it was only a 1.85 ratio movie. Abbott and Costello meet Frankenstein had a better plot decent laughs and more scares, watch that instead. If you must watch this wait for the dvd. Hopefully the directors commentary will feature him saying sorry for this mess. 4 out of 10,boy am i generous.

title: Good, fun summer blockbuster
review: I am really quite surprised how many IMDB users disliked Van Helsing. I really enjoyed it, ok it really is daft but I never expected anything less than what I got. Firstly I'm not a huge fan of CGI and to be honest I was getting rather tired of it but Van Helsing looks absolutely stunning. I loved the design of the whole film, the sets and landscapes were amazing. Also the special effects were fabulous. Hugh Jackman could have done with been given a little depth to his character but he was great as Van Helsing as was his sidekick who was very funny in his role as the Friar. I'm not so sure about Kate Beckinsales acting ability but she looks absolutely beautiful anyway. I did find the actor portraying Count Dracula a little OTT even for this film though!, Frankensteins Monster was better represented in the acting stakes. I'm no expert on the old Universal monster movies being Scottish I was brought up on the Hammer Horror films with the likes of Peter Cushing and Christopher Lee and have always loved a good horror film. Thats why I give Van Helsing a huge thumbs up but still hope for a better plot and storyline if there is a sequel but i can't fault the superb special effects and acton sequences. Great popcorn flick ***7/10***

title: BORING
review:
I wanted to watch the movie although I had heard a lot of bad things about the film. Unfortunately all those things are true.

The opening sequence (shot in black and white) is quite okay, but after that it gets worse. When in the beginning of the movie Van Helsing fights some Hulk-like monster I was already bored and thought "just kill it and let's get over with", but unfortunately the fight lasts quite a while. I could not at all relate with the characters, neither with Van Helsing nor with Anna Valerious, even Count Dracula remains bland and uninteresting. Besides you don't learn anything about their motivation. Also the fact that Van Helsing mostly fights CGI-beings and does not get even a scratch during those fights does not exactly further the tension. In addition the movie is quite foreseeable. And Carl as Van Helsing's sidekick/comic relief is not funny at all and the one liners the characters get to speak are just stupid. The only reason I didn't leave the cinema before the end of the movie was that I was curious about the final fight between Count Dracula and Van Helsing, but even that fight was not worth the wait.

The acting was okay I think, but I had the impression that in a bad movie even decent actors look bad.

The CGI was way too much, human adversaries might have been much more interesting to watch, so it was more like style over substance. Maybe they should have saved the money they spent on the CGI and invested it in a decent script instead.

title: Cartoon characters
review: I knew there was a good chance this movie would be disappointing, but being a fan of the vampire genre I had to check it out. On the good side:  Stylish sets, some good music, a somewhat interesting Frankenstein monster (we've seen this interpretation before, but still OK), pretty good werewolves.  On the bad side:  idiotic dialogue, uninteresting main characters, music often too loud and intrusive, CGI way overused (it has a long way to go before it replaces a good makeup job), terrible Dracula character (kind of a discount Gary Oldman), and ludicrous situations (even for a monster mash movie like this).  The worst thing about the movie is that the main characters (Van Helsing and Anna) are just as cartoonish as the CGI characters.  How many times can we watch them be smashed through walls or fall hundreds of feet and just get up and brush themselves off, before we stop taking them seriously?    I guess I got my money's worth, but I could easily have lived without it.

title: Not Even Good Enough For Popcorn
review:
I assure you I am capable or recognizing a "summer popcorn movie" and am not the type of person who goes into one expecting award-calibur material so you can cease and desist.

Van Helsing was not even good on a "summer popcorn movie" level. The plot was hopelessly convoluted (the "rules" as to how one does or does not become a "real" werewolf were particularly ridiculous) with holes large enough to drive a Mack truck through (why exactly does Dracula need to create an offspring army when there are obviously plenty of vampires hanging about? Enough for a yearly ball even!). The special effects, while impressive, were so hyperkinetic I feared suffering sensory overload or perhaps even a seizure. The actors who spoke with a "Transylvanian" accent were practically unintelligible. And to top it all off a completely unneccessary and ultimately pointless romantic sub-plot. These are but a few of the things that make this movie sub-popcorn fodder. Thankfully there are others this season with plenty of popcorn potential. "Day After Tomorrow" perhaps?

title: I've seen worse films, just not in a while
review:
It's excruciating to watch three very talented actors (Hugh Jackman, David Wenham, and Richard Roxbury) perform in a film lacking such essential substance, character and plot development, and that has more special effects than acting in it. Basically, the movie is poorly plotted dross the like of which has not been seen since The League of Extraordinary Gentleman. Why did they bother hiring decent actors for this slop when they could have made the same film (with even more crap special effects) without wasting the talents of people who could (and yet didn't) act?

So don't watch this for a plot or even just an adventure story. Watch it because you like the actors, though a couple of the performances are wince worthy, or because you like special effects.

If I had paid for the movie ticket, I would want my money back. Rent it when it comes out (maybe), but don't waste time seeing it in the theater.

title: Didn't really Expect to see an Oscar Winner.
review:
When I paid my 6 bucks at the Ticket Window I was not really expecting to see an Oscar winner, and that is exactly what I got. What I got was an adventure movie that was not really all that bad and had enough to keep me entertained for the two hours.

I have been watching Frankenstine, Dracula, and Wolfman movies since I was a little kid. I did enjoy the movie even if it was Cheesy and at times Lame but then Half way through the movie I decided to just have fun and realise that You can't really take things too serious when Frankenstine Monster can quote The Holy Bible and is the smartest one in the Group.

It was fun though Grab a Big Bucket of Popcorn, A Tall Cold Soda sit back and enjoy the Movie.

title: Fun...but the CGI was way too cartoonish....
review:
I just saw the movie yesterday afternoon. It was an entertaining movie, good acting by the cast, good script, but my only problem was the CGI. The CGI looked too fake and unrealistic to me, in other words, the CGI looked way to cartoonish. But of course, you know the typical Stephen Sommers when it comes to CGI. Don't get me wrong, Sommers did a great job with CGI in the two "Mummy" sequels but when he did CGI in "Van Halsing", it all fell flat and dull.

"Van Helsing" wasn't the best summer action movie ever made but it sure was entertaining. The acting of Hugh Jackman, Kate Beckinsale and Richard Roxburgh were the best part of the film. Richard Roxburgh made a great Dracula. I also loved Dracula's female vampires.

It's just that the Frankenstein and Wolfman both looked too cartoonish. I just think this film would have been much better if the Wolfman, Dracula, and Frankenstein were done for real, not CGI. But of course, I can understand why Sommers would want the movie to look cartoonish with CGI, he simply wanted this to be a family film. Popcorn action entertainment for the entire family to enjoy. I would give this movie a score of: 7/10

title: Aggressively Average
review:
No need to recount the plot here. No need to go over the plot holes, leaps of logic, and general shoddiness of narrative. I wanted to like this film. There are still parts that are fun and inventive (Dracula walking along walls and ceiling, nice touch), but the stupidity of the characters grows wearying, after a while.

Too, the "homages" to other films begin to smack of creative desperation. Not just the obvious rifts and lifts from the classic monster flicks, but the variations on Stagecoach, Alien, and James Bond simply distract.

Sommers has done great work with CGI in the past, but it still looks like CGI. So when Hugh Jackman is doing the famous Yakima Cannutt leap from horse to horse (first seen in StageCoach), the fact it is obviously the CGI Jackman robs the scene of any tension or drama.

Tip to aspiring filmmakers: Just because you can do something (hurl millions of dollars of CPU processing at the screen, for example), doesn't mean you should.

title: Hugh does the monster mash.
review:
Hugh Jackman is rapidly becoming this decades Harrison Ford. He seems to get tagged for the all the big budget action parts that require someone who has rugged good looks and appears between the age of 30-40. Much the way Ford was typecast in the late 70s and 80s.

Previously, he hit the nail on the head with his protrayal of wolverine of X-men fame. And in Van Helsing he does a credible job despite being surrounded with basic ineptitude.

In Van Helsing Jackman is basically playing vampire hunter D....look and all....tracking down a monster mash of classic movie creatures circa universal 1930. This time around the beasts are given the modern day CGI treatment. Most come across as cartoonish or rubbery.

The acting....minus Jackman is mostly a miss. His wasp waisted co star Kate Beckensale is as fetching an actress as hollywood has to offer. And her gypsy warrior look is to die for. But brother.....her performance here is for nothing. Her alleged central european accent is a source of constant annoyance. She spends most of the film performing impossible aerial and gymnastic feats or being being slapped around by one of Dracula's albino brides.

The plot itself concerns Dracula.....who is far from frightening or seductive here.....trying to bring the fruits of 400 years of passion to life....while Van Helsing and company seek stop him. In the process various scenes from old horror movies are paid dubious homage.

Vampires appearing when the sun dips behind a cloud as seen in "Kiss of the Vampire". The classic ballroom dance of the living dead from "The fearless Vampire Killers" is shown here as well. We even have the Frankenstien 'It's alive' comments and the famed windmill final from the original frankenstien.

But Van Helsing does have a some moments. The village attack early on by Dracula brides is impressive. And the werewolves represented in the film are top notch of the film. But for the most part Van Helsing fails to live up to the hype. At times only Jackman stands between it and total failure. Showing that even in a overhyped large budget film....Jackman can stand out.

title: By far the worst......
review: This is by far one of the worst movies I have ever seen! I thought the movie Blade was bad but this had that movie beat. It was so boring that I had to fight to stay awake, and parts were so cheesy that I spent most of the time rolling my eyes and trying not to gag. The movie left much to be desired. The acting in it was mediocre. And the accents were irritating. The plot of the movie itself needed work, though it would be spoiling it for those who haven't seen it for me to say exactly why. The only good thing about this film was its special effects, but its uses in the action sequences will just have you asking yourself why was it wasted. But for anyone who feels that they just have to watch it, I suggest that you wait for it to come on TV, as it would be a waste of money otherwise. All of you Hugh Jackman fans are bound to be very disappointed.

title: Oh lighten up people!
review:
If you often find yourself referring to a movie as a "Film," then steer clear of this movie, because you are too stuck up and elitist to enjoy a good butt kicking hero movie.

The music rocks, the scenery rocks, the heroes rock, and the villans rock. (and the gadgets rock too)

The funny thing is, the more victorian literature you know, the funnier (and cooler) this movie gets. Expect to see all your favorite villains up against the hero! I laughed my arse off when I saw Mr. Hyde!

"Serious Film" Buffs, get over yourselves already. Movies aren't made for you, why don't you just go wet yourselves over Mulholland Drive or American Beauty.

title: Good Movie If You Keep Your Expectations In Line
review: First off, if you go to this movie thinking you are going to see a classic you are wrong. But with that said, this movie was enjoyable, even with all the CGI (the Jekyll and Hyde CGI was the worst). Hugh Jackman does a good job as the title character, Kate Beckingsale is obviously gorgeous and adds some very welcome aspects. What I really like about this movie is the fact that all of the monster's stories are woven together in a way I have never seen before. Even though some people here say there is no character development, there is some. There are some things I could have done without, especially in the last 10 minutes or so but I won't spoil it for anybody here. I suggest that anyone who wants to see a decent move that is pure escapism - go see this. One last note, I have NEVER agreed with Roger Ebert but I love that he gave this movie a thumbs up.

title: WOW!!
review:
POSSIBLE SPOILERS

I walked out of this film amazed. This is pure genius. All the special effects, hunky Hugh Jackman....everything is worth the $6.50 I paid to see it.

What I do not like about the film is Kate Beckinsdale's gothic-esque bodice that she wore during the entire film. That could've been scrapped...it looks disgusting.

Another good thing about the film is that there are no sex scenes in it. While there are a few sexual references and some sensuality in the film, there isn't anyone doing the actual deed, which is a good thing since sex scenes make me very uncomfortable.

The guy playing Dracula looks a lot like Alan Cumming, however, he isn't Alan Cumming. Just my thoughts.

3.5 out of 5 stars

title: Hollywood tries to cheat and pack in the familiar faces
review:
If there was any truth to the notion that Hollywood has run out of new ideas and even less unique characters, one has to look no further than the recent crop of box office fodder we have been fed over the past few years.

In efforts to rip our hard earned dollar from our pockets with once proven yet stale characters, the cinema has tried a new approach of coupling these faded franchises into the same story. One only needs look at Freddy vs. Jason, Aliens vs. Predator or even the notably bland League of Extraordinary Gentlemen to see the newest trend of familiar characters against a common enemy.

The recent attempt at this warfare tactic is the biggest and boldest risk yet in Universal Studio's Van Helsing. With adds swarming about a one man's crusade against the Wolfman, Dracula and Frankenstein it's a way of almost tricking the audience into thinking they are getting three movies for the price of one. Add Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde who makes a rather large cameo early on in the film and you have seasons one through four of the X-Files minus any alien abductions.

For those of you who may not be aware of this almost a quarter of a billion dollar adventure (this number includes the lucrative advertising budget and sequel rights), Hugh Jackman (Wolverine in the X-Men franchise) plays the title character who is commissioned by the church to rid the world of the evil creatures it harbors. After a memorable chase with Mr. Hyde, Van Helsing is dispatched to Eastern Europe to stop Dracula and his gang of monsters from channeling the efforts of Dr. Frankenstein and bringing to life the dead offspring of the Count and his wives.

Conceding that this is not enough to propel a blockbuster film, we also are introduced to the lovely Kate Beckinsale (who no doubt was still wearing the same wire harness she perfected in last years Underworld) as Anna Valerious, the last in a line of hereditary challenges for the Dracula family. Van Helsing's role is then quite clear, he must save the Valerious family and set them free from purgatory, foil the plans of the count, hide his decision to save the Frankenstein monster from his superiors while trying to race against time and find not only the answers to his own legacy but also to inject himself with a cure for the Wolfman curse to which he has been infected. Whew!

You would think that with all this going on, all these familiar evil characters that we grew up on with Saturday afternoon matinees, that we would be in for a roller coaster ride of the can't fail variety.

If you thought as did I, you are in for a disappointment.

As a critic, it is always easier to pick out the bad in films, so let me start there. Even though writer/director Stephen Sommers has given Universal an incredibly lucrative franchise in The Mummy (followed by The Mummy Returns and The Scorpion King, the three combined for nearly $850 million at the worldwide box office), he has never been one much for character development. A master of the special effects and CGI action, I would expect that when storyboarded, this film must have looked incredibly fun with the studio licking its chops at the theme park possibilities. However, when put on the big screen, the characters were all bland. Dracula was never frightening, Frankenstein was a wimp (granted if you read the book, it stays true to his good nature), and only the Wolfman offers any kind of real peril.

With the supporting cast as backdrops, the hopes would be that the leading crew of Jackman and Beckinsale would rise to the occasion, but together they offer not one ounce of chemistry and although human fighting the supernatural they seem to be able to fall from incredible distances or get thrown into walls without as much as an Advil for back pain. If these characters don't seem to falter after being manhandled by creatures ten times their strength, then where is the adventures? Where is the sense of urgency?

Granted, I am not blaming the two leads for this mess. They really didn't have anything to work with. The whole cast are forced to not show smiles while uttering such as `I don't know if you've looked in the mirror lately, but you kind of stick out in a crowd' (said to Frankenstein) or `Too bad, so sad' as orated to Van Helsing to by one of the Counts evil brides. Even when they are trying to be funny, they don't seem to hit on any consistent cylinders. It actually reminded me of The Mummy Returns in 2001 when I witnessed what I still profess today to be the only movie that has over 50 attempts at humour and does not hit one note. Van Helsing is just as bad. When a friar walks into a room just vacated by the Wolfman, he asks rhetorically, `What smells like wet dog in here?' and when Igor is asked why he tortures the Wolfman he says, `It's what I do' in a very annoying accent. When these and countless other expected catchphrases were thrust upon the audience, I swear, you would hear crickets in the background where the director paused in the action expecting laughter.

To give the film its chops, I will say that the production values and the special effects are top rate. In fact, that is the only reason why the film will be a success and not end up on cable as quick as LXG. The Wolfman was evolved to a point where watching even An American Werewolf in London might now finally seem dated. And it was more 21st century to see Dracula turn into a six-foot bat instead of a flying rodent that we were used to in the old Bela Legosi films.

This movie is however critic proof. Fans of the genre have been awaiting it with bated breath and the 2004 summer film fleet is now aligned and firing with this early entry. It is just too bad that they couldn't have done more or in looked at previous attempts and done less. If Daredevil and Electra fighting Bullseye and The Kingpin were a benchmark, Universal should have taken a page from this lesson to learn that more sometimes isn't always better.

All this said, I am developing a script for Pee Wee Herman vs. the Star Wars Jawa's that I hope you buy into next year.

title: Great Entertainment
review:
Okay, So you won't leave this movie feeling enlightened or emotionally effected....so what? Not EVERY movie needs to be an intellectually moving experience. Sometimes you just need some cool, exciting fun. And that's what Van Helsing offers. Enjoyment. I really liked this movie, and as far as action movies go, this is one of the best I've seen in a while. The cast was pretty good, and I have a biased love for David Wenham, who plays the funny, genius, sidekick Carl, because of his role in Lord of the Rings. He was very good, as was Hugh Jackman. It was action packed, and interesting and no yawns were involved! If you're one of those crazily critical people, you'll be able to find flaws in this, although I couldn't, but if you go in with the mindset of being entertained, not moved, you'll embrace this movie happily.

8/10

title: Cartoon fun
review: Ridiculous stunts that defy the laws of physics and a simple one-dimensional screenplay drag this down. The action sequences could have been trimmed a bit, but it is surprising how well the single plot-line with short, go-nowhere subplots keeps its momentum. The atmospherics of the movie are good -- think Sleepy Hollow meets Two Towers. Jackman plays a very Wolverine like character. So most of this is a derivative hodge-podge of cliched eye-candy from other better sci-fi, fantasy and suspense films -- Matrix, Alien, X-men, Batman, James Bond, etc. Even Silvestri's Gothic-Wagnerian score sounds familiar from other movies. Nevertheless, it is fun to watch Jackman tackle various monsters. His female sidekick does an adequate job, but plays up arrogance and vulnerability and downplays the sort of intensity that the character needed, more in the direction of Linda Hamilton in T2, Sigourney Weaver in Alien(s).

title: Hypnotic Entertainment
review: This has to be one of the most entertaining films I have seen in a long time and I can't understand why it is being critically ripped to shreds. I was so engrossed in this film that I forgot about where I was and what I was doing. I was constantly captured by climax after thrilling climax!! The storyline was slightly vague, but it really didn't matter, as the stunning effects and fight sequences are a please to any movie-goer. This film was really created for pure escapism, a chance to exit reality, and it does this perfectly. It exceeded all expectations I had of the film (before I saw it, I thought that it was going to be distinctly average)and it has the hypnotic ability to grasp the audiences attention in practically every scene. It keeps at a constant mind-blowing pace throughout it's 2hr duration. This has been crafted to perfection. I am thoroughly impressed.

title: Waste of Life
review:
Seriously, I have never heard a more collective groan from an audience in a good while. Aside from the design and look of Van Helsing, this hole has nothing going for it. Boring, unintentionally funny, the cheesiness, all of those little words that say, "I'm garbage," this turkey has them all. Please for the love of your intelligence and sanity, do not watch this.

Superhero Van Helsing is sent by secret priesthood in Rome to dispatch Dracula, who has plans to give life to his ugly offspring.

One big mistake on the box is they forget to mention ages 6-14 only. Second big mistake was the awful CGI. The entire movie was collective garbage sadly and Jackman and Beckinsale (whose optical illusion/corset outfit will appeal to teens), deserve better. And so does the audience. The 'Big Three' do not deliver here. The Brides are a waste of screen time sadly. This movie sucked.

COMPLETE SPOILER: If Anna never saw the sea, the least you could have done to ease the audience is to let her see it or bury her in it! This further buried Van Helsing.

title: Save your dough......
review:
1) Somers seemed confused as to whether he wanted serious or campy. Within the first minute I found myself singing "Puttin on the Ritz" ala Young Frankenstein.

2) Kate Beckinsale and Richard Roxburgh both OVER-ACTED their little hearts out. C'mon guys, you weren't doing Hamlet.

3) Dracula's brides........like nails on a chalk board.

4) The story itself? More holes than a dozen donuts.

There was some beautiful cinematography and I got a great scare when Van Helsing was initially confronted by Mr. Hyde but other than that, it's difficult to find anything positive to say about this flick.

title: Best movie of the year so far!
review:
I had to comment on this movie because it is the most awesome movie I have seen all year so far! I was not expecting it to be this good! I was expecting it to be something like "The League of Extraordinary Gentleman", but it FAR surpassed my expectations!

The characters fit their parts perfectly. The acting was pretty good, the special effects were AMAZING and done extremely well, and the whole look of the film was just magnificant. It's definitely worth every penny I paid to see it.

I don't see how anyone could be disappointed with a film this spectacular! I'll definitely buy it when it becomes available!

title: An enjoyable fun packed movie
review:
There is often too much written into why a film is like it is, and this is something that seems to be happening with Van Helsing.

Van Helsing is everything it promises to deliver. It has action, good special effects, the plot flows well and above it is fun to watch. You know that Dr Gabriel Van Helsing will prevail and Count Dracula will lose. So why read more into it than that. The film is a spectacle that will lose some of its impact going to DVD, but the over all experience will still be enjoyable. The charters are not one dimensional, the good ensemble cast brings colour to the characters, that they obviously had fun playing which in turn makes the film even more enjoyable.

I left the cinema after having enjoyed a film that I had been looking forward to since I'd heard of its production (so many moths ago). I would willingly have walked back into the foyer brought another ticket and watch it all over again. I would be happy to say that it would lose nothing on a second sitting.

It is a good start to a string of exciting looking summer blockbuster.

title: No plot, bad acting, even worse dialogue
review: I was disappointed in the movie. It has such great potential but fell very short of that. The dialogue was so bad that at certain points it was too cheesy to sit through. There was little to no logical connection between the characters. The brides of Dracula were so under developed that it would have been more effective to not have them speak. The claim was that this movie would be like Indiana Jones, but the only similarity was the hat Jackman wore. Beckinsale relied way to much on her looks and didn't bother to bring any real acting to the movie, which is a shame because I enjoyed her in Underworld. Other then that it was a bad attempt at what could have been a good movie. I wish I could go back and retrieve the two hours of my life that were wasted in that theater.

title: It Ain't Just the Vampires That Suck...
review:
Van Helsing is not a great movie, I'm afraid. It's not even a good one. It's vaguely significant in that it's the first time since "Abbott and Costello Meet Frankenstein" came out (that'd be in 1948) that Dracula, Frankenstein's monster and the Wolfman have appeared in the same film. Too bad it was this one.

Hugh Jackman (who was a lot more entertaining as Wolverine in the X-Men movies) stumbles and lurches through this mish-mash of well-meaning special effects sequences to no clear end. The story is muddy--it seems as if they must have had more script than film, and had to do the best they could with the resources available--and where it seems to proceed along some sort of coherent line, which it does for moments at a time, the directions it takes leave you scratching your head.

Jackman is Gabriel Van Helsing, apparently no particular relation to the Abraham of Dracula fame, who gets sent hither and yon by some secret gang within the Roman Catholic Church (a concept which makes its appearance in a single scene and then vanishes, never to be heard from again--there's a lot of that sort of thing in this film) to retrieve or kill various supernatural baddies. Presumably as a result of these activities, Van Helsing is himself a wanted man, a fact made clear in the opening sequence of the movie and, likewise, never referred to for the entirety of the remainder of the picture.

In an early sequence, he does battle with Mr. Hyde (who comes off a little, but not a lot, better than he did in League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, a film which seems to have presaged many of the flaws of Van Helsing) and then gets sent off to Transylvania to deal with Dracula himself, who's planning (I think) to take over the world with thousands of bat-like "offspring". The little batlings are lying dormant in globby cocoons reminiscent of the wad of goo that Natasha Henstridge burst out of in Species, but aren't quite alive, or undead, or something: they need to be zapped with electricity run through Frankenstein's monster--juicing 'em through a werewolf is suboptimal--in order to enable them to flap around without their exploding into gobbets of green goo, a fact which has Dracula's three wives extremely depressed.

In an early sequence that's probably as good as this movie gets, Van Helsing dispatches one of the harpy-like wives with a Gatling crossbow provided by his assistant, the Friar ("I'm not actually a monk...") Carl, who acts more-or-less as Q to Van Helsing's James Bond. The special effects here are okay, but as CGI-heavy as any of Sommers' previous films. And like The Mummy and The Mummy Returns, the production values overall are quite good--sets, costumes, make-up are all great. Not put to any especially worthwhile use, but good eye-candy, for the most part.

Speaking of eye-candy, Kate Beckinsale plays the local princess whose family has sworn to destroy the vampire, and who apparently devote themselves to werewolf-baiting in the meantime.

If all of this sounds disjointed and silly, it's only because it is. The script is a knot of non-sequiturs, dead-ends and pointless excursions, and Sommers--who has a pretty good eye, but not much of a sense of what makes sense, it seems--does, I suppose, the best he can with it. He'd be in a decent position to blame this morass on the writer, except for one thing: he is the writer.

Do I sound disappointed? Well, I got to see a couple of good trailers.

Of course, that's what I said about this one. If you've been wanting to see this, see The Mummy instead: it's funnier, tighter and better directed by a big margin. Wait for this to come out on DVD. Then wait some more.

title: Stephen Sommers Stop Threatening With Another Movie
review:
Whoever pays the Sommers budgets is definitely even a bigger idiot than Sommers himself. The director who wants to become the new Spielberg and makes not-scary horror movies with Saturday-morning-cartoons effects must stop. I mean enough is enough.

They couldn't even make the theatrical trailer look good. Someone should explain to Sommers that computer technology has not yet come to the point where it can produce a whole movie of cgi. By the way, someone should explain that to George Lucas as well.

Stephen Sommers should check out 'Underworld' to find out how men in suits, still look a lot better than cgi. You know, make-up has improved a lot over the years too. We are at the point where we have to combine techniques to create realistic effects.

Enough.

0/10

title: Van Helsing is to Epics what the Ford Pinto is to classic cars.
review:
Van Helsing is just one more example of how "money does not a movie make." Whatever happened to good plots, performances and dialogue?

Lot's of CGI, lot's of color correction and retouching... but whatever happened to substance?

The acting is weak and by association so is the directing , or vice versa.

The dialogue is simple and predictable, lacking wit or charm.

The music-video-editing style may have worked in "Run Lola Run" or other highly artistic and creative projects but fails miserably in this epic wannabe. This movie is simply a lame replica of a video game. Universal must have thought that investing in a huge budget flick with no essence would be enough to satisfy today's audiences. How insulting!

Its one saving grace? The photography. Allen Daviau, as usual, delivers.

title: A great spectacle; didn't take itself too seriously.
review:
This film is getting slammed a lot but I really liked it. True, the production values were over the top: the music was a bit heavy-handed, the special effects were, at times, overly cartoon- y compared to the live action stuff (Dr. Jeckyll is an example)--also, maybe at 34 I'm showing a generational lack of CGA sensibilities but I would have found the special effects more interesting if they hadn't moved so quickly I couldn't actually see them. That was a bit irritating.

On the positive side the settings and costumes (not to mention the actors) were quite intriguing eye candy that pleasantly drew me in. The animation of Dracula's Brides was really lovely, as were many of the CGA landscapes. The movie didn't take itself seriously so I didn't feel the fact that it's just an entertaining diversion (and not a FILM) was particularly burdensome. It entertained me in a way older movies often do--the spectacle, watching more as an audience member than being completely sucked in. I also thought the ending was appropriate and really appreciated it (except for the cheese factor at the very end). I found this movie to be a thoroughly entertaining afternoon and nothing more.

title: Disappointed
review: Someone tell me what this has to do with Van Helsing?? As in, Professor Abraham Van Helsing, the character from Bram Stoker's Dracula? Since when is Van Helsing the angel Gabriel? And since when does Van Helsing cavort with gypsy princesses?? The writer of this movie perhaps failed to read the books from which he pulled several of these characters, or else just decided to butcher them without regard.  This film made the same mistake as League of Unimpressive Actors (what I like to call that other movie...) in portraying Edward Hyde as a big ugly gorilla man in a top hat. Read the book, please, and try and stay true to it! And Dracula's offspring... Did someone feed the gremlins after midnight??? Did the wicked witch of the west let her monkies loose again??? I DO have something positive to say about this movie... Frankenstein's monster was portrayed wonderfully and respectfully to Mary Shelley's book.  The werewolves were good and scary (they actually gave me nightmares, so kudos!) and the special effects were very well done.

title: I'd really like to punch Steven Sommers!
review:
How many production errors can you have in one movie? One second he's got dripping, saturated hair.. the next it's puffy and drying! She kisses Dracula with her really glossy red lips and not one spec of the gloss is left on him! Dracula asks the guy whose family was murdered by him to join him, and all he says is "I'd rather die and than join you!" talk about stating the obvious! The guy sees his fathers dead-for-a-year-or-more corpse and all he says is "NOOOOO!!!" no crying or anything... but then again.. he's been dead FOR A YEAR!!

Suffice to say, that's the worst movie Hugh Jackman has ever done. Main role or not, that's a big bad chunk out of his popularity meter.

title: It is awful!
review: Poor film with awful screenplay and unsuitable vampires. Can't recommend it - only if you wanna have crazy night full of laughter:) Full moon through all the film Vampires fly at day light! They can't have any children. Dracula is very funny man. Saint Gabriel - it is TOO much for me! This film made from another ones - I saw scenes from Pirates of the Caribbean, Master and commander:far side of the world, Harry Potter and Lord of the Rings.

title: Good Film, Worth a Watch.
review: I enjoyed this film, Fits nicely into the "Blockbuster" genre. The CGI is well done and the story moves along nicely, However look out for the "Obvious" steals from other movies, Like The League of Extra Ordinary Gentlemen, Q Branch in the Bond Movies and Star Wars. Other Directors have got away with it so why not sommers!. In the Uk it received a 12A rating which meant we could take our 10 year old daughter, its mild horror wasn't to graphic for her, and though at times was watching from behind her coat, thoroughly enjoyed the film. All in all I would recommend this film, as worth the price of a Ticket and bag of popcorn.

title: Entertaining
review:
I must admit that the lukewarm reviews here where rather discouraging to me, notwithstanding I watched it today (08 May 2004)and found it really entertaining.

I believe it is somewhat underrated here so far. May be the expectations were too high. To me if we avoid comparisons to the Mummy or the Indiana Jones movies "Van Helsing" could be enjoyed on its own merit. It is, certainly, not a classic (some more humour would have done substantial impact in this regard) but still it worths watching. It is not overloaded with thought provoking sequences, while the action scenes are both dynamic and surprising. Altogether...enjoyable. 7/10

title: So wishy-washy....
review:
From the previews, I expected this to be a "serious" monster movie, about a man who is called on by God to fight the forces of evil. But, it was clear that after the first 10-15 minutes, that the movie was absolute camp.

I was wrong though, but I wouldn't ask the filmmakers to classify this movie. It's obvious that they didn't know what the movie was either, because at some points it's camp, trying-to-be-camp, kitschy monster movie, serious romantic drama and a few others. It gets very annoying.

And the only character I found to be likable, was Carl (David Wenham). He's the typical sidekick character whose job is to help the hero. Oh, and he talks funny.

All-in-all, I was disappointed. *C-*

title: Go for a Soda instead...
review:
I am having a super hard time finding anything positive about this movie... I was soooo disappointed! Although you don't know me, I almost always find something positive about every movie!! This one is truly hard to accept... it's like they "had to" squeeze everything into it in the hopes to improve it somehow. Even Dr. Frankenstien would have moved onto another body... or changed professions. They should have stopped production and started over... maybe after a cold soda... OR seriously considered trashing the whole thing!

The only thing I can say is wait until it comes out on DVD and you have a two for one coupon... AND you've seen everything else... twice! It's two hours of your life you will wish you could get back... I promise!!

Oh... a sequel will be coming I'm sure!

title: Better than LXG
review:
Ok, so this movie may be better than LXG, but is that really saying much? No, not it is not. You may ask why I am posing questions to myself and the reason is two-fold. The first reason is because this is not an instant system so therefore no one will be able to respond right now, and the second reason is that I don't really care what you have to say on the matter. The movie was pretty much a crapfest. There were a few good points. I will list them in order of importance: 1) Special Effects were pretty good. 2) The music was quite nice

The bad points far outweigh the good points. I will list them below in no particular order: - Story... yes there was one, but it was lame - It started WEAK, then tried to lure you in towards the middle with good music and special effects and then just got even more lame. - The bride's screeching and laughing like the wicked witch of the east was just down-right annoying. - The dude who plays Dracula looks eerily like Gary Oldman, yes I know who he is, but it was distracting. I kept asking myself why Gary Oldman was lowering himself for this. - Didn't Beckonsale already do a version of this movie? - There are many many other reasons, but to avoid ruining the "story" for others I will refrain from mentioning them.

That is all.

Trinytee Out

title: Sommers had too much money
review:
Being a big fan of Sommers two Mummy movies, I was really looking forward to this one. The Mummy movies were poorly reviewed, as Van Helsing was, so I wasn't discouraged. While I can't say the movie was bad, it wasn't great, I'm afraid.

I think the great weakness of the film was that Sommers just had too much money to work with and didn't have to make any decisions. If you listen to the director commentary for the Mummy and Mummy Returns, you hear him talk about the choices they had to make and the tricks they had to pull because of limited budgets. I think Sommers did very well with those constraints. After seeing how he behaves on an essentially unlimited budget, I think he needs the constraints of a tight budget to be effective.

As a general case in point, CGI was limited in the Mummy movies and Sommers comments on how much it cost to get effects shots done. This time around, the effects shots are so numerous and overwhelming that they detract from the overall experience. Instead of being there to advance the story, they are there to simply impress. It's unfortunate, because the price paid is in plot and character development, of which there is sadly very little. There's just not enough substance to make a connection with Van Helsing and Anna, the way you do with O'Connel and Eve in the Mummy movies.

I'd recommend this one as a rental. I own the Mummy movies on DVD. I don't expect this will be joining my DVD library when it comes out.

title: Action Fest
review:
Van Helsing is one long trailer - but in a good way. I feel you will either love it or loathe it. Comparisons will be drawn with all the horror films you could possibly imagine but in truth it should be looked at as a parody of the genre. The opening crowd sequence is superb, done in black and white for added effect and pays homage to the old Frankenstein movies.

From there the plot moves on at some pace. In fact if you drew a really big breath you could probably tell the whole plot in one sentence and not go blue in the face but hey, I'm not complaining. The accents are acceptable but I think they paid too much attention to sounding Romanian rather than actually acting so it's a bit ropey in that department. I don't really think Kate Beckinsale got the part for her acting though.

It's not really a horror film, it's not really a spoof, its somewhere in between and that is it's major flaw. It has no real identity but if you want a slobber knocker action fest with great looking leads and lots of vamp action then this is the movie for you.

title: Van Helwhat?
review:
This movie was the first movie, to my knowledge, that I saw in digital projection and it turned out to be a horrible movie.

This is a sad attempt for a clash of the 3 classic horror characters gone horrible wrong. I can't believe how 3 classic characters can be ruined in less than 2 hours and 30 minutes.

The start was decent. I like the black and white start. Gave the movie a good mood. But when Van Helsing (Hugh Jackman) comes on, the movie starts to crumble. From the lame jokes to the lame acting, nothing was going right for this movie.

Why is Frankenstein made such a fool in this movie? He isn't suppose to think, and he is only suppose to listen to his father, the creator. If your going to use classic horror characters, don't ruin the character. Wolf Man was used in a decent way, and Dracula was done good besides the fact that he had a bunch of Oompa Loompa's running around doing all this work for him. What is he now, Willy Wonka?

The concept of how to kill Dracula was heavily modified, which is understandable considering it would be easy with the original garlic, stake through heart, and cross. I was hoping the way to kill Dracula would be better, but to end it the way it did made the story crap. The connections were way too easy to make, it didn't involve any thinking.

The action scenes were crap. I knew the action scenes would include CGI, but the whole damn thing was made with CGI! I mean, directors are getting so lazy nowadays. I was hoping for some battles that actually looked real.

Overall, probably one of the worse movies of the year so far. The only thing that kept me awake was seeing Ana, damn she's hot. Other then that, Hugh Jackman should stick to X-Men.

Plot: 6 Acting: 6 Direction: 5 Visuals: 5 Overall: (not an average) 6

I have to admit that this movie was a complete mess. But i did find it amusing and entertaining.

I'd say that the plot of Van Helsing and how everything tied together was interesting, but i don't think it was executed properly. The timing for certain characters to show up and do their part was just too perfect, and too coincidental. I also noticed that the villains spent way too much time talking when they could have finished off whoever they needed to there and then.

But if you ignore the silly nicks about the film and just enjoy it as an entertaining two hours, I'd recommend it.

6/10

title: The Newest Trend?
review:
This isn't a review of this particular movie. I thought it profoundly mindless, but fun enough to make up for it. I think the CG was a tad overused, and didn't look all that good most of the time. I was particularly unimpressed with the Dracula creature. But that's pretty much all I have to say about it. It was harmless. Not good enough to leave any lasting impression, but not bad enough to make me care enough to hate it.

But I just can't get over this crossover trend that was set with League of Extraordinary Gentlemen last year. There have been several movies since that throw a bunch of characters from different franchises into the mix. Even though the Alamo is supposed to be a historical docudrama or whatever, it seemed strange to see Jim Bowie and Davey Crockett in the same story. So count that one, or don't, if you wish. Freddie vs. Jason pitted the two famed slasher movie icons against each other, and Alien vs Predator does the same with the equally iconic sci/fi monsters.

All right, two in one, that's not that bad. League of Extraordinary Gentlemen was just ridiculous, of course, with dozens of literary sources mangled in a shredder and thrown together, barely stitched together to form what some might consider a moderately coherent plot. We've got, like, ten different books colliding in this movie. Apart from the League itself, there were further references to others, including Sherlock Holmes.

But that one we can let go, because it's based on an old comic or whatever. Fine. The movie was bad enough on it's own.

Van Helsing, however, does this so overtly and so needlessly that you really have to wonder what anyone was thinking. It's the League of Extraordinary Universal Monsters. If you haven't seen the movie, you likely already know that it features Dracula, Frankenstein's monster, and the Wolf Man. However, it also feature's Mr. Hyde in a utterly unnecessary preamble. And not only does this seem out of place in the company of these classic monsters, but it's hinted that Hyde is also the Hunchback of Notre Dame, AND Jack the Ripper. These references just seem thrown in for the sake of throwing them in.

I seriously don't know what the hell they can do with the sequel you know they're going to make, unless it's just the same movie over again, with all the dead villains either coming back or turning out not to have died. Maybe we'll get computer-animated flashbacks to enlighten us.

I swear to God, Bram Stoker must be wishing he could rise from the grave and wreak his terrible, vampiric revenge upon all the different bastardizations of EVERY possible character he created. Dracula's been done to death, of course. The League butchered Mina Murray, and now Van Helsing has turned its titular character into something that barely resembles the guy we met in the book. Should we expect "Jonathan Harker" coming in 2005? Starring Keanu Reeves as an vampire hunter who engages hordes of identical undead in slow-motion kung-fu brawls? Or, better yet, "Westernra" starring - oh, I don't know, Drew Barrymore, let's say - as Lucy Westernra, turned vampire, but kept her soul or something, and so uses her supernatural undead powers and sex appeal to fight evil. It'll be like "Angel," except she's a chick.

You might laugh or roll your eyes, but if Van Helsing has been any indication, we are not that far off.

Maybe Somers thought this would be a dud, and so tried to cram in every monster he could find because he didn't think he'd get another chance. Or maybe he has a terminal illness or something. Because this is what he loves doing - taking classic, iconic figures and revisiting them in new and occasionally moderately interesting ways.

Unfortunately, Van Helsing was NOT one of those occasions.

Well, what do you know, I guess this sort of WAS a review of the movie.

title: The Best Comedy of the Year!
review:
Van Helsing was probably one of the funnier movies I've seen for a while. Or wait.. What's that you say? It wasn't supposed to be a comedy? Wow.

The first thing I noticed about this movie was how beautiful it was. The cinematography, sets, costumes, and cast were all wonderful as many of the people here have said. But there was still one thing missing here: a real plot and characters.

When I first went to see this movie, I was expecting an anime-style action movie, but when I first laid eyes on the poorly portrayed Mr. Hyde and Werewolves, I was about ready to leave the theater. I was reminded of the graphical disappointments that were "The League of Extraordinary Gentleman" and "Underworld". When is Hollywood going to get it through their heads that Mr. Hyde is not some strange, hunch-backed hairy creature incapable of normal speech? It's like they took the original character and gave him steroids along with a little bit of cocaine. As for the werewolves, I am absolutely disgusted. Now I know we all have our own images of what werewolves should look like, but come on! At least don't give us these hyeana-headed disproportionate monstrosities! It completely ruins the movie. They could have used sockpuppets with mean faces drawn on them and gotten a better effect.

The second thing in this movie that completely cracked me up was the scene where Van Helsing sticks his hand into the mirror and says the line "it's cold". It's so obviously stolen from The Matrix that they might as well have had a million Agent Smiths come out of the castle and attack the poor villagers.

I'm not saying that "stealing" certain things makes a movie bad. Believe it or not, most movies have copied off one another since the beggining of film making. Shakespeare's plot points and situations have been used countless times (e.g. "10 things I Hate About You"). I thought Van Helsing portrayed Dracula very well.

You have to admit that to make a movie like Van Helsing would have been very difficult. First of all, you would have to know all of the stories and characters by heart. Looking back on what your fourth grade teacher told you, write (ahem...direct) what you know. The Director/Writer of this movie obviously did not know very much about any of his characters except possibly Dracula. Van Helsing can be looked at as a failure to learn from. And hey, it's not even that much of a failure. Besides, it will give you a few good laughs.

P.S. What's all of this bashing of 13 year olds? I'm thirteen and I find it quite offensive when people like floridanate practically segregate us from the rest of society by saying that "we may very well enjoy this film". It's not like I can get away with saying "Those childish white people may very well enjoy this film". Keep that in mind for the next time you feel like insulting a general group of people for no particular reason.

title: Worst movie ever!!!
review: I have never seen a movie where the entire theater laughed AT the screen. This must've be some sort of practical joke - the $170 million kind of practical joke. To all you film students - remember the name Stephen Sommers; it will soon be in a textbook right next to Ed Wood.  Anyone who has anything nice to say about Van Helsing works for Universal. The production company must've been so embarrassed about putting out such trash that they neglected to put in any opening credits. Don't even bother pirating this movie; you'll want the two hours of your life back either way!

title: Relies to much on CGI which isn't that good anyway
review:
I was looking forward to seeing this movie and was disappointed when i did.

The story is fair but the script is poor. The unnecessary use of humour (which isn't that funny) makes a mockery of what should have been a classic movie and the use of cgi way over the top. Mr.Hyde cgi (1 out of 10) The transformation of wolfman looks like it was done by an amateur (2 out of 10) the vampire transformations extending the vampires mouths when they bite was totally stupid.(2 OUT OF 10)

In essence, not bad for an animated movie. Disney would be proud.

title: Critics, gimme a break
review:
Oh my god! This movie was freakin awesome. You literary nerds who say "well in bram stoker and mary shelly's novel thats not how it happened" can take this stake... You know where to stick it.

no movie is based on an original idea. they should be proud that they had the guts to come out and say "it is Frankinstine" and "it is Dracula" instead of making it some stupid movie that just happens to have a Vampire Lord in translvania, and a 7'7" monster made from corpses.

and you dorks who say "well, Van Helsing was an old dutch professor of the occult" can go give themselves a Holy Water enima because the creators who made the movie were not thinking "hey, lets make an accurate representation of the life of Stoker's character Van Helsing" but instead they said "hm, lets make a sweet action flick with all three classic Horror monsters... but who would be the hero? Well he'd have to be totally awesome, but we have no cool name for him. Oh lets call him 'Van Helsing' just cause he relates to Dracula." You understand? The character only got his name from the literary character. thats right, he is in no way supposed to be the novel character.

3rdly "Oh dear... whine... well i just cant accept a movie that is so different from the great classic novels and movies....boo hoo.."

Got news for you, buddy. why dont you go and rent those "classic" movies. Anyone who has half a brain can see that the classic movies are also very loosly based on the books. So don't cry to me about accuracy because no one did in the 1930s!

(sorry for ranting, but alot of people have griped at me when i told them i saw it, presenting these very same arguments)

Finally: Give it a freakin chance, ok? if your heads are too small to get by these statements that i have said, then you will probably not see it. well too bad for you. youre missing out on what might be the greatest monster mash ass-whuppin spree since the fight scenes in Lord of the Rings (as if there were any other kinds of scenes)

Ah well, Ive done my ranting for the day.

Those who have seen it, post here

title: Fantastic!
review: Van Helsing is everything that I hoped it would be. Awesome visual effects and tongue and cheek humor (much like The Mummy movies). The acting is superb and it never allows itself to be taken too seriously. Well done to all involved. For those of us who are Hugh Jackman lovers, he NEVER disappoints! A wonderful scene in nothing but some shredded underclothes (no shirt; no pants)!!! WHAT A PHYSICAL SPECIMAN HE IS!!! There are no sexual scenes (some sensual behavior from the vampire brides - some innuendos otherwise) - no filthy language and no real gory parts - excellent movie. Rating is accurate as some children may experience nightmares because of monsters.

title: Entertaining
review:
**(1/2)*

This movie is very enjoyable. It was just entertaining and nothing more. I wasn't a fan of the acting or writing and with the budget, I wasn't to thrilled with the special effects. Although at the very beginning with the black and white, the special effects were very good. All around ,though, they did a pretty good job in it. It was pretty long and had many unneeded scenes but once again there was something about it that was intriguing. Although I wouldn't recommend going out to see this, when it is available for rent this is a movie that is a good way to spend 2 hours.

title: Fun, fast, furious, full of holes...
review:
Yes, this movie has tons of plotholes. Yes this movie has all sorts of small flaws. Do those things matter to this movie? No, they do not. And why don't they matter? Because this is a James bond meets medieval fantasy. I had fun watching this movie. The people that went to see this movie and claims here that they would've "stormed the box office and demanded the money back for the entire audience" and request that the director should apologize in public for this movie, are idiots. This is a movie you watch if you like gung-ho action, to be suspended in disbelief by something so outré that no way in hell could this ever be real. And none of it can of course. But that's the beauty of it. This movie takes something so far out, so outrageous as this is, and turns it believable.

This is a great new action-movie. Action movies were best in the 80's and since then the genre has degenerated into horrible movies featuring The Rock or clever things with cool gimics, like The Matrix and Boondock Saints. This is more true to the action legacy of movies like Indiana Jones and James Bond than even the new James Bond movies.

Fun movie, but not a great movie. And there's a difference there. You can hammer this movie all you want, but that won't change that fact that it's still fun and you can enjoy yourself with this piece of excellent escapism. Just don't for one second think that it will contain a hidden message that will cause every person in the world to realise the errors of their ways and love each other.

8/10, judged like an actionmovie, not as a poetical masterpiece.

title: Set brain to "idle," relax and enjoy
review:
Once the plot elements are in place, the action is nonstop, which leads one to forget, or at least ignore, the gaping holes in said plot. The special effects are riveting in some places, cartoonish in others. The sexy yet sexless harpies may rate Oscar consideration for special effects. Jackman, Beckinsale and Roxburgh all have a strong "presence" in the film, something I always look for. The movie has elements of not only Dracula and Frankenstein, but also of James Bond and Lord of the Rings, and probably other stories and films that I have missed. A couple of plot and theme elements are unresolved at the end, leaving open the possibility of a SEQUEL--the dreaded "S" word.

--Spoiler-- Two characters who you would expect to die in movies of this genre are still alive at the closing credits, while one expected survivor dies at the end.

title: Truly Awful...ultimately so absurd that it's a $150 Million B-Movie
review: It's built on a shaky foundation of impossibilities. Willing suspension of disbelief is expected with any film, but this movie asks you to swallow a lot of stupidity. It's ultimately so absurd - and sometimes so downright unintentionally laughable - that nobody associated with making this movie can possibly emerge unscathed and that's a shame.  Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale are just too good for this type of lame-brain summer movie. Was that the absolute worst Dracula in the history of the cinema? EVERY line that two bit actor delivered was so cheesy and over the top that it my me grimace in disbelief. A film of singularly boneheaded conceits...populated by, and appears to have been made by, stoned college dudes more hung up on oh-wow twists than the need to make sense.

title: NOT WHAT IT WAS CRACKED UP TO BE
review: I went to see the preview of this flat film and was totally dis- appointed in the slow moving film. I remember the Boris Korloff and Bela Lagosi originals and they scared me out of my wits. The cast in this movie left a lot to be desired.  What has happened to the writers now days, and they do not seem to have the talent to write a decent screen play. This tale of Frankenstein should have been left alone, and they say newer is better.  Not in this case.

title: Attack of the boom mics
review: We went to see Van Helsing at the drive-in, as we felt this was the perfect venue for viewing such an epic. The costumes truly matched the period. The special effects were top-notch.
