Not silly enough to be fun in the MST3000 sense, it was merely dull. As if to make up for the dullness, it's also long. I kept checking my watch, something I don't recall doing in the movies recently. I paid US$0.50 to see this movie, and I think it was about US$8 too much. Some have called this movie "homage" to monster movies of old. If this is what the golden-oldie monster movies were like, I'd say they're best forgotten.

title: What a Mess
review: Van Helsing is a complete mess. I am mystified why they would have two of the most beautiful stars in Hollywood in Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale and not highlight them.  The movie throws everything related to 19th Century horror novels against the wall in hopes that something will stick.  Most films now a days don't have enough plot but Van Helsing has too much. Battles with Dr. Jekyll, Dracula, Wolfman, Frankenstein's Monster and the immortal lab assistant Igor mostly complete the list.  Unfortunately there is zero emotional connection, not even reaching to the depths of Armageddon. This is a pure set design movie with bad CGI monsters; even given the efforts of Hugh and Kate.  What a lot of people don't realize is that Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale are GOOD actors.  However the director, Stephen Sommers gave them nothing to work with.  Too bad, coulda been a contender. Wait for the DVD.

title: Not so serious monster smash
review:
Movies like Blade and underworld opened the doors of vampires and werewolves to the big audience once again. Of course this means that there are vultures who want their share of the tasty and rich corpse. This could be a good thing, but in this case it's not. For example comparing Van Helsing to Blade the difference is that Blade is a good movie and comparing to the Underworld difference is that Underworld has credible filming. Sorry Van Helsing

Movie is about this radical monster hunter called Van Helsing. Actor Hugh Jackman as Van Helsing is just walking through the movie with basic routine. Nothing special is transferred to the screen. I miss the Wolverine attitude what Hugh gave in X-Men.

Movie's worst problem (after that annoying idiot sidekick who is forced to tag alone with Mr. Helsing) is that it tries too much to please everybody. Movie is bit of comedy, action, fantasy, `romance?' and horror. Combining all these factors make the movie only to be below average in every category. It can't be a good action film because it's too busy trying to be scary and so on.. Well the makers of the film have really wanted to invest their multi category story by giving the film over two hours duration. It's pretty rare to have such a long time in this kind of movie but it won't work. Movie is over long and after the first hour it starts repeating itself pretty much and starts to make you pretty bored and numb.

If you have to find something good out of the film I have to give a credit of the huge amount of effects they have use. In over two hour film there is not many scenes where CGI graphics aren't used. This is a good thing because so many times effect movies have effects only couple of minutes (the scenes what you see in trailer) and that's that. Rest of the movie is just dull conversation etc. But that's a difference in Van Helsing. Unfortunately the effects used in movie are only in average level, some are almost good and some are bad. But if you like watching effects there's plenty of that in this film.

At the end just to keep the movie review in balance and remind that we are talking about a bad movie here, I have to say that the gadgets and guns Helsing were using are too over sci-fi to be only cool or funny, they were embarrassing. Keep away from this one and eat some garlic just to make sure that it keeps away from you.

title: A disappointment...
review:
**Spoilers ahead**

I really wanted to like this movie, I really did. I watched the trailers and TV commercials thinking how cool this movie looks. Unfortunately Van Helsing is marred by some glaring flaws that keep me from recommending it.

This is not to say the movie is all bad. The most obvious high points are the fight scenes. My attention was definitely grabbed when Van Helsing started wailing on some vampires with his automated crossbow. Also Hugh Jackman is pretty good (although not great) in this movie with his somewhat comedic dialogue. Kate Beckinsale is also smokin hot in this movie, although you wonder about the practicality of fighting in high heels.

My main beef with Van Helsing is with the monsters. Particularly with Frankenstein, Dracula, and Dracula's wives. The acting and dialogue spouted by these characters is bad. I mean REALLY bad. I cringe whenever they start talking, not because it's scary, but I'm afraid they might not stop yapping. The CGI for some of the monsters, such as the Mr. Hyde monster, at times looks obviously fake. Yeah I know they're fake to begin with, but I think an actor with some good monster make up would have been a better choice instead of computers. Lastly, this movie relies too much on special effects instead of character development. In a movie like Van Helsing you expect a lot of special effects to be used, but other movies (like the Spider-Man and X-Men movies) have shown that you can have great effects and great character development as well.

I would like to leave off by saying that Van Helsing was not a totally bad movie, but it does nothing to propel itself above just being an average one. However, if Van Helsing 2 ever comes out, I am willing to give it a chance, in the hopes they have corrected a least some of the mistakes from the first movie.

I give Van Helsing a 6/10.

title: 5 of 10 stars
review:
The good: Good special effects.

The bad: The dialogue was cliche. The special effects are nothing new by today's standards. Fight scenes lacked choreography. Lots of plot holes. For example, the monsters somehow get to keep their underwear while the rest of their clothes melt into their skin during transformation. The characters were inconsistent in their abilities. In one scene a character can leap tall buildings in a single bound, and another scene later the same character can't hardly climb a ledge.

This movie was rated PG-13, however it was basically a rated G movie with a script fit for saturday morning cartoons and a few scenes of violence to get the rating up to a PG-13.

title: Auch.
review:
This isn't a review as much as it is a part of a self-therapeutic process to get over a stinking experience.

Before I begin, I'd like to tell you about something that characterises this inflated project where far too much money have been involved. I noticed some advertisement for a writing competition connected to this film. It stated that you should submit a story containing certain words and among them was (I kid you not) "Van Helsing the computer game". After reading that, it was only by chance I came to see this film, as I walked by a free showing out in the open, no charge.

There is a certain type of film where you get the feeling that they cut down on working on the manuscript in order to beef up the special effects department. It usually has 'big' names fronting it, like Chuck Norris or Van Damme. Plot weaknesses are abundant and there is a clear tendency where every car crash ends with an explosion.

For a film on the supernatural set before the invention of the automobile, this sure do come close to that description. Lousy acting, a story so illogical it hurts even if you've switched your brain to "sit back and enjoy the ride" and a 'car chase' that ends with an explosion.

Some dosage of this might be forgivable if it is a shoe-string budget film made by a rookie and three of his or hers friends. This, in lack of better words, 'entity' contains digital artwork by WETA (Lord of the Rings), fabulous locations(among others a cathedral), made by an experienced director alongside actors that have been seen in cinemas before and costumes that Anne Rice would dream of putting on her characters. The sad thing is, it all feels wasted. A film that so much relies on special effects, doesn't even put them to good use.

Now I didn't expect high-quality acting or a great artwork made a by a great director. After all, Stephen Sommers did The Mummy Returns. I do expect to at some degree to find enjoyment. Seeing horrible versions of classic characters being torn to pieces (did they say "Here's an idea: Let's combine Frankenstein's monster with Tarzan!" in the planning stage?) on expensive sets in hopeless settings doesn't include in this. I had no expectations of excellence, but any hopes of mere mediocrity was blown away. Highlander and Universal Soldier are great series going strong in comparison. Considering that the original Dracula manages to be creepy by the mere use of shadows and make-up at a time when the director's title was 'herr doktor', then Van Helsing is an artistic failure.

I should say that I didn't watch the entire film. It being an outdoor showing on a plaza, I took time to go and buy myself a hot dog and some soda. I also arrived after it had begun, somewhere before Jack Hughman meets Kate Beckinsale.

Even for a free show, this felt disturbingly incompetent. This is from the guy who quite liked Underworld in some of it's moments; save yourself the trouble and do NOT watch this film. Valid alternatives include renting Highlander, taking a look at episodes of Narnia or go down to your video store, close your eyes and point at random. Both Willow and Ronja Røverdatter knocks Van Helsing down into his socks and those were made before CGI with main characters under 5 foots.

title: This sucked!
review:
I was set out to prove my local radio station wrong... I should have stuck with what they said.

I originally thought it would be a halfway decent monster beat-down... however it was nothing more than CGI all around.

I went with my dad and one of my friends (Both separately) and I got the same reaction... I had to get out of the theater before I died from boredom

This movie does less for the mind, and more for the sphincter.

In closing, I say to you: Stay away from this one!

1/10

By the way, I think you all could learn from me... listen to your radio station when they say a movie's bad.

title: I can't describe in words how bad this movie is.
review:
This movie it's so bad, it actually gets funny. I laughed and laughed as the movie went on. It's the largest amount of garbage I've seen, since League of Extraordinary Gentlemen.

I really think that anybody who has at least half a brain should be spared from watching such monstrosity who some may call a horror movie. The combination of monsters, with bad accents, with "vampire babies" (this one killed me :) ), with horses that can actually fly over broken bridges and with name used by Dracula (Vladislau Dragulia - is not even by far a Transylvanian name) makes this movie a "HORROR" (in the bad way) movie for the people who actually enjoy the genre.

So .. being the nice person that I believe to be, I must warn all of you who intend to watch this movie: DON'T !!! You won't miss anything.

title: Disappointing...
review:
I just saw this film recently and I was sadly disappointed. The previews made it appear as though it would a non-stop suspense/horror roller coaster ride, however it wasn't at all.

I'll make this as brief as I can by just getting to the point. The first scene of the movie was the best more than assuredly, and when that scene ended I was excited hoping that the rest of the film would be just as terrific, unfortunately I was going to be let down. And by the end of the first half hour, I was trying to read my watch in the dark wondering when this movie would finally end so that we could all be released from the pain and misery of such a horrible piece. Obviously the writing was the worst part of it. There was just no story to it. It would have also been nice had Hugh Jackman had personality. When our hero first arrives at the beginning of the movie, I thought to myself, "Oh yea, Hugh Jackman's in this." Which was fine, however it's not fine when you continually do this throughout the entire film. Every time he spoke or made somewhat of a action that was more than drab, I reminded myself that not only was he actually in the movie, but he was also the start. Not a good thing.

The directing was outstanding and it was some of the most incredible CG I've ever seen, but there were so many elements missing in the film and story. They never developed any of the characters, and the monsters just weren't scary enough I think for one main reason. They didn't wait long enough in between "scary moments" to let you catch your breath and not expect to see them again, they just sort of kept showing up.

A couple more things to that I'd like to add to this, was it just me, or did Frankenstein's monster resemble Peter Boyle (see: 'Young Frankenstein')? And didn't Egor look like Ted Danson just a little too much? Just a thought.

The girl was probably the best in the movie next to Egor, who I sort of had sympathy for, is that right, by the way? But overall this movie really sucked in my opinion. I paid 3 bucks to go see this, and in my opinion I overpaid by $2.75. So, if you wanna see it go for it, if you're hoping for great special effects and a lot of bad dialogue and no story you're definitely in for a treat, otherwise don't bother.

I give it a 2.5 out of 10 and that's being kind.

title: Great Movie with your favorite horror stars
review:
This movie combines all of your old time favorite horror stars with a new updated look. You have your Count Dracula, Dr Jeckell, The Wolfman and Frankenstein. The only one I missed was The Mummy, and from what i have heard they are working on a Van Helsing 2 that will include The Mummy. Holds the viewers interest, with shocking jolts of surprise. Hugh Jackman was the perfect person to portray the slayer of all the evils. Kate was a great leading lady following her lead role in Underworld.

Great movie, I will watch it over and over once it is released to purchase.

title: Some of Column A, Some from Column B
review:
"Van Helsing" Column A: There doesn't seem to be much of this going around so I'll try: there are a few things I think the film-maker's did well in the production. First off, if someone were to try and jam 90% of the most famous Gothic characters into one film AND attempt to create a coherent (if not anywhere near plausible) storyline around it - this isn't too shabby. Secondly, as an avid movie and television watcher, it is really hard to find anything that is genuinely surprising anymore, but I did find a few twists in the film that were completely original; namely, the clever integration between the Frankenstein subplot and the main Dracula one - a truly diabolical application of technology I must say. In addition, there are some very scary ideological underpinnings that sprout from the fictitious reinvention of the leading antagonist characters. It was a cool answer to the question, "if Dracula and Dr. Frankenstein met, what would they talk about?" In short, it was these two factors of surprise and clever integration of multiple themes that made the movie worth watching.

On the flip side, we have column B: What the film has in ideological plot ingenuity it lacks in its rampant efforts to "make its mark" in the action genre; Sylvester Stallone's Rambo and Sigourney Weaver's Ellen Ripley define the persona's of Van Helsing and Anna, respectively. The characters are often shunted around as more staples of a different genre rather than key players in Gothic fiction. They're tired veterans and experienced soldiers, and as such, they are completely desensitized to the genuinely creepy, violent, and monstrous elements of their world. Some people accuse the movie of being over the top; rather, I think that the film is just missing some of the drama of watching all-too-human characters butt-heads in a conflict that creates an all-encompassing, paralyzing, bed-wetting fear. This Van Helsing is an icon, but nothing more. We watch in awe and amazement at the things he does, but forget him just as quickly after because his humanity (such as compassion and fear) has been shone away in a way that ours hasn't.

In general, this creates a strange paradox for potential viewers; the plot gracefully argues the shared Gothic core of the original fiction where emerging technology and magic question our beliefs about the nature of the divine, but presents it in a way that heralds the later action/sci-fi genre - using the magic and science as a plot device to deliver what boils down to a really big brawl.

My recommendation: if you're willing to look past the brawl because you love Gothic fiction, you will be heartily rewarded for the film's attenuation to the original spirit of the works; namely, the integrative treatments of Dr. Frankenstein's "monster," and (to a lesser extent after the first reel) the origin tale of Dracula. If that doesn't matter to you and you just want to see a supernatural slug fest, then have no reservations about checking out the film - immediately. Drama in this film is few, far-between, but wholly rewarded when seen; even so, their are many surprising and genuinely fun moments that are worth watching for any audience.

title: Van Hell-to-sit-through
review:
Bats! Fangs! Cleavage! This must be a crappy take on Dracula.

Lightning! Thunder! Zaps of electrical power! This must be a crappy take on Frankenstein.

Secret agents! Gadgets! A funny sidekick! This must be a crappy take on James Bond. Or Batman. With a bit of Disney sprinkled in.

Is this really a tribute to Universal horror films? Those movies had story lines, morals, characters...this is two hours of nonstop fighting between a stony-faced Hugh Jackman and duff CGI creatures. Why not do a tribute to the Marx Brothers starring Adam Sandler? Or a tribute to Jimmy Stewart starring Vin Deisel?

Bring headache medicine. And a pillow. And don't expect to be thrilled, scared, or titillated. "Van Helsing" is about as frightening and sexy as a trip to CVS to stock up on toiletries.

Biggest surprise? After making a good impression as Wolverine, Jackman is an utter bore here. Beckinsale steals the movie with a nice hairstyle and a cool costume. But who's she trying to fool "viz" that accent?

title: Unspeakable Cinematic Monstrosities.
review: Super-monster Dracula (Richard Roxburgh) and his super-erotic wives (Elena Anaya, Silvia Colloca and Josie Maran) try to get to Frankenstein's monster (Shuler Hensley) for a deviant scheme. The last of a family of Transylvanian warriors (Kate Beckinsale), the titled character (Hugh Jackman) and a technically sophisticated holy man (David Wenham) try to stop the evil-doers before it is too late. These Hollywood monsters have been around seemingly since the advent of the motion picture, but I do not believe that any other picture has been this disappointing from the genre. "Van Helsing" is a loud and incoherent bore that tries to win its audience over with crazed visual effects, chaotic sounds and admittedly beautiful women. All this does nothing to make up for a terrible screenplay and mediocre direction by Stephen Sommers (of "The Mummy" series fame). The characters get lost in the venture and really this would have been better as a long computer-generated exercise than a cinematic feature. Turkey (0 stars out of 5).

title: Stick a pole through this one!!
review: A movie whit Frankenstein's monster, Dracula, Werewolfs and Van Helsing should be a pretty cool flick on the paper. Director Stephen Sommer did make the average "The Mummy" and the not so good sequel. But this time he decided to put all the old universal monster in one movie. The result? Total garbage, no one whit the least taste for movies can give this one a good review. This suck on so many levels and the monster of Frankenstein is maybe the worst one ever to be put on screen. A monster movie should rely on the atmosphere and the gothik feeling but this one is molested whit sh***y computer FX and why does half the movie take place among ropes that the cast is flying back and forward in all the time? Shame on you Mr.Sommers, shame on you. Give us the real monsters back!!!

title: Entainging Movie Created A Fan Site
review:
This movie was entertaining. I do not think it was some of the more glamorous films but overall entertaining.

I did however find myself watching the film and guessing what was going to happen next. Predictable in some spots.

Also the movie seemed to have the same problems as some of the other multi character movies. Trying to give each of them same equal time in which it seems the movie jumps around.

title: Comic book action, neither scary or funny enough
review:
I went to "Van Helsing" hoping to see a throwback to the Hammer Horror movies, set in the late 19th century that provided some genuine horror.

While the movie made an attempt, it was unfortunately a comic book/gamer movie with virtually non stop action, excellent special effects, and vanilla characters. I liked it, but would like to see the director try again with a sequel.

Next time, slow it down and scare the c**p out of me. Try for fewer unbelievable swings through the air and more screams with a few laughs mixed in. By the way, Van Helsing's first name was "Abraham". Unless maybe this is his son.

title: Well what did you expect?
review: Really, from the man who brought us The Mummy films and Deep Rising (with Treat Williams as a lead, Ha!), did anyone honestly expect this to be up to much? Okay, maybe I did. But I suppose you can't just throw loads of money at something and think it's gonna be any good. Frankenstien's brain looked quite nice and the wolf man gave my wife a fright or two (though she got scared during Monsters Inc so I wouldn't pay much attention to that) but what the hell was old Dracula all about? Who keeps on casting Richard Roxburgh as villains? He's rubbish at them. Maybe it's just his slightly bulbous nose putting me off but I just can't take him seriously when he's trying to infect the world with gremlins/ blow up Venice/ ravage Nicole Kidman. Overall the whole film was just far too hectic for it's own good. I just have one thing to say to Stephen Sommers; calm down man, breathe in occasionally. Oh that's two things, oh forget it.

title: Boring....
review: Van Helsing is an example of the worst kind of Hollywood Popcorn movies; it's violent, no sex, filled with CGI effects and no plot (or too much plot that doesn't go anywhere). This very much reminds me of Underworld (also starring Kate Beckinsdale)- a pure set design piece. Van Helsing is a mysterious hunter of supernatural villains (all of the standard 19th Century English Monsters) working for Rome (the Church). After dispatching a very phony CGI villain in Paris he get sent to Transylvania to kill Count Dracula. I'm so disappointed. I adore the actors and the set design but the CGI is extremely fake and the plot might make sense to the MTV generation (as long as they are on a sugar-induced frenzy). Pointless violence is boring however lots to like but it's a missed opportunity. Don't spend your hard-earned money, wait for the DVD. Josie Maran as one of Dracula's wives is a real looker.

title: Good characters, fun film
review:
Its over the top with some crazy fantasy put in to boot. Decent accent by Kate Beckinsale only, Hugh sounds a cross between Harrison Ford and Hugh Grant and his sidekick is a fleshed out C3PO.

Stephen Sommers has had a memorable stab at the thirties classics, including the obvious and the Bride of Frankenstein, although the most detailed character is the monster, a little more wouldn't go amiss. The trouble with the film is the high octane action with no room to breathe, like Die Another Day. The character I was most looking forward to was the The Wolfman, whom has a confusing storyline that with the fighting against Van Helsing becomes the rest of the films main suspense. A sham, because the mood could have handled a rest, creating a nest errie surrounding. The ending is like a scene from King Kong, a similarity with the end of T2 and a bit of a Tarzan Lookalike in there as well. The musical score is not hitting the target particularly the horse carriage scene. Generally the plot strengthens during the film, but not to make is a great one to watch. Unfortunately the film adapted a pure action flick rather than a restrained thriller, which giving the potential atmosphere would have been a real bloodsucking treat.

title: ". . . full of sound and fury, signifying nothing."
review:
This is an atrocious movie. It constitutes one of only three films I've ever actually wanted to walk out of despite having paid theater rates (I've only ever walked out of one). _Van_Helsing_ possesses no plot or character development other than tired and overly used clichés. The only redeeming and creative effort I can discern occurs in the presentation of the end credits. Vast amounts of stimuli shouldn't be boring, but it's clearly possible.

This movie makes _Underworld_ (also starring Beckinsale) look like a work of genius, and _X2_ (also starring Jackman) seem like a well thought out effort.

title: A terrible end...
review: I loved the special effects in this film. And Hugh Jackman is the best cast for the role of Van Helsing. But the Americans have the bad habit to destroy the entire film with the too sentimental ends of their films! Why do they do that? It is too slushy and that irritates. The role of Dracula is a bit miscast. He does not play it very mysterious and he does not look dangerous in all scenes. Kate Beckinsale plays very good as well. She has not been the wallflower she was in "Pearl Harbor" and she looks well trained! Hollywood may give her more roles of this kind. She acts more mysterious than Dracula and his brides together!

title: Great show. Not a Movie Experience.
review:
I fell in love with the premise of this movie. For all you fantasy fans out there, it was taking an old cleric/scholar and turning him into a kick-butt paladin/assassin. The more I read the promos, the more I loved the idea.

Then I saw the movie.

I still appreciated the premise. The scripting was pretty good, minus two or three scenes. Great action movie. The overall movie experience was lacking.

Its special effects were its great strength and weakness. They spent so much money and time on getting the effects right, they seemed to skimp on the little things: choreography, accent coaches, wardrobe, music, lighting, set design. These are the things that make the movie an experience rather than just a show.

VAN HELSING & ANNA (Lead characters) The two main characters were very well done. I can't really complain much about them. They were well written, well acted, well directed, well wardrobed. . . I do wish they had given some character development as to why Anna was able to fight so well. But it was a long enough movie as it was, maybe they cut it out for time.

Dracula Richard Roxburgh did an excellent job in his execution of his script. But he could have made his speech about having no heart a little more than one-dimensional. Let's face it, in a movie like this, we appreciate a villain that has SOME redeeming quality. His interchange with Van Helsing was much more impressive. And he handled his death rather well. Excellent method of showing a vampire's healing abilities.

THE VAMPIRESSES (Dracula's brides) The vampiresses should have just been extras. Their action sequences were great. But every time they opened their mouths, I rolled my eyes and was just waiting for the next scene. They didn't really add anything to the plot or the movie except for their fights. I didn't even think they were sexy. Especially not in those campy outfits they had on. They looked like they were trying out for some psychic hotline ad.

CARL ("I'm not a monk. I'm just a friar") This was a work of genius as far as character creation goes. They give you a great taste of what it would be like if James Bond had Q with him on his assignments as a sidekick. Although I feel it was a simple part for an actor, I have to give David Wendham credit for performing it well.

IGOR His line,"It's what I do" pretty much sums it up. You can't have a movie like this without Igor. And he was doing exactly what we expected him to do. But someone was going to ask "why is he doing that?" So, they had Dracula ask for us. It's just what he does. Don't question it.

SET DESIGN Most of the scenes were very good. But I'd think the most important set would be inside Dracula's castle. And that is where the set designer really disappointed me. Maybe it was partially the lighting and camera work. Maybe other little factors. But the cobwebs were overdone and the entire set looked too plastic. The colors were just slightly off to make it look like it was faked. Again, if I'm there to just see an action movie, OK. But the promos made it seem like it was going to be a little deeper than that.

WARDROBE Van Helsing was well outfitted. As was Dracula. I could even say that the friar was done OK, but how can you go wrong with a plain brown robe? Everyone else looked really campy. Anna's wardrobe: designed well, poorly excecuted. It needed slightly different fabrics or colors that would project differently on the big screen.

SPECIAL EFFECTS The battle scenes with the vampiresses and even the baby vampires were good.

I never felt like I was suspending any disbelief. I just looked and felt I'd been transported. The transformation sequences were good for both Dracula and the werewolves. But when they had their final battle, they fell victim to the same problem that all heavily CG characters have. The speed and balance of the characters is always slightly off from reality. The only way I could console myself was that these were superhuman creatures able to violate some laws of physics in a fantasy movie. Even then, it was an effort to suspend my disbelief. Van Helsing's weapons were very well designed. Obviously not realistic for the era. But it was not too big a stretch for this genre of movie.

EXPERIENCE This is a quality of movies that I don't see much comment on. It takes into account things like flow of the movie, emotions not only portrayed by the actors, but absorbed by the audience, the feeling that you are actually in the scene.

For this quality, I'll have to give an 8 for a few scenes, but a 2 or 3 for the rest of the movie.

SUMMARY If you're looking for an action movie that has someone being the superhero and kicking butt (Swarzennegger's --Commando) it's a great movie. They made some effort at being an intelligent movie as well, but only had limited success at executing that goal.

If you want a movie that made you feel like you want to hear more about these characters and this world you've just been introduced to (Lord of the Rings), this was OK, but not a great movie.

Cloud Castle

title: If it wasn't for Hugh Jackman...
review: If it wasn't for Hugh Jackman, this movie will go down as one of the poorly-made movies ever. It was pretty good at first. We've got this guy with superhuman strength commissioned by the church to fight off the bad guys. Pretty good so far. And then he was sent to kill Dracula. And he teamed up with Kate Beckinsale, that's when it started going downhill. It didn't match up with the main premise. The movie had a great premise, but it seemed Sommers couldn't quite connect with it. I loved how he manipulated the stories of Frankenstein, Dracula and werewolves and made it a good twist to the story. I didn't like how he developed Jackman and Beckinsale's characters though. And the ending made me laugh out loud. It was either that or cry from frustration. I chose to laugh. But it's a great action movie, just don't watch it for the script.

title: Special effects good... story terrible.
review: Not even having great actors like Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale could save the awful story line of this film. It didn't help that Beckinsale's accent was distracting at best. I love classic monster films but I am not a purist in stating that Frankenstein's monster couldn't be pseudo-insightful, but thousands of vampire offspring that look like Spyro flitting around after being empowered by energy harnessed through Frankenstein's monster??? I think they were obsessed with how to get as many monsters into one film as possible and not very worried about how to make an exciting story. I gave it a "3" for the special effects which were decent even by today's standards.

title: Promising moments but tried to do too much.
review: I found this film disappointing almost purely because it had some excellent elements that were crowded out in an attempt to pack too much into to smaller space. Firstly what was good about the film. The opening sequence was excellent and really grabbed my attention with a black and white recreation of the famous sequence involving a mob of Villagers burning down a windmill with Frankenstein's Monster in it, this sequence was excellently filmed although this may be due to the strength of the source material rather than the director. Secondly the actor Richard Roxbrough who played Dracula was fantastic and gave across a fantastic air of charming evilness with a particularly good speech about the heartrates of victims as he is about to dispatch them. The settings were also excellent with plenty of nice touches such as a semi built Eifel Tower in the Paris sequence. However the film was spoilt for me by the music which was an inappropriate trance type selection and by the seemingly obilgatory comedy side kick monk who added nothing whatever to the plot. Lastly Hugh Jackman seemed to be struggling to add anything to Van helsing which wasn't his fault as his character was utterly one dimensional. The film wasn't bad exactly and filled a dull Sunday afternoon but it had to much chaff nd didn't develop its strong points. In fact a series might have been better with Van Helsing encountering each Monster in turn.

title: Filmmakers "used" Prague's St. Nicholas holy ground for "Vampire carnival"
review:
Dear God, I still can't believe this can be true(!)

I've recognized it at the first moment, the "Vampire carnival" scene is filmed entirely in the interior of the ancient and one of the holiest grounds in the old Europe, in the great St. Nicholas cathedral of Prague of Bohemia. They even removed the ancient benches. I feel really disgusted and say angry of what those ignorant cinematographers did.

This is and it was one of the most admired and one of the holiest grounds in the old "Holy Roman Empire" and the "Kingdom of Bohemia". This was the Church of choice (besides St.Peter's) for Emperors and Kings in the middle ages when the Prague was capital city of the Roman empire from the Baltic to Adriatic sea. This is master-piece-church of the Gothic/late baroque, made by the most skilful artists of Italy, Germany and Bohemia for God sake!

Church people said that they have no idea of what filmmakers will do in the inside. They "rented" the cathedral for some big money so the church people were happy for the "donation". My brother said that he saw a spot about it in our local television. I am surprised that the city is not suing producers for this.

So what now mr. Sommers ? Will you go to Vatican and use the Sixteen Chapel as your next playground ? Because the old town cathedral at the very heart of Europe is ready for a new dedication after this.

Another clear example of ignorance of American filmmakers is the scene where the ancient emperor's Charles IV bridge of Prague and the (obvious) city landscape of Prague is shown and "the vampiress" named the city Budapest (!). So the filmmakers now trade Prague for Budapest ? It's like show landscape of New York and say Moscow. Bohemia's Prague has nothing in common with Magiar's Budapest for God sake! It would be better if they use no names at all.

The CGI made castle scenes looked fabulous so why they decided to use those well known Prague sightseeing and renamed them.. ? It is odd, it's unoriginal and it feels horrible (at least for mid European).

I admire Sommers for his previous flicks, but he will be send to hell for what he did in Van Helsing.

:-)

title: One of the worst movies I saw recently
review:
Incredibly bad, that's all I can say about it. I actually walked away - the second time I did this in my entire life. I didn't care about Princess Anna or Van Helsing or the werewolf. I just wanted the pain to stop.

The visuals are breathtaking. The CGI is OK, although the water is too obviously computer generated, (the werewolf too).

Kate is sexy and it's nice to see a strong woman in a movie like this.

Everything else is a wreck. The story is plain stupid, with absolutely no regard to history or geography (they travel from Transylvania to Hungary by crossing the mountains in the south?? Budapest is to the west!) The violence bothered me a little - it kinda pushed the PG13 label.

title: Die, movie, die
review:
One of the worst movies I've ever seen in the theater.

I couldn't wait till the movie ended. During the movie the film and sound messed up, however this was one of the good points. When the movie returned to normal, a great sadness fell upon me. However, there was one point in the movie that was exciting. In fact I can't remember when i've been this excited over the ending of a movie...LOL

Seriously, though, the characters were boring. The actor who played Dracula, was one of the worst actors i've seen in a long time. But it wasn't' all his fault, part of it was the script. I can't believe I wasted over 2 hours of my life there. I can never get that back. :(

title: Hilariously bad
review:
20 years from now, I'll probably be able to watch this train wreck of a movie again after a few drinks and laugh at it. I admit that I did get a few laughs this time around, too, but mostly I was just groaning in frustration.

The worst Dracula ever, the worst Frankentein's monster ever, the stupidest phallic big gun ever, and worst acting ever from Beckinsale and Jackman. It's a good thing that the director decided to focus on shots of Beckinsale's butt bouncing up and down instead of her acting, so there weren't too many of those "I've never been to the sea" moments.

All the performances are pitiful, but one of them stands above the rest in its sheer stupidity: David Wenham, who plays a retarded idiot for the benefit of other retards in the audience so they can laugh at him. He was the only one I felt sorry for.

The story is so nonsensical it seems as if they were making it up as they went along. There is, of course, a half-baked love story of sorts between Jackman and Benkinsale, but it's there just because it has to, not because it makes sense in any way. The ending will leave you wondering whether to laugh or cry.

In every way, Van Helsing is light years behind Hellboy, the other recent supernatural popcorn thriller. See that instead and leave this for a "bad movies" DVD night.

title: Its watchable I'll give it that.
review: Basically disappointing though. I didn't think the Dracula character was very well done. I don't know if this film is meant to be scary but I'm fairly easy to scare and yet nothing here is remotely scary in the least. Its just an action flic involving vampires. Hugh Jackman comes off well. He makes a good solid hero and Kate Beckinsale is decent eye candy who speaks her lines well. I didn't think her running was very photogenic at the beginning though. The film feels like LXG with its combining of fictional characters into one single plot. The film starts with much better character development but at the end is a mess just like LXG to be honest. Its good for one watch during your lifetime but I certainly wouldn't want to buy the DVD. Once is enough for me. The CGI was also hit and miss. Generally a lot more hit than miss but a few times it was pretty rough.

title: This movie is its own Frankenstein monster.
review: A regrettable waste of talent and resources. Aside from the acting, this was a heavy-handed effort. Were it not for some lighter moments with the female vampires and a re-imagined Frankenstein monster, I would consider this the most pointless movie of 2004. Some reviewers have noted that Van Helsing borrowed elements from a number of other recent movies. I agree. In that vein, this movie is its own Frankenstein monster. The acting was satisfactory -- I just wish there had been more boldness, creativity and imagination on the other end of the camera. I must add, though, that at least some of my fellow audience members were hugely entertained by the film.

title: For all the SFX, this one just SUX
review:
Even though I love Universal's classic monster movies (as well as Hammer Films' versions, including Kronos, AKA Captain Kronos: Vampire Hunter, I decided to chance Van Helsing. I mean, "how bad could it be?" Famous Last Words...

I did have reservations. For one thing, how could this new film manage putting (almost) all the classic Universal monsters into one movie? Even Universal had a hard time pulling that off -- in fiilms like House of Dracula, House of Frankenstein, et.al. The studio finally got it right when they added Abbott and Costello to the mix and turned the formula into a comedy. Would Van Helsing be a comedy? I wondered...

I held out hope that what little excitement I'd seen in teasers on TV would translate into grand scale entertainment, and that Van Helsing might not be a *great* movie, but might be a fun summertime distraction. WRONG.

All this movie offers is a "video-game-on-steroids" type of experience. This comes through on a number of levels, but one of the most obvious is demonstrated by the way the "heroes" leap and spin and tumble and jump and bounce and twirl and plummet and so on and so on...in ways so humanly impossible that after the first or second "fight scene" I was thinking, "these vampire-fighting characters have no mortality whatsoever; they're invincible...they're BORING!" Any potential thrill of seeing them put in situations of peril was quashed -- after all, you can't kill a cartoon character, and that's what these characters are: totally one-dimensional. The leads in Van Helsing are so ridiculously superhuman, in fact, that it becomes clear that they're never in any real danger no matter how "scary" or "startling" the imagery attempts to be. Even when mortality finally catches up with one of the characters it's not that upsetting. After all, this film is only a video game on steroids...

I am forced to compare it with Conan The Barbarian (arguably another comic-book hero film) or Superman: The Movie (wholly based on DC comics lore), either of which greatly surpass Van Helsing for having soul at the core of their productions. Van Helsing is hollow and gassy. It simply lacks heart.

The barrage of SFx is dizzying and because there is so much action with little time-out for recovery, the effect is mind-numbing. Wearying. Tedious. Cheap-shot moments with werewolves leaping at the viewer startle you to consciousness every so often, but otherwise the pace is monotonous. I found myself checking my watch more than once wondering when the "ride" would end. It felt like it was going around in circles at one point! The storyline (what little there is, and of emininent unimportance) is rattled off in quick handfuls of sentences by the main characters, so quickly that it's clear the film makers have little interest in the fantasy elements except if they can be employed to set up the next elaborate action sequence. The plot, as it is, is totally flushable anyway... This film plays not like a film but like a hugely overstyled video game. The camera follows the action the same way it might in a video game. The characters move from one level to the next as in a video game. The result is pretty ugly, obvious, and tiresome. Worse still, the monsters culled from Universal's prestigious history bear no resemblance whatsoever to the legends created by Boris Karloff, Bela Lugosi, Lon Chaney Jr., et. al. What was the point in Universal's making such a big deal about "reviving" these characters? I know, I know...marketing. Marketing (with a capital M). Well, this film is all about marketing. You can smell it like the stink of a rotting corpse even before you enter the cinema. It almost seems pointless to critique characters in such a one-dimensional production, but it must be said that Van Helsing the character rings hollow, and Hugh Jackman does little to elevate the cardboard hero any higher than absolutely necessary. Any number of talentless nitwits could have played the leads (or the monsters) in this film, and in some cases it seems nitwits were actually cast. No doubt the nerds out there who actually play video games all day long will feel this is a superhero they can sink their teeth into -- and even (dare I say) "identify with" ... The sad fact is, not even great performances by better actors could transform this film into something more than the slick marketing trash it is. SFx is certainly the REAL star of this show. But it's an overbearing star, continually bludgeoning you into senselessness with one daring set-piece piled on top of another. There's no time, if any, to recover from this, and the effect is numbing -- somewhat like the bloated feeling you get after eating too much. By the time the film is over you're simply grateful the roller-coaster has stopped long enough for you to get off.

I was grateful to see the current state of digital effects, which have come a long way in recent years -- and continue to astound. But in this case it was overkill. I was very impressed with a burning windmill in the beginning of the film, one moment I can still recall. There were a few other stand-out moments, but I can't remember those now because they were swept away in the flood of other effects and inane story development.

Just what a 13 year old boy might enjoy, one might say (and clearly this is the target audience since nipples have been left off the breasts of the female vampires). But the 13 year old boy inside me decided Van Helsing was junk. Just a slick marketing tool to get people to spend money at Universal Studios, or buy a dumb video game, or some action figures, etc. Because of this method of film making Van Helsing stands to make some money, but can't be considered much value for your buck.

title: Gimme a break! Gimme a break! Break me off a piece of that ...
review:
I was invited to the premiere of this film last May by my good friend Kevin J. O'Connor, who plays Igor in the film. I didn't exactly get to walk the red carpet, but I did get the inside track on a seat in the Chinese Theater and I got to rub a few elbows with the stars. Rub elbows is what the experience is like in a very literal sense of the word. Something about a premiere brings the weirdest talking cockroaches out of the woodwork and in addition to spying stars like Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale I also saw a few has-beens like Eric Roberts and David Heavener trying to sneak into the wings.

Perhaps the highlight of the event was bumping into Arnold Vosloo, who had been in Sommers' two MUMMY pictures and was hanging around for moral support. Arnold is a funny guy, and I quizzed him about how a few years earlier he'd talked to local sports guy Vic The Brick Jackobs and offered to remove the Mummy's curse off of LA so the Dodgers could win a few games. I guess Arnold is so cool because he hasn't reached Brad Pitt status yet and doesn't have a thousand dewy-eyed fans hanging around.

So what to say of VAN HELSING? Save your money and rent the original horror movies. This movie is busy, like the shower scene in PSYCHO being looped over and over and sped up to about 100 fps. It gave me a headache. Definitely not my kind of movie. Oh, but you were born after 1981 you might like it.

title: Horrific script. Nice sets. Mainly rubbish.
review:
How not to make film: 1. Inherit stable of well loved horror characters from Universal, each with their own fascinating (literary and cinematic) heritage and decide to throw them all into a film. Sounds promising....

2. Ditch virtually all the well established lore and tradition surrounding these characters in favour of stupid unsatisfying premise and threadbare plot. 3. Receive 200 million dollar budget and decide to spend *all* of it on special effects. 4. Ask video game designers to come up with a dozen or so set-piece action sequences(shooting vampires with repeat action crossbow, swinging from rope to rope, obligatory coach-and-horses 'driving section'). Base entire film around these. 5. Cobble together a "story" that attempts to fill in the occasional few minutes between these action scenes with some sort of coherent narrative. Fail. Badly. 6. Realize story is so bad that film is actually a comedy. Sprinkle disastrous hotch-potch of story with lame attempts at humorous one liners. 7. Add 'comedy sidekick' character in vain attempt to distract audience from gaping holes in plot. 8. Add Kate Beckinsale in tight black trousers for same reason. 9. Demand all actors speak in a ridiculous "generic foreign accent" for that 'school play' hammy feel. 10. Throw in a few references to other films (Bond, X Men) etc. in final desperate attempt to engage audience interest.

I genuinely feel sorry for the art designers on this film. They came up with some very impressive and visually stunning sets, only to see them employed in the service of a truly rubbish, rubbish story. Dracula had all the menace and charisma of an insurance salesman, and Van Helsing himself looked mostly bored. The only character with any semblance of interest was a sympathetic portrayal of Frankenstein's monster.

Stephen Sommers needs to watch a few decent films, and take notes on how they establish and build characters and construct a narrative (almost any Spielberg would prove very instructive). Spewing out a dumb action film for yeah-haaah simple-minded teens with no attention span is soiling the horror canon.

Please don't let this man direct or write anything else till he's at least mastered some of the basics of making a film, rather than "some stuff that will look good in the trailer".

title: "It had great special effects"
review:
"It had great special effects." That's about all i heard from any source before going to see this movie. Unfortunately, to a movie, that little five-letter phrase is like what "Can't we just be friends?" is to a relationship: A hint that nothing good is about to happen.

So i went to see it anyway? Of course i did. This movie HAD to be good. I'd been waiting for it to come out for nearly a year. Everything about the concept interested me. A sort of Vampire$ meets Blade. I was even thinking about how pitifully the upcoming Blade 3 would pale in comparison to Van Helsing. I haven't been that naive since the 3rd time i said "I do."

You probably want me to elaborate on what was so bad about it. I wish i could nail it down to any one thing. But i can't quite put my finger on it.

I'll start with the convoluted plot. James Bond, er, i mean Van Helsing, an agent of MI-6, er, i mean a secret religious security/intelligence agency under the auspices of the churches of multiple religious faiths, is sent (accompanied by Q, er, i mean Carl, the weapons/gadgets expert from MI-6, er, I mean...oh forget it!) to find/aid the last remaining descendants of a family that has been battling Count Dracula for several centuries. Why the sudden urgency? Because the family pledged long ago never to set foot in heaven until the Count has been defeated. Should the last of the family fall, their souls and those of all their ancestors will be forever in limbo between heaven and purgatory. There's an equally convoluted sub-plot/co-plot involving the Dracula family that i won't bother going into as there's no easy way to do it without going spoilers.

The actors/actresses all seemed about as interested in being in this movie as i felt in watching it. Jackman, Beckinsale and Roxburgh, all of whom I've loved in multiple other roles, gave performances worthy of only the most mediocre of after-school-specials. Granted, the movie was so fast-paced that there wasn't much room for petty little things like feeling, or character development, i still couldn't help but imagine as i sat there, how much better the movie might have been if it had been performed as a school play by one of my 2nd wife's kindergarten classes

I hope the writers/producers of this masterpiece are already in a back room somewhere shredding documents and deleting e-mails, because just like in the Enron incident, they've got some 'splaining to do. They're going to have to explain to someone eventually why this movie was made in the first place, much less released in theaters.

title: 5/10 is WAY too generous.
review:
"What, exactly, was wrong with the movie?" I hear you ask...

Well, I'll tell you:

* Plot - Horrid! How could Jackman read this script and think to himself... "Oh yeah, I've GOT to be a part of that!"

* Action - Ludicrous. Ex. They light a windmill up with torches and it HAPPENS to be filled with bottle of alcohol so it can explode into a fiery inferno in less than a minute. Even the humans seem to have super human abilities. Scenes drag on for ages and are poorly cut as to make the editing obvious. Almost as bad as the last Matrix movie, but not quite.

* Acting - n/a.

* Special effects - Inconceivable. Frankenstein's monster doesn't need glowing bits of electricity to look fierce or cool. He's a monster, not a futuristic sci-fi concoction. Now put him back the way he should be before I hurt someone!

I just want those 2 hours back! I don't even care about the money. I thought it would take awhile before I found a movie that was WORSE than Underworld, but... "Mission Accomplished!"

title: Hmmmmm
review: Went to see this film last weekend after being disappointed that we couldn't get tickets to go see 'The Day After Tomorrow' because it had sold out! So instead of going home, we decided to see 'Van Helsing'. Hmmmm.......what can I say? Interesting concept, very good effects and make up and of course costume but on the whole, it was a cross between 1950s 'b' movies and comic strip stories. The director had thrown out the rule book on the origins of Dracula, Frankenstein, etc and has put them all into one film. Was entertaining but won't be buying it on DVD when it is inevitably released in the UK. The best thing I can say about it is the vampires where kick-ass!!

title: Could be better
review: After leaving the cinema, i couldn't help but to have un answered questions in my head about this film. OK the story line wasn't great, or was it because i was trying to compare it to "the league of extraordinary gentlemen" which is why i didn't enjoy it as much as i would of liked to. to be fair to hugh jackman i thought he played his part very well, as he has done in x-men 1 & 2 and i thought he was brilliant in swordfish. I must comment on the special effects as with most films now a days they were second to none i really like the scene in notre damm where our hero dr. van helsing is in chase of mr hyde where they finally come face to face with each other before a fight breaks out, the effects of that are fantastic but overall its the story that counts and I'm afraid to say in my view, the story line did let it down, it could have been a much better film.

title: Disappointing and uneconomical
review: "Van Helsing", the first "guaranteed blockbuster smash" of the manic summer movie season, amounts to the most frivolous abuses of CGI lacking any intelligence or even plot. Starts out somewhat intriguing, broaches the vampire hunter with some style and, well the rest of the movie is simply ruthless, brainless, and frivolous to the extent of disturbance. Generally, a film which boasts fantastic CGI can succeed IF it is reasonable and enjoyable enough for the audience to believe and enjoy its "popcorn rollercoaster". Yet, every once in a style, the likes of "Van Helsing" arrives, with ample anticipation and, it sincerely disappoints us in its desecrating foolishness, and we are merely lulled to sleep rather than intoxicated by its exhilaration and mindless fun. The creatures conquered by the vampire hunter whose name "they all know" are nothing short of ridiculous, silly plot contrivances to excuse the film's lack of innovation for better ideas. And this film could have greatly succeeded, if only handled on the right note, and not on the silliness of vampires, bats, and frankenstein creatures, none of which are either convincing nor exhilarating. Heart pounding music and impressive CGI, yet scarcely in the right places. Even the summer movie season should promise us more than "Van Helsing". ** out of ****

title: Just gets sillier
review: *spoilers* >From the very beginning, it's obvious that VAN HELSING was going to be an over the top CGI adventure pic that isn't meant to be taken too seriously. Fair enough: the initial scenes are fun, especially the fight with Mr Hyde and the first attack of Dracula's brides. BUT THE FILM JUST GETS SILLIER. By the time we've been introduced to other-dimensional mirror doorways and a vampire reproductive cycle that seems to be more like an alien pod-laying idea stolen from a Science Fiction move, this film becomes just too preposterous! If the baby vampires had been better designed they could've (slightly) saved this film. As it is, they resemble silly, cartoonish bat-things straight out of a Scooby Doo cartoon. When the first batch attack the village they don't seem nasty enough to the THE BIG THREAT that they're meant to be. IF these critters had actually looked like creepy flying baby vampires they might've worked (but I think that makers of this film wimped out of that idea because they considered the sight of exploding human-looking baby vampires to be too horrible.) The sequence where a vast chamber of hanging cocoons is filled with electricity looks like some out-take from a sub-par Matrix film. The monsters in ABBOTT AND COSTELLO MEET FRANKENSTEIN are far, far better than the Universal monsters on show here. Dracula, especially, is a travesty of the original. Awful! Pathetic! My 12 year-old nephew, however, thought the film was great.

title: Where has all the logic gone ?
review: Well, there has not been a movie like this for some time. Ads for it everywhere, no matter if subway, television or print media. I admit Mr. Wolverine did his job very well, but even a good actor cant save the movie if the script is that bad. It looks as if they took the plot of 200 B-movies, put it together - no matter if there are huge logical holes in this storyline. Okay, the sexy Underground-Lady is fighting against Werewolves, Vampires, even against Mr. Longteeth himself (should this be the prototype of a gay vampire king?) and doesn't even get scratched. But in the end, she gets killed (!) or rather crushed by Helsing. Helloooo??? Please, do me one favour and don't do a 2nd part of this nightmare.

title: A James Bond Movie in a Gothic Setting
review: I thought that I recognized the James Bond formula in Van Helsing. The villain is shown doing some evil deed. Then the hero is shown finishing up a prior mission. He returns to headquarters and is given the assignment which will be the body of the movie. Q demonstrates some gadgets that will come in handy and off Bond/Van Helsing goes. The villain's plan for world domination is elaborated and endless chase scenes ensue, culminating in the triumph of 00-Helsing over the villain. I have never felt so out five bucks.

title: Good Fun, If You're in the Right Mood
review:
I have to say that I am a big fan of "Dracula" and "Frankenstein" and all those other classic monsters. I've seen a lot of the old 1930s Universal films and I've read the original novels. Apart from some of the character names, "Van Helsing" has absolutely nothing to do with the original books, or those old movies (although they are cleverly referenced at the start).

In contrast to "Dracula"'s Abraham Van Helsing, an elderly professor, here we have Gabriel Van Helsing (Hugh Jackman), kind of a cross between Indiana Jones and James Bond on a mission to rid the world of evil monsters. Summoned by his employers, a secret Vatican organisation, to Transylvania, Van Helsing soon finds himself doing battle with Dracula, his three vampire brides, the Wolf-Man and Frankenstein's Monster.

The acting is wooden, the script is awful and the plot inconsistancies mount up, but this film is still a lot of fun! The special effects are great, the action scenes are impressive, the three vampire women are beautiful and there are a few laughs.

It's just a loud, fast, dumb action film, and providing you accept that going in you can have a lot of fun.

Personally, I enjoyed it. I thought it was great fun.

title: .:: Pointless action, uninteresting story, very linear ::.
review:
[May contain spoilers!]

Very very weak and stupid. So many annoying points to mention, that it would be no fun to think about them again. To me it seemed to be a children's film. And it certainly would be one, if there weren't so many brutal scenes at all. The director mixed-up information about all kinds of creatures: vampires, werewolfs, frankenstein's monster, Dracula, jekyll & hyde  in the end, vampires are even killed by silver pegs, which are originally invented to kill werewolfs.

Everytime monster-killer Val Helsing starts off to fulfil his orders, a whizz-kid provides him with the latest stuff to properly kill any evil creatures (like the supplier in James Bond films before every big task). This time Van Helsing leaves to get rid off the big boss' Dracula. Young amazon-lady Anna living in Transilvania carries out her duty to help him. There are a few problems like the people in town who were accomplished to being surrounded by vampires and not willing to support chaos, Frankenstein's monster being the target of Dracula due to the formula of endless life and Anna's brother mutating to a werewolf. But whatever may come into the way of Van Helsing seems to be no real problem, he simply rips it off.

I rated it 3/10, because of the great surroundings and atmosphere in the film. This is really something mentionable: the special effects are quite good (but not well integrated into the film at all, unlike in the film Alien e.g.), the places and localities are somewhat interesting. Besides that, this film is a waste of time.

title: Like being in a trashcan with someone banging on the lid...on Halloween.
review: Like being in a trashcan with someone banging on the lid...on Halloween. Van Helsing holds the dubious distinction, in my life, as the first movie that I have ever walked out on. And I'm a huge Horror / Monster movie fan too. I didn't even pay for the ticket myself and I still want my money back! Van Helsing was about as engaging as watching X-Box Duke it out with Playstation. My vacuum cleaner could have written a better screenplay than this. The old Saturday morning Johnny Quest cartoons had better story lines than this giant piece of CGI rotting compost. Oh where have you gone Boris and Bela, our nation turns its' horror film going eyes to you...

title: this movie is so bad, you have to see it to believe it!

title: WOW
review: This Movie is awesome. I love it. The computer graphics weren't as good as I thought they would be but the story was amazing and interesting. One of my favorite characters was Carl. He was great and hilarious. My folks and I thought it was an 11 out of 10. The one problem with this whole story is that when I was coming out of the theater, people didn't get some parts like who Van Helsing really was ( which i got) and why only a werewolf can hurt the Count (Which I got)? So other than that, good job. The actors did a great job, but the whole vampire thing was over doing it. For example, the baby thing was over doing it and the death scene of one of the characters was so fake.

title: Typical Hollywood monster movie.
review:
Van Helsing was a typical Hollywood monster movie. It could have been much more, the basic idea is good. Van Helsing is interesting character and i think that Dracula is a good choice to be the "Bad guy".

Actors in this movie were all right, Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale and Richard Roxburgh were good but not anything special. David Wenham, the monk, was really good, he was funny and he didn't overacted.

The plot was boring and typical, kill the bad vampire and save the girl etc, something was missing. Special effects where OK. Flying brides of Dracula were nice.

All in all this movie was a bit of disappointment to me. But it's not a completely bad movie. If you want simple monster killing action with good actors, watch this movie.

title: Terrible, plain terrible
review: Incredibly fast-paced videogame. I have never ever before agreed on the saying "it is like a videogame" about any movies. But this really is. Why does Mr. Hyde move like a stupid Chimpanzee? Why do we hear fast action music eve when we should not? It felt we have that inappropriately placed (otherwise not bad) music in some places just because the director could not come up with anything explosive in those scenes. But however fast this movie was, it was quite boring. it is easier to start sleeping during constant gunfire than when we do not have explosions every minute. Before Van Helsing and The Day After Tomorrow I thought Emmerich and Sommers are just the same poor Spielberg-imitators. But Emmerich is much higher quality, and this is not a praise for him...

title: great adventure
review:
I absolutely loved this movie, Hugh Jackman and Kate Beckinsale is just wonderful. Now Hugh Jackman have turned to my "one of the sexiest man i ever seen" list. Last time i saw him was in x-men. I love Kate Beckinsale, she is one of my favorite actresses, and she was so cool in the movie, i loved her in "Pearl Harbor" and "Underworld". She must keep playing in more movies too. This movie had an incredible storyline, without the vampires i think it would be better. But it was exiting to see wolfman again and also Frankenstein. But the real Dracula looked real ugly. i rate this movie 10/10

title: Nice one, with some flaws.
review: Yeah, Van Helsing is a nice film. But too many "poetic licences". There are a lot of ropes, there just to help one character to jump and then finish right at the exact time and place where he/her is supposed to be ? OK, I might live with that, only if it was all. Another thing, in the middle of the Carpathians, in a lost village full of ugly farmers ready to suspect anyone lives Anna Valerious, this woman that appears with such a beauty has sprung from those people? I hardly believe that. But after all, Jackman was perfect and Roxburgh too, the costumes where wonderful and even the settings. Nice way to spend an evening, if you don't have anything better to watch.

title: Glad I saw it for Free
review:
Apologies from the start for any comparisons with The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen, but there are a couple of "extraordinary" coincidences. Firstly, both deal with victorian Gothic horror. Where as TLG started as a clever book that was dumbed down for film, Van Helsing from the opening scenes promised to be nothing more than "Top Trumps" of horror movies (for the under 20's, "Top Trumps" is the same idea as pokemon") that dealt intelligently with the same characters. Secondly, Mr Hyde was remarkably similar in both films.

Despite the prospect of Van Helsing wiping out every monster of film history, it failed to deliver. Don't get me wrong, practically every monster was in it... just not a lot happened. Frankenstein's monster was for want of a better word, crap. Van Helsing's monk (sorry Fry), reprised the role of Q from James Bond fame, mixed with Pete Prostlewaites' role in Dragon Heart. In other words "comedy" relief in a semaphored style. I found myself surprisingly bored through various sections of the movie. Had the movie gone for die hard 3 thrills, it would have been perfect, but too often, it tried to explain it's lack of plot - and failed.

After the first five minutes all originality is used up, and if like me, you have read all the books concerned, part of your brain will be correcting the story throughout the rest of the film - because no-one else has.

Shame really. Dumber or Cleverer, either would have worked.

title: The best of the Frankenstein, Dracula, Werewolf Genre.
review: I just saw it and loved it. I almost chose not to see it because of the morons who panned it. The special effects are what everyone said they would be. Great. Best werewolves ever and awesome Gothic settings. The storyline is solid, unlike what others have declared. What were they watching? Dummies. Vampires in cloudy daylight, not direct sunlight was offered as the reason they were out during the day, and they wanted to surprise Kate. Great action. Dracula's accent was just fine, and so were those of his wives. What a bunch of malcontents to criticize a film of this caliber. In the future, this will grow to become known as a classic despite the recent low ratings and criticisms from some IMDb members. Critics take note! This is a first-rate film, one of the best of its kind, and obviously a labor of love.

title: Exceptionally well put together ! 9 out of 10
review: If you love the classic Monster and don't mind seeing the story altered then this is the movie for you! Huge Jackman gives a splendid performance in the movie as the monster hunting good guy who answers to a law of his own. The three major monsters were exceptionally well done, unique but still holding true to their own standards. I have to say that the reason that this movie did not get a 10 out of 10 was entirely due to certain specific enhanced scenes. I found that after such amazing special effect that went into the vampires and the wolf man, that some scenes were almost painful to watch - they were so obviously faked. Never the less the plot line of this movie was very well laid out, planed and presented in a wonderfully viewer friendly manner  giving you just enough but never too much and all of it actually made sense in the end!  With many unexpected twists and turns. Over all this was a spectacular movie of action adventure with just the right blend of comedy and romance to make it one of my new personal favorites! 9 out of 10!

Rate:10/10

title: At least Summer 2004 can only get better after this disaster.
review: What a waste. A waste of timeless characters (Dracula, Wolfman, and Frankenstein's monster are ruined for an entire generation of film-goers.) A waste of talent (the suave Hugh Jackman and beautiful Kate Beckinsale have hit bottom.) And finally, a waste of time (nearly two and a half hours of total boredom.) There was a cool concept to be found somewhere in this mess, admittedly. Universal Pictures has a stock of classic monsters, and have brought them together for one adventure by re-inventing Dracula's nemesis Van Helsing as a sort of 19th century ghost buster. This project must have been doomed from script stage, though, because that's when Universal handed everything over to writer/director Stephen Sommers, the genius behind those two silly MUMMY re-makes. Sommers rapes and plunders great monster movies, making Dracula, Wolfman, and Frankenstein's monster unrecognizable CGI Hulks, with no regard to their actual "history" or "legend" as characters. He takes fantastic, undoubtedly expensive sets and locations, and fills them up with frantic, non-sensual stunts and action. It's a crime to think that this pile of garbage cost $160 million.

title: The BEST-WORST movie, EVER!
review:
Other titles for this film could include Van Hellsing and the Search for the Holy Pail or perhaps The Van Hellsing Horror Picture Show. It was terrible, but in its atrocities it was wonderful! I must say it is one of the finest comedies out there to date. The dilemma of course comes in the fact that it is meant to be an action-adventure / horror movie.

From the opening scenes I was expecting a few things. A> A cameo by Mel Brooks, B> A cheesy song and dance number ala Monty Python or Moulin Rouge, C> Someone to do the 'alas' position with their left hand stapled to forehead, and/or lastly D> A man driving a Lexus across the country side beaming, safe and secure due to the fine engineering of his car and the anti lock breaks with somehow make him unconcerned about the mob of villagers or debris from an exploding windmill.

The acting was terrible. I would expect the same level of melodrama from a high school drama club, a bunch of goth wannabes, or a poorly designed White Wolf LARP. The main character of Van Hellsing played by Mr. Hugh Jackman was more of akin to a little kid pretending to be Batman then anything else. The lead chick, played by Kate Beckinsale (Serendipity and Much Ado About Nothing) whose character's name I've forgotten, but whose corset enhanced breasts and leather tight costume will remain in my memory happily, was equally unsatisfying except on the eyes and the fact that unlike most bad ass chicks in movies, she actually would hurt herself doing stunts as someone dressed like her would if they tired to do flips all over the place.

Dracula, played by the same man that was 'The Duke' in Moulin Rouge, was the most uncharismatic, cheesy-monkeyish, fruity, and untalented excuse for a vampire I've EVER seen. At least Leslie Nielsen was supposed to be funny. This Dracula was supposed to be scary I think but believe me when I say between him and his brides I was getting cramps from laughing so hard. His brides were acting like 13 year old pop star fans with breast implants I kept expecting them to ask to go to the mall. This one scene where our man Vald was reminding them that he had no heart and could not love was PLEADING for a musical number complete with fountains and dancing girls ala Los Vegas.

Well what about the other villains? CGI was their friend. The entire movie was most likely done on photo shop. Mr. Hyde was a Wolverine wannabe crossed with the Hulk/Beast and just plain silly. The Wolfman was alright, in a Vampire Hunter D sort of way. Frankenstein's monster was a total fruity goth kitten that I'd expect to see at the Castle, complete with the 'Alas my poor soul, I just want to live' occasional head toss, which on hulking beast charged with electricity does not invoke sympathy, but is so funny you want to slap yourself until you're babbling about jade monkeys at midnight.

Overall, the MVP of the movie was hands down the one intended to be comic relief of the film. David Wanham (Audrey from Moulin Rouge and Faramir from Lord of the Rings) had the best lines and was the character I think audiences will most identify with. At points, he was ACTUALLY ACTING! As the comical Friar Carl he was one part Q (from James Bond), one part Friar Tuck, and all parts amusing. By far my personal favorite character in the entire flick.

And what was up with all the Absinth in the windmill? Was it another reference to Moulin Rouge or maybe just a nod to the beverage of choice by the writers who came up with the cliché dialogue. Though to be honest, at several point of the film I was longing for a little bit of the 'green fairy' myself, as it might have made some of the scenes even MORE amusing.

So as the Python boys like to say, always look on the bright side of life (were you expecting the Spanish Inquisition?). The movie's redeeming qualities other then in Wanham's performance was in the cinematography, use of light and color, and scenery. Very nicely done! Visually the movie was great. From stunts to sets the movie was very eye catching. More over, for a hormone charged public every one had at least one piece of eye candy.

Overall, the movie was the bastard gang bang love child of a deranged 'Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory' (complete with Oompa Loompa minion), a less cool Vampire Hunter D, and 'Dracula Dead and Loving It' maybe sprinkled with 'Jesus Christ Vampire Slayer'. In conclusion, I must admit I enjoyed myself because I was expecting a crap movie and got one. I didn't have to focus on how horrible the movie was but instead could laugh so hard my sides were hurting. This will be a movie I will be purchasing, if only for a good laugh now and then.

title: Disjointed, uneven (SPOILERS)
review:
Well, it's certainly not as bad as it could be (the trailer for 'Soul Plane' convinced me of that), but it's not as good as it could be, either. The problem seems to be that the director had no idea other than to put all of these monsters together in one movie. Once he'd achieved that, he didn't seem to much care about the rest of the movie, which served primarily as a means of transitioning from one action scene to another. He never made up his mind whether he was creating a serious monster movie, a monster movie with humorous overtones, a parody of monster movies, or an homage to monster movies, or some combination of the above.

The product is disjointed, uneven, unrealized. The soundtrack was relentless, bombastic, and relentlessly derivative. The monsters are so overblown and unrealistic that they lose any power to frighten; they are clearly the creation of mad hackers, not mad scientists. They are incarnations of bits and bytes, not incarnations of evil. The movie lacks any real suspense; we don't much care whether CGI characters disappear from the Matrix  I mean, the movie, and every other 'plot twist' is telegraphed two weeks in advance. Was anyone surprised to discover what or who the 'Left Hand of God' was? Or that Anna did see her brother again?

The script provides opportunities for humor, but none are realized due to poor timing and delivery. The biggest laughs came in response to what were evidently intended to be pathos-laden scenes, but were pathetic in a different meaning of the term. The human characters are as flat and two-dimensional as the digital characters. The blame for this lies with the director and the writers, not the actors. They did what they could with what they were given, but it is clear that the director's real concern was with the virtual characters.

Exposition is not character development. All we know about the characters is what we are told. Van Helsing never convinced me that he was the scourge of evil; he seemed more like a nice guy caught in the wrong movie and trying to make the best of the situation. He kills monster as a means to self-realization? That New Age psychobabble doesn't even make sense today, let alone in the 19th century. Is he supposed to be a dark, brooding figure, or one with his tongue firmly in his cheek? If the second, his tongue keeps slipping, as does his accent. I heard American, English, and Australian, often in the same sentence. Or was that an obtuse reference to his being a citizen of the world? Others have remarked on the similarities to Hugh Jackman's other franchise character, Wolverine. Suffice it to say that midway through the movie, we were referring to him as 'Logan Van Helsing.' Except that Logan, a true cartoon character, displays a deeper level of angst and human suffering that Van Helsing. We laughed when the werewolf howled.

Anna Valerious looks like Wonder Woman by way of Transylvania. There is as much chemistry between Van Helsing and Anna as would be expected between a human and a cartoon character, as well. Unfortunately, her redemption scene elicited giggles and whispers of 'Simba,' rather than sniffles and tears. Well, at least she finally gets to see the sea.
